[20:43:00.0000] <annevk>
for continuity, the above was handled in /msg

[20:47:00.0000] <annevk>
so for the CSS value API we need some kind of hashmap and some kind of list

[20:47:01.0000] <annevk>
e.g. for 'margin' you need a hashmap and for 'cursor' you'd need a list

[20:48:00.0000] <annevk>
the hashmap can be immutable, but the list needs to be mutable

[20:49:00.0000] <annevk>
another constrain is that both the hashmap interface and list interface might need to be implemented on the same object in certain scenarios (for backwards compatibility; if something changes from being just a hashmap into a comma-separated list of hashmaps)

[20:49:01.0000] <annevk>
current sketch I have:

[20:49:02.0000] <annevk>
map { mapLength, mapKey(), getter getMapItem() }

[20:51:00.0000] <annevk>
list { listLength, insertListItem), deleteListItem(), getter getListItem() }

[20:52:00.0000] <annevk>
since getListItem() takes an int and getMapItem() takes a string the getter thing ought to work

[20:52:01.0000] <annevk>
thoughts?

[21:04:00.0000] <annevk>

[06:50:01.0000] <asmodai>

[06:53:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:53:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:54:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:54:01.0000] <hsivonen>
setAttributeNS sucks, but if script authors use the href setter, they don't need the NS-aware attribute setter

[06:55:00.0000] <hsivonen>
and writing xlink:href is not *that* terrible when factoring in the backwards compat benefit

[06:57:00.0000] <shepazutoo>

[06:57:01.0000] <hsivonen>
shepazutoo: if we're making incompatible changes to SVG, let's kill the load event

[06:57:02.0000] <hsivonen>

[06:58:00.0000] <shepazutoo>

[22:42:00.0000] <Hixie>

[22:47:00.0000] <rjett>

[22:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
sounds like you have a proxy that's blocking outgoing connections

[22:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
i recommend either looking to see if you can use a SOCKS proxy, assuming your browser supports that, or using port 443 and TLS-encrypting the websocket connection

[11:32:02.0000] <dglazkov>

[11:33:00.0000] <dglazkov>
it's a bit weird, but all browsers seem to agree, so probably should be spec'd

[11:33:01.0000] <dglazkov>
for size == 1, first item is selected by default

[11:33:02.0000] <dglazkov>
if no other items are selected

[11:34:00.0000] <dglazkov>
but then if you change the size, the default selection is preserved.

[11:34:01.0000] <dglazkov>

[11:34:02.0000] <dglazkov>

[11:34:03.0000] <annevk>

[11:36:00.0000] <annevk>
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/the-xhtml-syntax.html#the-select-element-0

[11:36:01.0000] <annevk>
defines UI

[11:36:02.0000] <annevk>
i.e. what to render for various values of size

[11:38:00.0000] <annevk>
I think it is defined also that the first is selected

[11:38:01.0000] <annevk>
"If the multiple attribute is absent, whenever there are no option elements in the select element's list of options that have their selectedness set to true, the user agent must set the selectedness of the first option element in the list of options in tree order that is not disabled, if any, to true."

[11:38:02.0000] <annevk>
(that's in section 4.10 again)

[11:52:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
So what's so bad about allowing xml style self-closing on all elements?

[11:52:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Or on divs and spans?

[11:53:00.0000] <Philip`>
Legacy compatibility

[11:54:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
JonathanNeal, no existing browser parses them that way in text/html.

[11:54:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
And none can change, because there are pages that use the self-closing syntax but actually rely on the fact that it's not self-closing.

[11:55:00.0000] <tabatkins>
I've never been a fan of the term "rely" in that context, because it implies they did it on purpose, when really they just did it, then hacked around it until it sort of worked.

[11:56:00.0000] <Philip`>
Why do you think reliance is purposeful?

[11:57:00.0000] <Philip`>
I rely on lots of things that I've never even considered

[11:57:01.0000] <dglazkov>

[11:57:03.0000] <Philip`>

[12:00:00.0000] <tabatkins>

[12:07:00.0000] <annevk>
dglazkov, cool

[12:17:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
AryehGregor, so you don't do it so it's more compatible with the old html version?

[12:18:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
JonathanNeal, there is no "old HTML version".  HTML5 is the one and only specification to fully specify the details of the text/html format that has been used for years.

[12:18:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
ok

[12:18:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
All these implementation requirements (or variants there of) were a de facto standard for a long time, now they're becoming de jure.

[12:19:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Previous HTML specs just didn't say anything about error handling by implementations.

[12:20:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So <div /> was non-conforming in HTML prior to XHTML, and browsers consistently ignored the "/" (which was allowed by the HTML specs of the time).

[12:21:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
So it's just a property of hypertext to not have self-closing elements?

[12:21:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
or bi-closing elements?

[12:21:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
The closing "/" was not valid in any version of HTML prior to XHTML 1.0.

[12:22:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's an XML feature, not a text/html feature.

[12:22:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It would raise validation errors if you used it, which no one did, because it did nothing anyway.

[12:23:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
XHTML allowed the self-closing feature, but browsers didn't implement it in text/html for compatibility reasons.

[12:23:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
And still don't, and presumably never will.

[12:24:00.0000] <Philip`>
Actually it wouldn't raise validation errors, because SGML-based HTML4 parsers (e.g. validator.w3.org) consider <br/> to be correct and equivalent to <br>&gt; or whatever it is

[12:25:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Right, and there is meta and link too

[12:25:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
and img

[12:25:02.0000] <Philip`>
It's never meant "self-closing" in non-X HTML

[12:25:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Oh, really?  Interesting.

[12:26:00.0000] <Philip`>
SHORTTAG and NET are relevant keywords

[12:27:00.0000] <Philip`>
http://lists.whatwg.org/htdig.cgi/whatwg-whatwg.org/2004-August/001940.html

[12:27:01.0000] <Philip`>
(The W3C validator does warn about these things now, though)

[12:30:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
So <br> <img> are bad?

[12:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
No

[12:32:01.0000] <Philip`>

[12:32:03.0000] <Philip`>
I have no idea what you're talking about :-)

[12:33:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
<img> is okay because it's not an element that opens and closes, it just is.

[12:33:01.0000] <Philip`>

[12:33:02.0000] <tabatkins>
JonathanNeal: In old-style SGML, the / was a way of closing a tag without explicitly using the end tag.

[12:33:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>
So ... <br /> is also valid.

[12:33:04.0000] <JonathanNeal>
So what would be bad about <div /> then?

[12:33:05.0000] <tabatkins>
So you could, frex, do "<div>stuff goes here/" and be equivalent to "<div>stuff goes here</div>"

[12:33:06.0000] <Hixie>

[12:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
<div/stuff goes here/

[12:34:01.0000] <Hixie>
or <br/ (since there's no end tag, no end / either)

[12:34:02.0000] <tabatkins>
Ah yeah, right.

[12:34:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>
No > ?

[12:34:04.0000] <tabatkins>
Nope.

[12:34:05.0000] <Hixie>
the first / takes places of the / and the next / takes place of the entire end tag

[12:34:06.0000] <Hixie>
er

[12:34:07.0000] <Hixie>
let me retype that

[12:34:08.0000] <tabatkins>
Which means that, if browsers were conforming SGML parsers, you'd see a linebreak followed by a > character in your page.

[12:35:00.0000] <Hixie>
the first / takes place of the > and the next / takes place of the entire end tag

[12:35:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Wow!  That's not implemented that way in any browser, is it?

[12:35:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
No, browsers don't actually implement SGML.

[12:36:00.0000] <Hixie>
there's a reason html5 gives up on the sgml fiction :-)

[12:36:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
So, you can do <div /> because it wouldn't be properly conforming to something no browsers actually implement?

[12:36:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
*can't

[12:36:03.0000] <tabatkins>

[12:36:04.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[12:36:05.0000] <tabatkins>

[12:36:06.0000] <Hixie>

[12:37:00.0000] <Hixie>

[12:37:01.0000] <tabatkins>

[12:37:02.0000] <tabatkins>

[12:38:00.0000] <tabatkins>
So allowing <div /> as a short form of <div></div> wouldn't be backwards compatible in any relevant browser straight away, let alone all the pages that accidentally use <div /> and would be screwed up if it actually acted like <div></div>.

[12:45:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[12:45:03.0000] <Philip`>

[12:45:04.0000] <Philip`>

[12:46:02.0000] <Philip`>

[15:58:02.0000] <divya>
A question, In CSS3 the display property refers to block/inline elements http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-layout/#declaring-templates-the-display-property but HTML5 does not define block/inline elements. Is there something I am missing? 

[15:58:03.0000] <Philip`>
and they're rubbish compared to mouse+keyboard for FPSes anyway

[15:59:00.0000] <tabatkins>
divya: In terms of CSS, a block/inline element is one which has display:block/inline set on it in the default UA stylesheet.

[15:59:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
divya, look in the rendering section.

[15:59:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/rendering.html#rendering

[16:00:00.0000] <divya>
tabatkins: so does this mean display no longer alters the "content model" of an element? 

[16:00:01.0000] <Hixie>
a block/inline element in CSS is one which has display:block/inline as its computed value, not necessarily in the UA style sheet

[16:00:02.0000] <Hixie>
divya: it never did

[16:01:00.0000] <tabatkins>
Hixie is more correct than I was.  I was referring to what elements were by default.

[16:02:00.0000] <Hixie>
technically even its _used_ style, not computed style, though i think with 'display' they're always the same

[16:02:01.0000] <Hixie>
(or does 'position' not affect the computed style?)

[16:03:00.0000] <Hixie>
an element with display:inline;position:absolute is block-level

[16:03:01.0000] <Hixie>
ok yeah for such an element the computed value is 'block'

[16:03:02.0000] <Hixie>
so yes, computed value

[16:05:00.0000] <divya>
Hixie: I was under the illusion display can alter the content model because of this sentence in the HTML4.01 spec http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/struct/global.html#h-7.5.3 "Style sheets provide the means to specify the rendering of arbitrary elements, including whether an element is rendered as block or inline. "

[16:05:01.0000] <tabatkins>
Rendered as a block or inline, yes.  That doesn't change what kind of elements are legal to put inside of it, though.

[16:06:00.0000] <Hixie>
divya: yeah, that confusion is why i stopped using "block" and "inline" in html5

[16:06:01.0000] <Hixie>
it confused a lot of people

[16:06:02.0000] <Hixie>
you're not alone, by a long shot :-)

[16:07:00.0000] <divya>
Hixie: thanks, that is a comfort :) 

[16:07:01.0000] <Hixie>
:-)

[16:08:00.0000] <divya>
so in a sense display:inline/block are legacy CSS syntaxes with no real-world relationship with the elements?

[16:09:00.0000] <tabatkins>
I'm not sure what you mean by "legacy" or "real-world" there.  CSS has no interaction with what's legal or illegal in HTML.

[16:09:01.0000] <Hixie>
that's not how i would put it

[16:09:02.0000] <Hixie>
i'd just say display:inline/block conrtol the rendering

[16:09:03.0000] <Hixie>
and that's all :-)

[16:09:04.0000] <divya>
ok that makes sense :)

[16:10:00.0000] <divya>
(I think it is hard for me to not get confused between css inline/block and html4 inline/block)

[16:10:01.0000] <tabatkins>
Easiest is to probably just ignore the HTML4 definitions entirely.  ^_^

[16:11:00.0000] <divya>
tabatkins: :)

[16:11:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I bet that's why HTML5 doesn't use those terms to begin with.

[16:12:00.0000] <divya>
I wonder why not many people brought this up. :/

[16:12:01.0000] <divya>
(when they were writing their "Top Ten CSS Tricks" posts)

[16:13:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[16:14:00.0000] <divya>

[16:14:01.0000] <estellevw>
i found the distinction of block, inline and flow very helpful to understanding the semantics of elements

[16:14:02.0000] <Hixie>
/me has no idea what to do about character references that don't end with ;

[16:14:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hixie, are they used too much to just be dropped?

[16:15:00.0000] <Hixie>
yes

[16:15:01.0000] <Hixie>
there are bugs that ask for various changes to the way they're parsed

[16:15:02.0000] <Hixie>
9351, 9207

[16:15:03.0000] <Hixie>
or reported as errors

[16:15:04.0000] <Hixie>
9352

[16:16:00.0000] <Hixie>
we could make unescaped & not be an error but leave charrefs that don't have a ; be an error, i guess

[16:16:01.0000] <Hixie>
so "?a=b&c=d" would be fine

[16:16:02.0000] <GarethAdams|Home>
how do you tell the difference?

[16:17:00.0000] <Hixie>
but "?apple=banana&copy=ditto" would be an error (since the &copy gets parsed in an unexpected way)

[16:17:01.0000] <GarethAdams|Home>
oh, so from the fixed list of known entities

[16:17:02.0000] <Hixie>
or we could make &copy= not be parsed as a char ref in attributes

[16:17:03.0000] <Hixie>
just like &copypasta already isn't

[16:18:00.0000] <Hixie>
but that makes attributes even more different than content

[16:18:01.0000] <tabatkins>
Are we sure that char references without a trailing ; appear in attributes, especially @href and similar, often enough to cause a problem?

[16:18:02.0000] <Hixie>
tabatkins: cause problems in which direction?

[16:18:03.0000] <tabatkins>
In the direction of, if we make them not parse as entities, links will break.

[16:19:00.0000] <Hixie>
tabatkins: i expect there are plenty of pages that say "?foo=bar&copy=ditto" and are broken, and i expect there are plenty of pages that say "this file &copy 2010 by me" and expect it to be an entity.

[16:19:01.0000] <tabatkins>
Sure.

[16:19:02.0000] <Hixie>
the latter is even valid in ghtml4

[16:19:03.0000] <Hixie>
s/g//

[16:20:00.0000] <Hixie>
so yes, things will break if we change anything, and things are broken if we don't change anything

[16:20:01.0000] <tabatkins>
I think I'm fine with attributes being different from content here.

[16:20:02.0000] <Hixie>
i'm only talking about attributes here

[16:21:00.0000] <Hixie>
they're already different than content, so that ship has sailed -- teh question is whether we can keep that to a minimum, so that people moving stuff in and out of attributes don't get screwed

[16:21:01.0000] <Hixie>
i'd really like to make any valid content in one have the same meaning in the other

[16:21:02.0000] <Hixie>
invalid content is less of an issue

[16:22:00.0000] <tabatkins>
I'd like links to be easy to author, and not have to worry about the names of my query paramaters.

[16:22:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's too bad we can't just make &copy equivalent to &amp;copy in content as well.

[16:22:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
But the extra difference between content and attributes seems like the lesser evil here.

[16:22:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's not like it should come up very often in practice.

[16:23:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
You could make "&copy" and such raise a warning or error if used in content.

[16:23:01.0000] <tabatkins>
It would be interesting to try and see how much outcry there is (try making entities require a ;, and allow unescaped & otherwise).

[16:23:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yeah, I wonder if implementers would do that.  How many pages are we talking about?  It wouldn't be huge breakage in any case, if it's largely in copyright boilerplate then most users probably won't even notice.

[16:24:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
(even if they view an affected page)

[16:24:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me wonders why tabatkins has decapitalized himself

[16:24:02.0000] <tabatkins>
Indeed.

[16:24:03.0000] <Hixie>
we're talking billions of pages here

[16:24:04.0000] <tabatkins>
Eh, accidental.  irssi is taking my account name from linux, and I'm not bothering to correct it.

[16:24:05.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: it would be a disaster in non-english locales

[16:25:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Oh well.

[16:25:01.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. &egrave is one of these entities

[16:27:00.0000] <Hixie>
suggests the simplest option to improve compatibility on the web is to make = make these entities not get replaced

[16:27:01.0000] <Hixie>
er, http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9207#c5 suggests

[16:27:02.0000] <tabatkins>
= and _, apparently.

[16:27:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
That sounds like a clever solution.

[16:27:04.0000] <Hixie>
_ was not quite as clear

[16:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
ok let's add = and then reexamine the conformance problem.

[16:31:00.0000] <Hixie>
i suppose i could make &foo= be not a parse error in attributes, but otherwise leave these rules alone

[16:31:01.0000] <Hixie>
or i could just make all &foo that don't match an entity be not parse errors

[16:32:00.0000] <Hixie>
the latter seems simpler, though it would lead to authors never bothering to escape their &s, which could get them in trouble if they accidentally walk into &amp;s

[16:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
this would make &foo; (where "foo" isn't anything known) into _not_ an error...

[16:42:00.0000] <dglazkov>
Hixie: I demand a recount

[16:42:01.0000] <dglazkov>
:)

[16:43:00.0000] <dglazkov>
can you point me to the place where the spec says that if the size of select is >1, multiple is not set, and no options have selectedness set to true, we shouldn't mark any item as selected?

[16:45:00.0000] <Hixie>
no, because the spec doesn't say that :-)

[16:45:01.0000] <Hixie>
"If the multiple attribute is absent, whenever there are no option elements in the select element's list of options that have their selectedness set to true, the user agent must set the selectedness of the first option element in the list of options in tree order that is not disabled, if any, to true."

[16:45:02.0000] <dglazkov>
but all browser that I know of do it.

[16:45:03.0000] <Hixie>
do what?

[16:45:04.0000] <dglazkov>
not select if size > 1

[16:46:00.0000] <dglazkov>
annevk told me to do the comment thingy

[16:46:01.0000] <dglazkov>
should I go ahead and do it?

[16:47:00.0000] <Hixie>
how weird

[16:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
why would size="" have any effect on this?

[16:48:01.0000] <Hixie>
please do file a bug

[16:48:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's an easy fix

[16:48:03.0000] <Hixie>
i wonder why browsers act like this

[16:50:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie, dglazkov: I suspect the browser rule is "if it renders as a pop-up menu select the first item, if it renders as a listbox, don't select anything"

[16:50:01.0000] <othermaciej>
because listboxes have a reasonable "nothing selected" state

[16:50:02.0000] <dglazkov>
othermaciej: yes, something like that

[16:50:03.0000] <othermaciej>
that would be why size= has an effect

[16:50:04.0000] <dglazkov>
but if you change the size from X to 1 and then back to X (X>1), you'll have a selected element.

[16:51:00.0000] <othermaciej>
sure, because size changes don't cause the selected element to be deselected

[16:51:01.0000] <dglazkov>
but they do cause the element to be selected :)

[16:51:02.0000] <othermaciej>
and browsers don't keep track of whether something got selected by default

[16:51:03.0000] <dglazkov>
yep

[16:51:04.0000] <dglazkov>
/me is writing a layout test for that

[16:51:05.0000] <othermaciej>
yes, if you enter the "must have a selection" state (no multiple or size > 1), then an item gets default-selected

[16:52:00.0000] <othermaciej>
but when you leave that state, nothing gets deselected

[16:52:01.0000] <othermaciej>
seems logical to me, at least to the extent one can expect logic of the Web platform

[16:54:00.0000] <Hixie>
i guess it makes sense given visual UAs using different widgets and how single-select list boxes can have an (normally unreachable) no-selection state

[16:54:01.0000] <Hixie>
doesn't make much sense from an abstract point of view though


2010-04-03

[17:00:01.0000] <othermaciej>
you can always cmd-click the selected item to deselect it

[17:03:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: wow, so you can

[17:03:01.0000] <Hixie>

[17:07:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[17:16:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Does it break some notion of semantics somewhere for a document to not have a location?

[17:17:00.0000] <othermaciej>
that question is too abstract for me to understand it

[17:17:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
The context is an intended-to-be-ephemeral document created by a page, with a location that is only valid until the creating page is trashed.  I think you can navigate to that url fine (by the time the document is trashed and the url becomes meaningless, the navigation action is already moving).  But what does document.location then return in the new doc?

[17:19:00.0000] <Hixie>
TabAtkins: is this a doc created by document.open(), createDocument(), XHR, window.open(), navigating to a File API URL, a Stream URL, or something else?

[17:19:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Created by a FileWriter.

[17:20:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Note: This isn't defined.  We're asking what it *should* return, and if it's valid for it to have no location.

[17:20:01.0000] <Hixie>
wait, FileWriter returns a Document?

[17:20:02.0000] <Hixie>
you don't want to do that

[17:20:03.0000] <Hixie>
just have FileWriter use the same URL generation mechanism as the File API

[17:21:01.0000] <Hixie>
oh christ it even broke my bookmarklets

[17:22:01.0000] <Hixie>
bbiab, tgif

[17:22:02.0000] <TabAtkins>

[20:14:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[20:14:03.0000] <othermaciej>

[20:15:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[20:15:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:43:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:43:01.0000] <Hixie>

[02:43:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:43:03.0000] <Hixie>

[02:44:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I can see how adoption agency turned out to be the lesser evil

[02:44:01.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. <span style="a"> aaaaa <b style="b"> bbbbb </span> bbbb </b> will result in a DOM like <span> aaaaa <b> bbbbb </b></span> bbbb

[02:44:02.0000] <Hixie>
but it'll use the styles from <b> when rendering the last text node

[02:46:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:46:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[21:50:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: btw, as far as the general rationale for having document-conformance criteria in the spec, I think another reason that could possibly be cited is that non-browser tools that consume HTML also benefit from the existence of constraints that bound the possible markup cases they are designed to process

[21:50:01.0000] <Hixie>
are there any conformance criteria that we've added for that reason?

[21:51:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I don't know if there are some that have been added for that specific reason

[21:51:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
but it is at least a beneficial side effect

[21:51:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
tools can't be expected to process every insane markup case that some author wants to use for whatever bizarre reasons

[21:52:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
e.g., whatever recent bug was arguing that div should be allowed as a child of span

[21:53:00.0000] <Hixie>
depends on the tool

[21:53:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
true

[21:53:02.0000] <Hixie>
not really sure what kind of tool would have problem with that kind of thing

[21:53:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
I guess cases like that actually break the element semantics

[14:47:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
JonathanNeal: fieldset is crazytimes, and not actually done with CSS in any browser

[14:47:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Sure, but you're recommending margins and padding, so why not display type?

[14:48:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The hardest part is positioning <legend> (which, though it is required to be the first child of <fieldset>, for legacy reasons must be accepted as any child) and styling the border (since it breaks behind the <legend>).

[14:48:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Shrug, dunno.

[14:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think <fieldset> is essentially a block other than the special handling of <legend>

[14:54:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
It is.  If we could find a way to specify the border rendering, and the positioning of <legend> without making all <fieldset>s into positioning roots, we could do it all in CSS.

[14:56:00.0000] <othermaciej>
<fieldset> is kind of legacy cruft - it isn't very useful in modern UI design

[14:56:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
It is essentially a block, so is it a bad idea just to write it in?

[14:56:02.0000] <othermaciej>
so not worth spending too much effort on it

[14:56:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>
It's not legacy if you're putting it in the new spec.

[14:56:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
(While I don't really like selectors appearing in values, I suspect that's what would be required to specify <legend>'s positioning.  position-to: "fieldset"; would grab the closest ancestor that matches the selector, and treat it as the positioning root (unless there was a closer ancestor who is actually a positioning root from normal means).

[14:57:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
That would be useful in more than just <fieldset>/<legend>.

[14:57:01.0000] <othermaciej>
in WebKit, fieldset in fact has a display: block rule in the UA stylesheet

[14:57:02.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: to really do fieldset/legend, you need the notion of an interrupted border with something positioned in it, and an item that acts as the border caption for the relevant container

[14:58:00.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: so I think it can be done without selectors in values

[14:58:01.0000] <KrocCamen>

[14:58:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[14:58:03.0000] <KrocCamen>

[14:58:04.0000] <TabAtkins>

[14:58:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
KrocCamen: No, radios know each other by @name.

[14:58:06.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: the latter finds its containing table without the table having to act as a containing block and without specifying it explicitly by selector

remysharp, e.g. you have to roundtrip with the server at least once before you can actually submit a comment

[04:48:02.0000] <annevk>
remysharp, for that first roundtrip validation is not needed, but user feedback might still be useful

[04:49:00.0000] <remysharp>
I still don't see how this works in <form novalidate>

[04:49:01.0000] <remysharp>
sorry, I don't mean to sound like a pain/muppet

[04:49:02.0000] <remysharp>
trying to understand the difference :)

[04:50:00.0000] <remysharp>
one mo, let me mock up my understanding of formnovalidate, and perhaps you can tweak the source to show me how novalidate would work - if that's cool?

[04:52:00.0000] <annevk>
sure

[04:53:00.0000] <remysharp>
example: http://jsbin.com/inaxo3 - editable source: http://jsbin.com/inaxo3/edit

[04:53:01.0000] <remysharp>
so I've got a formnovalidate on the "save" button

[04:53:02.0000] <remysharp>
annevk: hit "new revision" to save any changes you make

[04:57:00.0000] <annevk>
my form would have only one submit button

[04:58:00.0000] <annevk>
see the form here: http://annevankesteren.nl/2010/03/css-wg-brainstorming#comments

[04:58:01.0000] <remysharp>

[04:59:00.0000] <remysharp>
it's a contrived example I know :)

[04:59:01.0000] <remysharp>
it's more to show the formnovalidate attribute working

[04:59:02.0000] <remysharp>
but I'm struggling to see how novalidate comes in to play

[04:59:03.0000] <annevk>
sure, i was just saying that for preview you might not care about validation yet

[05:00:00.0000] <annevk>
and therefore add novalidate to <form>

[05:00:01.0000] <remysharp>
if you use it on the form element, then what's the point in having validation on the form at all?

[05:00:02.0000] <annevk>
user feedback while entering controls

[05:00:03.0000] <annevk>
you still have the form controls apply and all etc. it just doesn't prevent submission

[05:01:00.0000] <annevk>
sites might want to use this too if they don't care if the user got the email address correct or not

[05:01:01.0000] <annevk>
but still want the control to integrate with the address book and create better input methods

[05:01:02.0000] <remysharp>
okay, *that's* what I was looking for

[05:01:03.0000] <remysharp>
perfect, cheers.

[05:02:00.0000] <remysharp>
I can see it being used on the type="email" input, and as you said, still benefits from web forms integration

[05:02:01.0000] <remysharp>
cheers :)

[05:04:00.0000] <annevk>
to be clear, "novalidate" cannot be specified on <input>, just on <form>

[05:05:00.0000] <remysharp>
crap.

[05:05:01.0000] <annevk>

[17:02:01.0000] <volkmar>
i've been told you can explain this choice

[17:03:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah, it's on my pile of feedback

[17:03:01.0000] <Hixie>
in short though the answer is that it makes the authoring experience better

[17:05:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
othermaciej: Yeah, I just talked to TV and he said he did.

[17:08:00.0000] <volkmar>
Hixie: does it make the authoring experince so much better ?

[17:09:00.0000] <volkmar>
Hixie: i think it's a bit odd to set a string to a DOM object to access directly to an attribute

[17:09:01.0000] <volkmar>
i'm not sure it worths it

[17:11:00.0000] <Hixie>
volkmar: it's how window.location works

[17:12:00.0000] <Hixie>
volkmar: i think it's a heck of a lot easier to say  foo.className = 'x y z'; foo.htmlFor = 'a b c';  than to have to make them different as in foo.className = 'x y z'; foo.htmlFor.value = 'a b c';

[23:22:00.0000] <Hixie>
i like how shelley thinks styling controls is some new topic that's never come up before

[23:22:01.0000] <Hixie>
given that i've written entire specifications (e.g. xbl2) on the topic

[23:27:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: I didn't even mention XBL2 as part of the story for deep styling of custom controls, but of course it is a potential part of the toolset

[23:27:01.0000] <othermaciej>
maybe I am just embarrassed that we haven't implemented it yet

[23:27:02.0000] <Hixie>
xbl2 is even designed to be extended to have predefined control bindings, much like what html5 references in the rendering section

[23:28:00.0000] <Hixie>
and supports the pseudos that people are suggesting

[23:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
these are all essentially solved problems at the theoretical level... it's all coding from now on, if y'all agree with my approach. :-P

[23:30:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't think XBL2 solves the problem of minting brand new pseudos... or does it let you make up arbitrary new ones?

[23:31:00.0000] <othermaciej>
also doesn't define all the right appearance property values

[23:31:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think XBL2 is a good tool, but shouldn't be the only way to style form controls

[23:31:02.0000] <Hixie>
we'd need some pseudos from the csswg, and yeah, appearance needs rewriting

[23:31:03.0000] <othermaciej>
nor should form controls have to be implemented with XBL2 to be stylable, although it may turn out to be a convenient implementation technique at some point

[23:31:04.0000] <Hixie>
well, depends what you mean by "only way"

[23:32:00.0000] <Hixie>
i think conceptually it makes sense to pretend the form control is a binding, for expository purposes if not necessarily implementation purposes

[23:32:01.0000] <Hixie>
but anyway

[23:32:02.0000] <Hixie>
i think all the concepts are in place, though some polishing may be needed in various places

[23:33:00.0000] <othermaciej>
well one thing I'd like to see defined is have clear conformance requirements for simply putting CSS properties on <input type=text> and <input type=submit>

[23:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
if we had a conceptual binding combined with a well-defined 'appearance' property, that would be one solution that would work pretty well

[23:34:01.0000] <Hixie>
and would extend well to a world with xbl2

[23:34:02.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: let me be clear about the basic level I am talking about

[23:34:03.0000] <othermaciej>
the styling that <http://www.google.com/> applies to the text field and two buttons...

[23:35:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I would like the result of that to be interoperable and defined by spec

[23:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
per spec, the effect of the CSS properties put on those controls is completely implementation-defined

[23:36:01.0000] <Hixie>
anyone who tries to write a spec to do that will fail to prevent scope creep all the way to defining every property, unless they are _extremely_ resistant to feedback

[23:36:02.0000] <Hixie>
hence why i'd just go all the way and just define it in a way that uses conceptual bindings and true 'appearance' work

[23:36:03.0000] <othermaciej>
yes, you have to define how every property works

[23:37:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't see how appearance helps

[23:37:01.0000] <othermaciej>
that page doesn't set the appearance property

[23:37:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's set by the UA sheet

[23:37:03.0000] <othermaciej>
nor do I see how "conceptual bindings" help, because that page does not use them either

[23:37:04.0000] <Hixie>
they're used by the UA sheet

[23:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
if you define how setting a property overrides 'appearance', and how setting a property affects specific parts of a binding, you ground your definition in something useful

[23:38:01.0000] <Hixie>
it's not the only solution, certainly

[23:38:02.0000] <othermaciej>
overriding 'appearance', I see your point

[23:38:03.0000] <Hixie>
but i think other solutions are far less likely to be sanely scalable or workable in the future

[23:38:04.0000] <othermaciej>
'specific parts of a binding', I don't see how that is relevant to text fields or buttons

[23:38:05.0000] <othermaciej>
I can see how it is relevant to compound controls

[23:38:06.0000] <Hixie>
for text fields and buttons, maybe not

[23:38:07.0000] <othermaciej>
that need to have subparts individually styled

[23:39:00.0000] <Hixie>
but e.g. for <input type=file>, you need to say what the element's styles apply to

[23:39:01.0000] <Hixie>
anyway

[23:39:02.0000] <Hixie>
i'm not planning on doing this work

[23:39:03.0000] <Hixie>
and if others want to do it in a different way, i'm certainly not going to stop them

[23:39:04.0000] <boblet>
annevk: you there?

[23:42:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: yeah, for <input type=file> we have a separate pseudo for the button

[23:43:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: I hope at some point we can find a person with the skills and experience to specify this.

[23:43:01.0000] <Hixie>
add it to the list

[23:52:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it's a big list!

[23:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm thinking a bit less about the big list these days because I want to focus on getting HTML5 through the W3C meat grinder

[23:53:01.0000] <othermaciej>
cause that's gonna be some delicious sausage when it's done

2010-04-08
[17:24:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
TabAtkins, you may find this interesting http://sandbox.thewikies.com/html5-wai/ it attempts to hit many birds with one stone; html5, outline, wai, 508, microformat.

[17:28:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
JonathanNeal: Why are you using <div>s for the main content rather than <article>?

[17:28:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Also, role=document is assumed automatically on <body>, so there's no reason to put a wrapper <div> just to get that.

[17:29:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
It's there in the event I add an application aside of it.

[17:29:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
?_?

[17:29:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
say a dockbar on the top, a chatbar on the side, or some other role="application" aside the main document but on the same page.

[17:30:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Regardless, the <body> is still a role=document, and I don't think it needs to be repeated on the main page.

[17:30:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I assume that anything which isn't explicitly wrapped is considered part of the body's document.

[17:32:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
If that was the case, then there would never be a reason to use more than one role per page.

[17:32:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
clarify --- role="document" || role="application"

[17:33:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'm not sure what you mean.  You just gave a potential reason to use more than one role.  You're embedding applications inside a document.

[17:33:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I can see removing it because it is inherited from body (since body is not overwritten)

[17:34:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Btw, the lynx viewer link you have gets angry if it sees a referer from another page.

[17:34:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
<body><div role="application>dock application</div><div role="document">main document</div><div role="application>chat application</div></body>

[17:34:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I know, I go there and then just re-highlight the addy and return.

[17:34:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Kk, just saying.

[17:34:04.0000] <JonathanNeal>
So ... you're saying that it's unnecessary because in that case ...

[17:34:05.0000] <JonathanNeal>
<body><div role="application>dock application</div><div>main document</div><div role="application>chat application</div></body> ... is just the same

[17:35:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah.

[17:35:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I think.

[17:35:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
/me isn't an expert on ARIA, but that seems to make sense.

[17:35:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Yeah, that makes sense to me too, I think you're right.

[17:44:00.0000] <KaOSoFt>
I'm just a novice but, why <div id="main-content"> and not <section id="main-content">? I'm coding an HTML5 template right now, and I use a <div id="wrap">, but I also (inside the "#wrap") use a <section id="main-content">.

[17:45:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I don't see a particularly good reason for either of those <div>s.  The whole <div><div><section> structure should be swappable for a single <article> or <section>.

[17:47:00.0000] <KaOSoFt>
Well, I read somewhere (unfortunately don't remember where) that now with <section> and <article>, <div> had no semantic meaning, that's why I use it as a meaningless container.

[17:48:00.0000] <KaOSoFt>
Well, while <header> and <footer> should make things "easier", I also have a point of view where they are still <section>s, which means, that I'd do it: <section id="header">, <section id="main-content"> and <section id="footer">, for example.

[17:48:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
<div> Never had semantics meaning, actually.  It was always purely there for the purpose of grouping things to make it easier to throw CSS and JS at the page.

[17:48:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Same with <span>.

[17:50:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The idea of <section>, <article>, <aside>, etc is that some of those groupings *were* semantics, and commonly expressed by authors (often through #ids on the elements), so we can usefully capture those semantics and allow other technologies to use them.

[17:54:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
For me, having a <section id="main-content"> would not be so easy to title.

[17:54:01.0000] <KaOSoFt>
Like I said, elements like <header> and <footer> are just short-cuts to me. They are indeed <section>s. Oh, well, I could just stay with my idea, and use <section id="header"> and the like, but future-proof machines wouldn't understand my web site as well.

[17:54:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
and something like <section id="wrap"> would default the sectioning purpose of <body>

[17:55:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I think there is still room for divs to be organizational for the content, which you could say is semantic.

[17:55:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
<header> isn't a section, actually, and you don't want it to be - it would scope the headings you put in it to itself, and not let them refer to the outer section you put the <header> in!

[17:55:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Since the requirements and recommendations for sectioning are too strict on <section|article|aside|etc>

[17:56:00.0000] <KaOSoFt>
TabAtkins- Hmm, yeah, I'm checking the code on your test-site, and it indeed doesn't use <header> as the header of the document. It uses a <div>, and you use <header> to encompass the headings.

[17:56:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's JonathanNeal.  ^_^

[17:56:02.0000] <KaOSoFt>
Er, yeah, that.

[17:56:03.0000] <KaOSoFt>
:P

[17:56:04.0000] <JonathanNeal>
KaOSoFt, yea that's my test site.  TabAtkins may not want to be associated with that little nugget of joy.

[17:57:00.0000] <KaOSoFt>
Hahaha.

[17:57:01.0000] <KaOSoFt>
God, semantics sometimes can be deceitful.

[17:57:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
You can use <header> as the header of the site!  Nothing wrong with that; in fact, plenty right with it.  It's just not a "section", in the way that <section> and <article> and <aside> are.

[17:59:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Precisely because "sections" scope the headings inside of them, and you *want* headings inside of <header> to apply to the content outside of <header>.

[17:59:01.0000] <KaOSoFt>
Where do you take the role from? Is it part of HTML5 spec?

[17:59:02.0000] <KaOSoFt>
"role="

[17:59:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>
<div id="main-document" /> extends body (the scope isn't changed by sectioning content), and there are instances where I will have other applications aside it, like I mentioned earlier.  The benefit is that, even in instances where there are NOT applications aside of it, I can keep the div because it doesn't have any meaning.

[17:59:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Officially from the ARIA spec, but HTML5 defines how you can use @role on HTML elements.

[18:00:00.0000] <KaOSoFt>
I see.

[18:00:01.0000] <KaOSoFt>
/me goes to check the ARIA spec

[18:01:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
So then it's useful for styling.  Giving it the role was to enforce its intended usage, but without the other DIVs it doesn't seem as necessary, and as TabAtkins is pointing out, the document role may already be inherited.

[18:06:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
KaOSoFt: Basically, ARIA is a way to add additional semantics to documents in ways that the document language doesn't yet allow, so that other types of UAs, like screen readers, can understand what something is.  For example, javascript libraries often let you define a slider control, and build it out of several <div>s.  You can tell what this is and how to use it by looking at it, but if you were having the page read to you you'd have n

[18:07:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
A lot of HTML5 elements now carry native semantics that render a lot of ARIA unnecessary, which is a good thing.  Frex, <input type=range> should replace many uses for sliders.

[18:28:00.0000] <KaOSoFt>
So many things to synchronize. :S

[18:29:00.0000] <KaOSoFt>
Everytime I read about a specification, it makes me wonder how long will it take to really release HTML5.

[18:31:00.0000] <KaOSoFt>
I mean:

[18:31:01.0000] <KaOSoFt>
It's like, there are so many things that HTML5 has currently addressed, that every time I see something new (to me), I wonder how long will it take to make it work together, all synchronized.

[18:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's probably a bad sign that having decided i wasn't sure if "punt" meant what i thought it meant, i looked it up on wikitionary, and the only example usage of the word in the sense i meant it is quoting two people i work with.

[18:35:00.0000] <KaOSoFt>
._.

[18:38:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[19:36:00.0000] <yael_>
hello, can I ask a ARIA related question here?

[19:37:00.0000] <davidb>
yael: sure, there is also #wai-aria

[19:38:00.0000] <davidb>
oh sorry that is on w3c

[19:41:00.0000] <yael_>
I am workin on connecting the progress element to accessibility technology. Since ARIA defines one role for both determinate and indeterminate progress bar, how does the browser convey the difference to the accessibility software?

[19:43:00.0000] <yael_>
On the mac, it says "9 percent" for indeterminate progress bar, and that is obviously wrong.

[19:43:01.0000] <Hixie>
if you're implementing the <progress> element in a browser, you wouldn't use ARIA, you'd use the platform-native accessibility APIs

[19:43:02.0000] <Hixie>
or am i misunderstanding

[19:45:00.0000] <yael_>
You are right, but I am still defining the role for the progress element , and pass that to the platform API.

[19:45:01.0000] <othermaciej>
yael_: if you're talking about WebKit, you would want to special case this in the accessibility code

[19:45:02.0000] <othermaciej>
yael_: we have the ability to represent roles that don't map to an ARIA role

[19:46:00.0000] <yael_>
othermaciej: Do you have an example?

[19:47:00.0000] <othermaciej>
yael_: look at the AccessibilityRole enum in AccessibilityObject.h

[19:47:01.0000] <othermaciej>
yael_: you can add roles to that if you need to

[19:47:02.0000] <othermaciej>
but it's also worth checking what the mac AX APIs expect for an indeterminate progress bar

[19:48:00.0000] <yael_>
sounds good, thanks

[19:48:01.0000] <othermaciej>
yael_: Mac has only one role for progress indicators; you can see the reference for all roles here: http://developer.apple.com/mac/library/documentation/Cocoa/Reference/ApplicationKit/Protocols/NSAccessibility_Protocol/Reference/Reference.html#//apple_ref/doc/c_ref/

[19:49:00.0000] <othermaciej>
yael_: what you probably need is to expose the right attributes

[19:50:00.0000] <othermaciej>
yael_: you can see what a native progress bar exposes for role and attributes with Accessibility Verifier.app

[19:50:01.0000] <othermaciej>
yael_: for both determinate and indeterminate state

[19:50:02.0000] <othermaciej>
yael_: your goal at least in the Mac accessibility interface should be to replicate that

[00:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
sure it is

[00:29:01.0000] <Hixie>

[02:06:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[16:37:00.0000] <Philip`>

[16:37:01.0000] <Philip`>

[07:42:00.0000] <remysharp>
Regarding media elements - if I want to visualise the download progress of the playable timerange, should I be listening for the durationChanged event or the progress event? 

[07:43:00.0000] <zcorpan>
remysharp: progress

[07:44:00.0000] <remysharp>
I was using progress in a test, but (I think Firefox) wasn't firing all the way to the end of the media downloading

[07:44:01.0000] <zcorpan>
remysharp: durationchange is only fired when the duration changes, which will likely be just once very early

[07:44:02.0000] <remysharp>
i.e. I'd read the video.seekable.end() when progress fired, and it wouldn't be the completed length

[07:45:00.0000] <zcorpan>
remysharp: i think that's a bug then

[07:45:01.0000] <remysharp>
or should I have been using the video.duration prop on the progress event firing?

[07:46:00.0000] <zcorpan>
duration doesn't say how much has been downloaded

[07:46:01.0000] <remysharp>
no - sorry I should have been clear - it was to update a playhead scrubber

[07:46:02.0000] <zcorpan>
remysharp: "Once the entire media resource has been fetched (but potentially before any of it has been decoded)

[07:46:03.0000] <zcorpan>
Queue a task to fire a simple event named progress at the media element."

[07:46:04.0000] <remysharp>
i.e. what amount of the video can be played

[07:47:00.0000] <remysharp>
ah - so the video is decoded after that event

[07:47:01.0000] <zcorpan>
might be

[07:47:02.0000] <remysharp>
therefore the duration wouldn't potentially be calculated on the last progress event firing?

[07:48:00.0000] <remysharp>
but - I guess that said, if the meta data comes down first, I'd have the duration before the video can be played, right?

[07:48:01.0000] <zcorpan>
the duration can be known before having decoded any video, e.g. mozilla supports an http header to indicate duration

[07:48:02.0000] <remysharp>
okay

[07:48:03.0000] <zcorpan>
if you want to know which parts you can seek to, you probably want .seekable

[07:49:00.0000] <remysharp>
I've just checked my code example, and I'm listening for the durationChange *and* progress, but updating the scrubber based on the seekable.end() value

[07:49:01.0000] <zcorpan>
(it's durationchange btw with lowercase c)

[07:49:02.0000] <remysharp>
aye, but I want it to show how much has loaded as it's loading

[07:49:03.0000] <remysharp>
(lower c - ta)

[07:55:00.0000] <remysharp>
zcorpan: cheers for your help.

[15:27:01.0000] <Philip`>
Can you stop calling it a shiv, and call it something like a shim instead, since that would make much more sense?

[15:30:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Philip`, is it really that important?  http://ejohn.org/blog/html5-shiv/ http://remysharp.com/2009/01/07/html5-enabling-script/

[15:30:01.0000] <Hixie>
a shiv is a weapon

[15:30:02.0000] <Hixie>
a shim is a thin strip of material to make things align

[15:31:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
The term shiv originates from John Resig, the creator of jQuery, who used the word as a metaphor to describe shiving support for HTML5 elements into Internet Explorer via javascript, where shiving  is a slang term for a sharp object used as a knife-like weapon. There's also a chance that John had a moment of false etymology and meant to use the word shim, which in computing means an application compatibility workaround.

[15:31:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'm going with the second possibility, which makes much more sense.

[15:32:00.0000] <Hixie>
you could use the word ship, claiming that you are "providing a way to get there from here"

[15:32:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Well, I don't think I'll be offending any SHIV people by changing the wording to SHIM --- done!

[15:32:02.0000] <jgraham>
You could use the word "hack" instead and then spend lots of time explaining to your grandparents that NSA aren't after you

[15:33:00.0000] <Hixie>
or or "shin", and say that you are giving IE legs to stand on

[15:33:01.0000] <Philip`>
Replacing things like <video> and <canvas> with a <div> on printing seems like a terrible idea, because it won't do anything useful in IE8 and it'll completely break printing of the elements in IE9

[15:33:02.0000] <Hixie>
or "shia" and claim it to be a metaphor for forking standards...

[15:34:00.0000] <Philip`>
(Same for all the other elements that have special not-purely-CSS renderings, too)

[15:34:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Ooh, good point.  You need a cc targeting IE8 and earlier only.

[15:36:00.0000] <Philip`>
I think IE9 parses unknown elements in an XMLish way so you don't actually need to do anything there

[15:36:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
TabAtkins, I will do that.

[16:35:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
JonathanNeal: Does IE ignore media=print on stylesheets or something?

[16:36:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
What do you mean?

[16:37:00.0000] <nessy>
othermaciej: now sent the change proposals email for media a11y - let's see what happens

[16:37:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
You have the _exposePrint and _concealPrint functions, which just turn <style media=print> into <style media=screen old_media=print>, etc.

[16:44:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Well, that's because I replace html5 elements with div/span

[16:44:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
so exposePrint and consealPrint temporarily change the stylesheets so I can grab the correct styling.

[16:44:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Then it creates a custom stylesheet that styles the new div / span elements.

[16:45:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Oh, now I get it.  You're switching them to screen just so you can analyze the styles *while* it's in screen mode.

[16:45:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Yes.

[16:45:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Can you use CSSOM to do that more cleanly?  (Dunno what the level of support is in IE6+.

[16:45:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I've never heard of that.

[16:46:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Search for CSS Object Model.

[16:46:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Yea, I pulled up some spec from the w3 but I don't ... know how I would use it.

[16:47:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Grab the appropriate stylesheet, iterate through and read out the styles, producing a new stylesheet as you go along with your substitutions.

[16:47:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Rather than reading off the styles of individual elements, you'd change selectors that reference the current element names to use, I dunno, a unique class or something.

[16:48:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Ah!  That's a good idea.

[16:48:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/w3c_cssom.html will this page tell you whether IE6 supports it?

[16:48:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
While I understand what you're saying ... I haven't seen the syntax yet to do what you described.

[16:49:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
No, that's just for CSSOM View.

[16:52:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I am just failing at the right google result to see how to do this.

[16:53:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[16:54:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes, that's it.

2010-04-11
[00:40:00.0000] <estellevw>
There were five global attributes related to microdata including itemid, itemprop, itemref, itemscope and itemtype that i remember seeing, but don't see in the spec right now. Am I missing something?

[00:46:00.0000] <myakura>
estellevw: they got split off from the main HTML5 spec about a month (or two) ago.

[00:46:01.0000] <estellevw>
thanks

[00:47:00.0000] <estellevw>
is it likely to come back in?

[00:48:00.0000] <myakura>
I guess the WHATWG version of HTML5 still incorporates it.

[00:48:01.0000] <myakura>
for W3C version, see http://www.w3.org/TR/microdata/ . 

[00:49:00.0000] <estellevw>
yeah, looking at it

[00:49:01.0000] <estellevw>
i think it needs some editing. The attributes are in the body but not in the table of contents

[00:51:00.0000] <estellevw>
http://www.w3.org/TR/microdata/#attr-itemref and the like have lost their original stature.

[00:52:00.0000] <estellevw>
it states The following attributes are added as global attributes to HTML elements:

[00:52:01.0000] <estellevw>
    * itemid

[00:52:02.0000] <estellevw>
    * itemprop

[00:52:03.0000] <estellevw>
    * itemref

[00:52:04.0000] <estellevw>
    * itemscope

[00:52:05.0000] <estellevw>
    * itemtype

[00:52:06.0000] <estellevw>
oops, sorry

[00:52:07.0000] <estellevw>
but if i recall correctly, those aren't listed in teh global attributes anymore

[00:53:00.0000] <estellevw>
the global attributes being here: http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/dom.html#global-attributes

[00:56:00.0000] <myakura>
because they are two separete specs; Microdata is build on top of HTML5 so those item* attributes cannot be defined in HTML5.

[00:59:00.0000] <estellevw>
ok, makes sense as to why role, and the aria-* attributes aren't listed as global even though they are too

[00:59:01.0000] <estellevw>
thanks

[00:59:02.0000] <myakura>
yeah..

[01:00:00.0000] <myakura>
just refer to the WHATWG version and you won't get confused :)

[01:00:01.0000] <myakura>

[04:29:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
in regard to http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/text-level-semantics.html#guidance-for-conformance-checkers

[04:42:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
writing code for a conformance checker to check "The img element is part of the only paragraph directly in its section" or even "only non-whitespace content in the only paragraph directly in its section" is not easy

[04:45:00.0000] <annevk>
prolly also depends on how you implement things

[04:46:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
well, it's not practical at all to implement using a grammar-based schema, so we forget about that completely

[04:48:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
and it's quite complicated to implement in the Java code that validator.nu currently uses for things that can't be checked practically using grammar-based checking

[04:50:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
as far as I can see, it will require adding code that is very unlike existing code for any other checking that is being done by validator.nu

[04:58:00.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: I think that particular exception is not very well justified in the first place

[04:58:01.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: but yeah, to check an "only paragraph in its section" condition would require running the HTML5 outline algorithm I think

[04:59:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
It would be help to have the spec provide the intended rationale for that exception

[05:00:00.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: Hixie explained it a bit in the specific bug Laura filed about it

[05:00:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
ok

[05:00:02.0000] <othermaciej>
let me see if I can find it

[05:01:00.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9217

[05:02:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I see

[05:02:01.0000] <othermaciej>
MikeSmith: I would personally think it was fine to say "just use figure"

[05:02:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
well, I think we could all live without that particular exception

[05:02:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah, what you said

[05:03:00.0000] <othermaciej>
because associating the relevant section header with the image is much more complicated

[05:03:01.0000] <othermaciej>
as much as you don't want to implement it in the validator, I *really* don't want to implement the outline algorithm solely for our accessibility code to handle this case

[05:04:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[10:33:00.0000] <micheil>

[10:34:00.0000] <jgraham>
With the proviso I am not an expert on that spec, yes

[10:34:01.0000] <micheil>
okay

[10:34:02.0000] <jgraham>
The server can do whatever it wants based on anything the client sends including the path part

[10:35:00.0000] <jgraham>

[10:36:00.0000] <micheil>
yeah, I'm just trying to work out how to direct data about by using that, all the reference implementations I can find don't indicate anything on that

[10:38:00.0000] <jgraham>
Well when the server recieves the client handshake it parses out the path so you can arrange for it to be passed to the app

[10:38:01.0000] <jgraham>
Not sure what existing implementations do though

[10:39:00.0000] <micheil>
yeah, just trying to think if it's possible to send data to a specific connection or not

[10:39:01.0000] <micheil>
(ie, rather then just being a broadcast type service)

[10:40:00.0000] <micheil>

[10:41:00.0000] <jgraham>
If I follow you, that sounds right

[10:42:00.0000] <jgraham>
From the point of view of the server each client is a seperate connection so you can read and write to each client independently

[10:43:00.0000] <micheil>
hopefully

[10:43:01.0000] <jgraham>
I don't really see how it could work otherwise

[14:23:00.0000] <annevk>
http://adactio.com/journal/1654/ -- I still think we should drop <article> and get <content>

[14:24:00.0000] <annevk>
though maybe just dropping <article> for now and see what patterns emerge

[14:40:00.0000] <Hixie>
annevk: i don't understand why people are so confused by them... they're completely differnet

[14:40:01.0000] <Hixie>
one is for chapters and the other is for syndicatable content

[14:40:02.0000] <Hixie>
they're different use cases with almost no overlap

[14:42:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Hixie: The confusion seems to be with the descriptions, maybe it's just a matter of condensing it down to a better explanation

[14:47:00.0000] <Hixie>
the descriptions are completely different

[14:47:01.0000] <Hixie>
i think the problem is that the element names aren't intuitive based on the descriptions

[14:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
but that's not a big problem, people will learn the difference in due course

[14:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's like <dl>, <ul>, and <ol>. Given just those element names and then descriptions of what they're for, how would you guess which was which?

[14:50:00.0000] <annevk>
hmm, would've been good to test that out

[14:51:00.0000] <othermaciej>
<article> and <section> as names sound very distinct

[14:51:01.0000] <othermaciej>
maybe the problem is with the descriptions

[14:54:00.0000] <othermaciej>
"The section element represents a generic document or application section." --> ""The section element represents a generic section of a document or application"

[14:54:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I bet that by itself would reduce confusion

[14:54:02.0000] <othermaciej>
if you skim fast, the current text looks like "The ____ element represents a document"

[14:55:00.0000] <othermaciej>
"The article element represents a component of a page that consists of a self-contained composition in a document, page, application, or site and that is intended to be independently distributable or reusable, e.g. in syndication."

[14:55:01.0000] <othermaciej>
and that one reads as "The ____ element represents a component" if you skim

[14:56:00.0000] <othermaciej>
could be something like "The article element represents a self-contained composition in a document, page, application, or site that is intended to be independently distributable or reusable, e.g. in syndication."

[14:56:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: ^

[14:56:02.0000] <othermaciej>
(annevk also)

[20:29:01.0000] <KaOSoFt>
boblet- Why should content be first than navigation? Sorry, I'm kind of new to this Web development topic.

[20:30:00.0000] <boblet>
KaOSoFt: the idea is that for content pages (ie not the homepage or the archives etc) the user generally wants to get to the content. For text-to-speech reading through the navigation and other stuff in the header takes time (visual equivalent is Flash loading animation)

[20:31:00.0000] <boblet>
KaOSoFt: hence skip to content links and putting nav after content in HTML (which as mentioned is generally a massive pita)

[20:32:00.0000] <KaOSoFt>
boblet- Hmmm, "content pages". I get it. Thanks. :)

[20:32:01.0000] <boblet>
KaOSoFt: happy to help :)

[00:01:03.0000] <Hixie>

[00:01:04.0000] <Hixie>
er

[00:01:05.0000] <Hixie>

[00:03:00.0000] <Hixie>

[00:03:01.0000] <micheil>
so far most I've seen don't even parse the headers correctly

[00:03:02.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[00:03:03.0000] <micheil>
because, theoretically there aren't any headers not allowed

[00:04:00.0000] <micheil>
plus, they use a fixed order for them, which isn't correct

[00:04:01.0000] <Hixie>
that's why the latest draft requires the servers to parse two headers, because otherwise the servers wouldn't parse any and would be vulnerable to a cross-protocol attack from HTTP

[00:04:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: I see, thanks (about aria-labelledby)

[00:05:00.0000] <micheil>

[00:05:01.0000] <Hixie>
the two Sec-WebSocket-Key headers

[00:05:02.0000] <Hixie>
MikeSmith: as a general rule, ARIA is a layer above HTML, so it should be possible to take any HTML file with ARIA, remove all the ARIA, and not make the page less conforming

[00:05:03.0000] <micheil>
oh, I thought they were part of the first GET request

[00:06:00.0000] <Hixie>
micheil: they are

[00:06:01.0000] <Hixie>
micheil: by "header" i meant "field" in websocket terminology, my bad

[00:07:00.0000] <micheil>

[05:27:03.0000] <jgraham>

[05:28:00.0000] <micheil>

[05:28:01.0000] <jgraham>

[05:29:00.0000] <micheil>
I know that the headers in a websocket client are going to be in the format: GET {path} HTTP/1.1\r\n{headers}\r\n\r\n{body}\r\n\r\n

[05:29:01.0000] <micheil>
or something like that

[05:29:02.0000] <jgraham>
micheil: Right but from the point of view of websockets it means we should be wary of security features that might fail due to likely bugs in servers

[05:29:03.0000] <jgraham>
(i.e. I agree with zcorpan about the location of the spaces)

[05:29:04.0000] <micheil>
and then the headers are going to be separated as {key}: {value}\r\n

[05:30:00.0000] <micheil>
and according to the spec for websockets, you should be fine, however, I wouldn't think of sticking websockets and a httpserver on the same network process

[05:30:01.0000] <micheil>
(ie, reading from the same stream of data)

[05:31:00.0000] <jgraham>
Me neither but some people seem to want that

[05:31:01.0000] <jgraham>
Or something

[05:31:02.0000] <micheil>
you do two processes

[05:31:03.0000] <micheil>
different ports

[05:32:00.0000] <micheil>
eg, your webserver on *.host.tld:80, and then your websockets on say, ws.host.tld:80

[05:32:01.0000] <micheil>
or just host:80 for http, host:8080 for websockets

[05:33:00.0000] <micheil>
nothing actually stops the two network sockets from talking to each other, depending on how you architect your app, take PusherApp.com for example, they have a rails app somehow pushing data onto a websocket server

[05:33:01.0000] <annevk>

[17:12:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The tools necessary to innovate in UI development already exist - use javascript and CSS, plus some accessibility help like ARIA.

[17:13:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Then, *after* we've established that something new is wanted by a lot of people, we can add it to the language.

[17:13:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Trying to guess what requirements people will have for new innovations is doomed to failure, and will just result in a lot of useless bloat in the spec that will end up getting in people's way more than it helps them.

[13:13:00.0000] <micheil>
okay, well, with websockets, and sending the body on the request without a Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding seems to go against RFC2068

[13:13:01.0000] <micheil>
"The presence of a message-body in a request is signaled by the inclusion of a Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding header field in the request's message-headers"

[13:14:00.0000] <jgraham>
So the hypothetical architecture is one where the HTTP server handles the entire request including the random bytes and then passes it off to a websockets handler

[13:15:00.0000] <micheil>
yeah, sorta

[13:15:01.0000] <jgraham>

[13:15:02.0000] <jgraham>
I mean at some point you have to hand over to WS-specific code

[13:16:00.0000] <micheil>
no. because the body is separated from the headers with \r\n\r\n

[13:21:00.0000] <jgraham>
So you only have a problem if the HTTP layer reads the headers, notices it is a websocket client, hands over to the websocket server, but also reads the body (even though the headers don't say there is a body) and doesn't make that avaliable to the WS server

[13:22:00.0000] <jgraham>
It's not clear to me why that would happen

[13:22:01.0000] <jgraham>
(it seems you could get into trouble with either design)

[13:24:00.0000] <micheil>

[13:24:01.0000] <micheil>

[16:02:00.0000] <Philip`>
In a process where there's no penalty for making bad arguments, and you believe a proposal should be accepted, it seems only rational to provide as many arguments as you can think of regardless of their quality because maybe somebody will accidentally believe some of them

[16:03:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah, that's pretty much the problem here

[16:05:00.0000] <Dashiva>
 <Philip`> In a process where there's no penalty for making bad arguments, and you believe a proposal should be accepted, it seems only rational to provide as many arguments as you can think of regardless of their quality because maybe somebody will accidentally believe some of them

[16:05:01.0000] <Dashiva>
For you, othermaciej :)

[16:05:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Which unfortunately creates more work for everyone, as there's more crap to wade through, and then you still have to debunk the crap arguments.

[16:05:03.0000] <othermaciej>
Dashiva: pardon?

[16:05:04.0000] <Philip`>
(Of course a process that penalises good arguments because of nearby bad arguments would be irrational, because things should be decided based on the merits of good arguments)

[16:05:05.0000] <Philip`>
(so there's no good solution)

[16:08:00.0000] <Dashiva>
othermaciej: Talking about how there's no reason to not make bogus arguments to bog down "the others"

[16:09:00.0000] <othermaciej>
the only penalty for bad arguments is that readers may pay less heed to your good arguments

[16:10:00.0000] <Dashiva>
They don't have a choice with change proposals involved

[16:10:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
othermaciej: That's not a real penalty, as your bad arguments will still generate work for others.

[16:10:02.0000] <Dashiva>
You must address everything to be sure bad stuff doesn't happen

[16:11:00.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: the chairs have rejected Change Proposals before for lacking rationale

[16:11:01.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: but we're reluctant to do a really deep analysis

[16:12:00.0000] <Dashiva>
If you create a proposal with one real argument and ten bogus arguments, that's a lot of extra work for counter-proposals

[16:12:01.0000] <othermaciej>
we'll only reject if the rationale is completely missing, or just transparently inadequate (e.g. tautological or does not actually cover all changes in the proposal)

[16:12:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
othermaciej: That's not stopping bad arguments from dominating a change proposal.  A single good argument in rationale is enough to carry a bunch of bad arguments, all of which have to be addressed.  ;_;

[16:12:03.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: well, a counter-proposal doesn't necessarly have to address every single argument from any Change Proposal it is opposed to

[16:13:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
And since the CP accept/reject mechanism is completely opaque, we have no idea how important it is to address any particular argument.

[16:13:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it just has to make the case that the status quo is better than the change

[16:13:02.0000] <othermaciej>
the chairs would likely mention if it seems like there are points worth addressing that haven't been

[16:14:00.0000] <othermaciej>
anyway, I get a sense that you are somewhat dissatisfied, but I'm not sure if you have a specific proposal for what the chairs might do differently

[16:14:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Not right now, no.

[16:14:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Perhaps allow striking of obviously invalid arguments

[16:16:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Something along that line might work.  The essential problem is that, since the accept/reject process is a single opaque step at the end, there's no way to know *where* to apply energy.

[16:17:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Feedback as things move along would at least allow CP authors to know which arguments to strengthen, and counter authors to know which ones don't need to be addressed.

[16:18:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Not sure precisely how to address or obtain "more feedback", but I feel it's the basic weakness in the Issue process.

2010-04-14
[17:02:00.0000] <Hixie>
what do people think of making <s> valid again, with a semantic something like "indicates that the contents are no longer accurate or no longer relevant" or some such?

[17:04:00.0000] <Dashiva>
To avoid diluting the semantics of <del>?

[17:04:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[17:04:02.0000] <Hixie>
(see http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9429 if you have any especially strong opinions one way or the other)

[17:06:00.0000] <annevk>
not opposed

[17:06:01.0000] <daedb>
Sounds fine to me, but I don't care strongly about it :p

[17:08:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I'm not opposed, but it sounds like a semantic fig leaf

[17:16:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: <s> is strikethrough? 

[17:16:01.0000] <othermaciej>
what's the difference between <s> and <strike> if any?

[17:16:02.0000] <othermaciej>
(change sounds good to me btw)

[17:17:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
othermaciej: No difference.  They appear to be the same element?

[17:17:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I wonder why both exist

[17:18:00.0000] <othermaciej>
HTML4 had both

[17:18:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Presumably because HTML doesn't make any sense.

[17:21:00.0000] <annevk>
I guess Netscape had <s> and Microsoft had <strike> or vice versa

[17:21:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Dashiva: Why do you think so?  There is a consistent semantic implied by the use of strike-through in text.

[17:22:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
It's sort of like <b> taking on the role of "everything that is bold for some important reason, but isn't otherwise covered by another element".

[17:22:01.0000] <othermaciej>
the <b> definition is also a semantic fig leaf

[17:22:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Well, what are the major semantic use cases for <s> that aren't covered by <del>?

[17:23:00.0000] <othermaciej>
<del> implies an edit or edit instruction

[17:23:01.0000] <othermaciej>
strikethrough in blogs is typically for uses of either "I made a mistake but am being transparent about correcting it" or an ironic fake version of that

[17:24:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it seems a little different to me than marking up document edits with <ins>/<del>

[17:24:01.0000] <othermaciej>
like the point of using strikethrough in that context is to *not* delete the stricken text, but rather let it stand and signal that it is no longer operative

[17:25:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Actually, I think the first use-case *is* covered well by <del>.  They're editting the document.  If they were feeling really fancy, they could cite the comment from the pedant that pointed it out.

[17:25:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
But the ironic fake version probably is abusing <del>.

[17:25:02.0000] <Dashiva>
So if I'm making ironic emphasis in a quote, I shouldn't use <strong> or <em> either?

[17:25:03.0000] <othermaciej>
But they are not saying that text has been deleted or should be - rather they are flagging it as false

[17:25:04.0000] <othermaciej>
or mistaken or unintended

[17:26:00.0000] <othermaciej>
but explicitly letting it stand for the record

[17:27:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Basically, the ironically-stricken text shouldn't be interpreted as ordinary text (that is, it shouldn't be just a <span style>), but it shouldn't be skipped over as a deletion either (and so shouldn't be a <del>).

[17:27:01.0000] <Dashiva>
(Like Tab says, transparent correction is very much ins/del, otherwise you'd just do the edit directly)

[17:28:00.0000] <othermaciej>
maybe I do not grok the deep semantics of <del>

[17:28:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I am not entirely sure what it is supposed to be for

[17:28:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I imagine if I marked up someone else's document to propose changes, I would use <ins> and <del>

[17:28:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah, that's right.

[17:28:04.0000] <othermaciej>
to me that seems different from transparent correction

[17:28:05.0000] <othermaciej>
where I am consciously *not* editing the text

[17:28:06.0000] <othermaciej>
and using strikethrough as an alternative

[17:29:00.0000] <Dashiva>
What is a correction if not editing the text?

[17:29:01.0000] <othermaciej>
well, newspaper corrections are generally an external annotation

[17:29:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
But you are!  In most cases I've seen strikethrough used as a transparent correction, the text could be read while completely ignoring the stricken text, and be correct.

[17:29:03.0000] <othermaciej>
the Web lets you do more of it inline

[17:30:00.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: I often see a strikethrough followed by a parenthetical remark explaining the correction, which would not read right if you skipped it entirely

[17:30:01.0000] <Dashiva>
The only problem with the ironic deletion seems to be that it shouldn't be collapsed

[17:30:02.0000] <othermaciej>
anyway, I am not the right person for this discussion

[17:30:03.0000] <othermaciej>
because I don't really care if elements are semantic or presentational, as long as they are useful

[17:30:04.0000] <Dashiva>
<del permanent-marker>

[17:31:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Is that somehow better than <s>?

[17:32:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Personally I'd be fine with <del> meaning "something removed from the text" without also implying "something that can be removed from the markup"

[17:32:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That might be the most pragmatic solution.

[17:33:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Hixie, presumably you had a reason why you think that that wouldn't be sufficient?

[17:33:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[17:34:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Haha.

[17:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[17:34:02.0000] <othermaciej>
not the way strikethrough implies some form of deletion or removal

[17:35:00.0000] <othermaciej>
also people rarely feel the need to mark up inline correction additions in any way

[17:35:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[17:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think Hixie's proposed definition of <s> for strikethrough of falsity/irrelevance/inoperativeness captures the distinction between transparent corrections and <del> as text that is/should be deleted

[17:36:01.0000] <Hixie>

[11:59:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Why do Firefox and Chrome both render this with the <th> not centered?  data:text/html,<!doctype html><table style="text-align:left"><tr><th>Foo</th></tr><td>Barzabel</td></table>

[12:00:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
There should be a UA rule like th { text-align: center }, but there's not.  Instead, <th> contents seem to be centered by magic.

[12:00:01.0000] <zcorpan>
hmm, who was it that took my placeholder.js script and improved it a few days ago?

[12:01:00.0000] <zcorpan>
oh here it is http://fsfe.org/scripts/placeholder.js

[12:01:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, I guess I mean: data:text/html,<!doctype html><table style="text-align:left"><tr><th>Foo<tr><td>Barzabel</table>

[12:01:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Should produce the same DOM, anyway.

[12:01:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Opera too.

[12:01:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Only IE8 seems to work as expected.

[12:02:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
HTML5 specifies that <th> should have text-align:center, not magic.

[12:02:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
So it'll presumably move over in time.

[12:03:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So does CSS 2.1.

[12:18:00.0000] <othermaciej>
WebKit has magic

[12:18:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it converts text-align: auto to text-align: center at style resolution time

[12:19:00.0000] <othermaciej>
for th elements

[12:19:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=37590

[12:19:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Is this necessary for compat?

[12:19:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I am not sure if it's possible to do all the weird legacy compat stuff with an explicit text-align: center rule in place

[12:20:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
What weird legacy compat stuff needs to be done?  Are th's sometimes magically not centered?

[12:20:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Does this need to be specced somewhere?

[12:21:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'm curious too.  If you're referring to some of the aligning attributes or whatnot, those are on the author level, and thus override UA-level rules.

[12:51:00.0000] <othermaciej>
AryehGregor: I don't know if our behavior is necessary

[12:51:01.0000] <othermaciej>
AryehGregor: is the behavior cited in the bug above divergent from other browsers?

[12:51:02.0000] <othermaciej>
very specifically what we do is that for th, text-align: auto is interpreted as text-align: center at style resolution time

[12:51:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
othermaciej, I covered that in the bug.  Other browsers do the same, except IE8.

[12:52:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(instead of being equivalent to left as for most elements)

[12:52:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I suspect the bug could be fixed by making th have an explicit text-align: auto property in the UA stylesheet

[12:52:02.0000] <othermaciej>
but I don't know if this would break anything else

[12:52:03.0000] <zcorpan>

[14:09:00.0000] <estellevw>
hi. There's a small discussion going on about section versus article in my blog, and i would love to get some feedback (either here or within the comments section) as to what is right.  My understanding of the spec is that sections can be nested in articles, and articles can be nested in sections.  Am i wrong? http://www.standardista.com/html5-section-v-article/

[14:09:01.0000] <Dashiva>
That's right

[14:11:00.0000] <Dashiva>
It might possibly be easier to think "articles (which have sections) can contain articles" instead of "sections can contain articles"

[14:11:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Hey, everybody!

[14:12:00.0000] <paul_irish>
so in general, Dashiva, you expect sections will be contained by an article?

[14:14:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Whoa whoa whoa, are we saying that articles and sections are no longer mutually exclusive?

[14:15:00.0000] <paul_irish>
(i'm not asking for rules, just what we expect common use will be)

[14:16:00.0000] <Dashiva>
paul_irish: No

[14:17:00.0000] <Dashiva>
But you can consider the a sufficiently important child of the <body> element a pseudo-article

[14:21:00.0000] <estellevw>
i do think of it as.... if its datable, it's an article

[14:21:01.0000] <estellevw>
so, you can have articles.... dated items ... a group of them, in a section

[14:21:02.0000] <estellevw>
and you can have a bunch of sections in a very long article

[14:22:00.0000] <estellevw>
i don't see off the top of my head a use case for article within article, but i do section in section

[14:22:01.0000] <estellevw>
doesn't mean there isn't a use case for articles within articles

[14:22:02.0000] <estellevw>
i just can't come up with one

[14:23:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Newspaper letters to the editor

[14:23:01.0000] <Dashiva>
The page itself is one article, but each letter can also be an article

[14:24:00.0000] <estellevw>
ah, good one

[14:24:01.0000] <estellevw>
thank you

[14:30:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
