[14:57:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
estellevw's explanation is probably one of the best.

[14:59:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Newspaper letters to the editor, I was wondering if those are sections vs articles, much like a comment section might be a section.  However, in the comment section one could say that is definitely datable.

[15:01:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
If I knew how to submit stuff to gsnedders's tool, I would suggest the outline allows marking which type of element is in use (it might make people feel better about those untitled navs and asides)

[15:01:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I would suggest == I would write and submit for review

[15:03:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
What is the recommended element for comments on a blog post?

[15:03:01.0000] <estellevw>
the comments is a section, and each comment is dates do article

[15:04:00.0000] <estellevw>
do = so

[15:04:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
And would that section belong to the article that is the blog post?

[15:04:02.0000] <estellevw>
yes

[15:04:03.0000] <estellevw>
at least, that's my take on it

[15:04:04.0000] <TabAtkins__>
/me came in late, but agrees with what estellevw is saying.

[15:05:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
<article>... blog post heading and content <section>... blog post comment heading and <article ... various comments /></section></article>

[15:05:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
where various comments represents multiple articles.

[15:06:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I agree too, just mulling the concept over.

[15:08:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
In a traditional newspaper, each article references the date of the entire paper (usually at the top).  Wonder if there would be a geeky semantic way to write in that reference.  I would totally make a fake newspaper as HTML5 sample.

[15:24:00.0000] <TabAtkins__>
JonathanNeal: Nope, you'd have to include the <time pubdate> in every <article>.

[15:24:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
No referencing?  Not even with microdata?

[15:31:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
If you have a metadata vocabulary appropriate to the task, then of course you can reference it.  But that has nothing to do with the implied connection between an <article> and a <time pubdate> that HTML5 defines.

[15:32:00.0000] <estellevw>
hhmmm, so a nested article doesn't inherit the pubdate of the parent article.

[15:33:00.0000] <estellevw>
makes sesne

[15:33:01.0000] <estellevw>
if instead of thinking of a daily newspaper, think of a monthly mag maybe

[15:33:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Or just think of blog posts - the pubdate on the post has nothing to do with the pubdate on the comments.

[15:33:03.0000] <estellevw>
the magazine may come out on april 1, but the letters to the editor each have their own dates

[15:34:00.0000] <estellevw>
exactly

[15:34:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
All of that would work even if it inherited the date.

[15:34:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
If you do not specify the date, it could be implied from an ancestor.

[15:36:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Well, right now you can't, but in theory what issue would you take with that?

[15:38:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The fact that it would be inaccurate?

[15:38:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Especially in the common case, that of blog comments?

[15:44:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
wouldn't the blog comments specify the date?

[15:44:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Otherwise, they're just as omitted in either case.

[15:44:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Possibly.  If they do, they're covered.  But if they don't, your suggestion would imply that they have the same pubdate as the article they're attached to.

[15:46:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
You'd rather they had nothing than possibly something.  That's fair, you can have them work strict in that sense.

[15:48:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
It would be my preference that inheritance is an option.  I may be alone.

[15:49:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
What's wrong with just specifying <time pubdate> in the descendant articles?

[15:51:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
It's easier to not do something than to do something.  I think it could be less strict.  I think there's wiggle room.  To compare, we've been talking about comments as articles, then comments aren't exactly independantly distributable content.

[15:52:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
\s\

[15:52:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
then\but

[15:52:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
They're independent chunks of content that can receive their own title and publication date, and are reasonable to link to and look at individually.

[15:52:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's close enough to make <article> a great match, I think.

[15:53:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Do individual comments commonly receive titles?

[15:54:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I don't see it universally, but it's reasonable common.  Techdirt, for example, has titles on their comments.

[16:00:00.0000] <estellevw>
It does happen, but it's not the norm (yet).

[16:01:00.0000] <estellevw>
would most table of contents, though, list each comment individually, or just have the header "comments" in the TOC?

[16:01:01.0000] <estellevw>
it really depends on the blog i would think

[16:01:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Probably the latter.

[16:02:00.0000] <estellevw>

[16:02:01.0000] <estellevw>

[16:02:02.0000] <estellevw>

[16:02:03.0000] <estellevw>

[16:02:04.0000] <estellevw>

[15:06:00.0000] <Hixie>

[15:08:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[15:09:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[15:17:00.0000] <hober>
Hixie: here

[15:24:00.0000] <Hixie>
hober: i replied to your mail

[15:24:01.0000] <Hixie>
TabAtkins: he keeps asking me to "test to see what happens when the IDs change" despite the fact that I'm not disagreeing with him on what happens if hte IDs change

[15:28:00.0000] <hober>
I think all Sam's trying to say with that is "feeds with shitty entry IDs and/or updated datetimes suck." Which, obviously, everyone knows so I don't know why he's banging on about that bit

[15:37:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
He's banging on about it because the HTML5 Atome extraction algo will, I think, generate shitty entry IDs (or no entry IDs?  Similar problems exist.).

[15:40:00.0000] <othermaciej>
HTML5 doesn't require you to preserve the entry ID if you generate the feed multiple times

[15:41:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(or rather, it is a SHOULD rather than a MUST)

[15:41:01.0000] <othermaciej>
but it's not clear how much of that requirement is needed to avoid aggregators breaking

[15:41:02.0000] <Hixie>
we could change it to "MUST if possible" i guess

[15:41:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah, I see it now.

[15:41:04.0000] <othermaciej>
I suspect just requiring that the identical document sent through the same converter to generate identical atom:ids is both feasible and would mostly solve that particular problem

[15:41:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
Nod to othermaciej.

[15:42:00.0000] <othermaciej>
"MUST if possible" means "SHOULD"!

[15:42:01.0000] <Hixie>
i know

[15:42:02.0000] <Hixie>
that's why i wrote SHOULD

[15:42:03.0000] <Hixie>
but apparently that's not good enough for julian and sam

[15:42:04.0000] <hober>
Hixie: use "OUGHT TO" ( ref: http://edward.oconnor.cx/2006/02/more-rfc-2119-humor ) 

[15:42:05.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't really understand the scope of the Atom spec's MUST

[15:42:06.0000] <TabAtkins>
It seems pretty easy to figure out how to generate a guurl from the article address and content.

[15:42:07.0000] <othermaciej>
when Julian has explained what he thinks it does and doesn't require, it sounds like he's making stuff up to suit his preferences rather than interpreting the Atom spec

[15:42:08.0000] <TabAtkins>
It is somewhat more difficult to generate one if the article changes between runs.

[15:43:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Which I think they raised as a problem with it.

[15:43:01.0000] <othermaciej>
yeah, the only truly sound way to deal with "article changes between runs" is to require the HTML document to have unique IDs embedded

[15:43:02.0000] <hober>
othermaciej: FWIW, I thought your point re: "why the double standard between text->atom and html->atom" was spot-on

[15:44:00.0000] <othermaciej>
hober: I still don't feel like he gave a straight answer

[15:44:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
othermaciej: Right.  So I think I'm fine with that.  Changing the SHOULD to a MUST would still allow the ids to be different if the content changes between runs (it wont' be the "same input").

[15:44:02.0000] <othermaciej>
but I also don't understand the double standard between "two runs of same converter" and "runs of different converters"

[15:45:00.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: it's not clear to me if Julian or Sam would be fine with that, or whether they would see that as violating the Atom spec (a possibly separate question)

[15:45:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
othermaciej: That one, at least, is similar to the distinction between "run on the same input" versus "run on similar input".

[15:45:02.0000] <othermaciej>
the problem is that the Atom requirement just doesn't make sense when starting from non-Atom input

[15:45:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Right.

[15:45:04.0000] <othermaciej>
it's totally plausible to apply to systems that are already operating in Atom

[15:45:05.0000] <hober>
exactly

[15:45:06.0000] <TabAtkins>
Unless the content happens to also embed an appropriate guid.

[15:45:07.0000] <othermaciej>
but it's unimplementable if your input doesn't already have globally unique IDs embedded

[15:46:00.0000] <Hixie>
yup

[15:46:01.0000] <Hixie>
that's exactly the line of thought i went through when i wrote this stuff

[15:46:02.0000] <Hixie>
hence the should

[15:46:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
So, yeah, bug in the Atom spec.  Change our spec to a MUST, and possibly explicitly call out the failing.

[15:46:04.0000] <othermaciej>
it *is* implementable for the special case of "same converter and identical content"

[15:47:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
It won't be a violation of our MUST if UAs generate new ids for altered content.

[15:47:01.0000] <Hixie>
one thing that's worth considering is whether we are interested in having a solution that outputs almost-valid atom that can be hand fixed to valid atom, or if we think the output must be valid atom

[15:48:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The latter.  Not much point in an automatic extraction algorithm if you still have to hand-edit the result.

[15:48:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Since the producer won't be the one doing the extracting, the consumer will.

[15:50:00.0000] <hober>
Hixie: my first choice is that the algorithm do what it's doing now. html -> atom tools can (and should) help their users improve their HTML so that the results are valid

[15:50:01.0000] <hober>
my second choice, if the output must be valid Atom, is to drop entries that we can't come up with IDs from. that way the entries that do end up in the feed don't annoy the crap out of subscribers

[15:51:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
hober: For your first choice, does that resolve to the former or latter option in hixie's question?

[15:51:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
It sounds like the latter, unless you're seriously suggesting that feed readers should ask their users to correct the HTML of feed producers.

[15:51:02.0000] <hober>
TabAtkins: the former, though I wouldn't suggest that people hand-edit the atom

[15:52:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Who is supposed to edit the Atom, then?  At what point in the chain does it go from almost-valid to valid?

[15:52:01.0000] <hober>
I don't expect anybody to edit the Atom.

[15:53:00.0000] <hober>
I've got a site, and I decide to use an html2atom tool to make a feed from it

[15:53:01.0000] <hober>
I go to the tool, paste in my URL, and the result page is something like

[15:53:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Then it never becomes valid, and you *can't* be agreeing with Hixie's former option.

[15:53:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
(Because that option, be definition, requires someone to edit the Atom at some point to make it valid.)

[15:53:04.0000] <hober>
"here's a url to an atom feed for your page. it doesn't look like it's valid; here are some ways you could improve your site so that your feed is more useful. have a nice day"

[15:54:00.0000] <hober>
or "here's a url... it's valid, congrats! here's a pat on the head"

[15:54:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's not the same use-case as "consume an HTML page as Atom".  That's an HTML->Atom validator.

[15:55:00.0000] <hober>
no, it's a converter, that's providing lint-tool-esque advice when used

[15:55:01.0000] <hober>
the feed consumers just get the url to the (possibly invalid) atom feed

[15:55:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
It's allowed to flag things that aren't right.  An actual conversion algo, though, either needs to output something valid, or we need to define exactly who turns it valid.

[15:55:03.0000] <hober>
it's the person feeding the site itno the converter that sees the lint/validation advice

[15:56:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Okay, such a tool could work equally by only producing a valid feed, but also flagging things that it's skipped for invalidity.

[15:56:01.0000] <hober>
sure

[15:56:02.0000] <hober>
hence my compromise proposal to julian

[15:56:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Then let's make sure that the algo just produces a valid feed.

[15:57:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
And let the market help people make their feeds better.

[15:57:01.0000] <hober>
sounds good to me

[16:12:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
For any folks working on Microdata in here, it would be nice if I could put itemprop="fn org logo" on an <img /> with an alt.

[16:13:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Hixie: ^^^ There really should be a way to get @alt in the property value.  Automatically, preferably.

[16:14:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
JonathanNeal: You wouldn't be able to put it on the <img> directly, anyway - that just grabs the @src instead.  But you *should* be able to put in on a <span> or <h1> or whatnot wrapping the <img>.

[16:14:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Yea that works too :)

[16:15:00.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: seems lame to add a span just to emit another property

[16:15:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I think in microformats you can place it on the <img /> itself.

[16:15:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
othermaciej: Shrug.  Grabbing the @src of an <img> is useful.

[16:15:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>
/me pokes you for keeping up with the Jones'.

[16:16:00.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: I agree - and as just mentioned, grabbing the alt is also useful

[16:16:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
And so it should continue to be easy to do so.  Using a wrapper is the obvious way to grab the alt without interfering with that.

[16:16:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I think it would be a design flaw if you had to add a superfluous DOM element just to emit both

[16:16:03.0000] <othermaciej>
although I do not have another design to propose

[16:16:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
You have to add wrappers for a lot of things in Microdata, if your data is part of prose.

[16:17:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Though, with JonathanNeal's use-case, the <img> will commonly already have a wrapper <h1> to use.

[16:18:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
You either have to add wrapper, or add another level of indirection to specify where the property value comes from.  The former seems a lot better to me, in this context.\

[16:18:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
(If you asked me the same question in a CSS context, I'd say the opposite, because we love indirection.)

[16:23:00.0000] <othermaciej>
CSS WG must have a bunch of computer scientists in it

[16:23:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes.

[16:25:00.0000] <Hixie>
when designing microdata i thought long and hard about how to get <img> to output one property for src="" and one for alt="" and i ended up deciding that was the mistake RDFa had made

[16:25:01.0000] <Hixie>
well, one of several, i guess

[16:27:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah, I don't think it should do it magically.  But I think that <span itemprop=foo><img itemprop=bar src=baz alt=qux></span> should output foo:"qux", bar:"baz".

[16:27:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Agreed that trying to stack the two together is a mistake in RDFa.

[16:28:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Essentially just, whenever a property is using the text content of an element for its value, <img> should substitute in its @alt value.  That's the whole point of @alt, after all - to be a textual equivalent of the image.

[16:31:00.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: in current Microdata, what would <span itemprop=foo><img src=baz alt=qux></span> emit?

[16:31:01.0000] <othermaciej>
(note lack of itemprop on the img itself)

[16:32:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
foo:""

[16:33:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Because @alt isn't part of the element's textContent.

[16:34:00.0000] <othermaciej>
would you propose changing what the markup I cited emits, or only in the case where the img element has an itemprop?

[16:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>
and what if there is more than just the <img> element inside the span?

[16:35:00.0000] <othermaciej>
additional side note: is there a way to get the contents of a "title" attribute into a Microdata property?

[16:35:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I would propose changing what the markup you cited emits.  It should emit foo:"qux".

[16:35:02.0000] <othermaciej>
those are the two cases I can think of where useful text is likely to be an attribute value instead of text content

[16:36:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
In the case of <span itemprop=foo>foo <img alt=bar> baz</span>, it should emit foo:"foo bar baz".

[16:36:01.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: that is a self-consistent model

[16:36:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
There is no way to get @title into a Microdata value.

[16:36:03.0000] <othermaciej>
although that solution doesn't scale to @title

[16:37:00.0000] <Hixie>
TabAtkins: yeah i've long been a fan of inventing some property that serialises HTML to text "correctly", e.g. turning <bdo> into unicode bidi formatting characters, inserting quotes for <q>, inserting newlines for <br>, etc. People haven't really been enthusiastic about it.

[16:37:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
@title isn't a textual equivalent of the element, so it shouldn't substitute itself normally.

[16:37:02.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: WebKit tries to do that for innerText

[16:37:03.0000] <Hixie>
TabAtkins: in practice btw there are actually few cases where you want the alt="" -- mostly you're grabbing the URL for purposes other than showing it in a context where you need the alt, e.g. you're grabbing it to label that image with metadata like a license

[16:37:04.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: really?

[16:38:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
And, unfortunately, it doesn't share the distinction of @src, @href, etc of being a special, use-restricted attribute so that you can usefully say "whenever @itemprop is <foo>, use @bar for the value".

[16:38:01.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: right - it's clearly ancillary information that shouldn't inject itself into the text content

[16:38:02.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: well at the very least we respect <br> and omit the text for some elements that are always unrendered

[16:38:03.0000] <othermaciej>
can't remember if we insert generated content

[16:38:04.0000] <othermaciej>
but innerText at least at one point did the same thing as Copy --> Past as Plain Text

[16:38:05.0000] <othermaciej>
*Paste

[16:39:00.0000] <Hixie>
interesting

[16:39:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Hixie: I agree that the case of wanting *only* the @alt, as in <img itemprop=foo alt=bar>, are rare.  I don't care about that.  I would like that case to continue to emit the @src.

[16:39:02.0000] <Hixie>
TabAtkins: i'm not talking about wanting only the alt, i mean wanting both

[16:39:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
But the cases on pages that I write where I have <h1><img alt="My Company Name"></h1> are much more common.

[16:40:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Yes, that's common.

[16:40:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'm not sure what you're objecting to changing, Hixie?

[16:40:02.0000] <Hixie>
the algorithm to grab text for a property

[16:40:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
If you want both, you specify an @itemprop on both the <img> (for the @src) and a wrapper (for the @alt).

[16:41:00.0000] <Hixie>
just use <meta>

[16:41:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's ridiculous when the information is *right there*, and it's completely unambiguous which data you want.

[16:41:02.0000] <Hixie>
*shrug*

[16:42:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's a pretty rare case and would make the mechanism less intuitive

[16:42:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
It's silly that <span itemprop=foo>foo <img alt=bar> baz</span> doesn't emit foo:"foo bar baz", and the only way to make it do so is to duplicate the whole text value in the <meta>

[16:42:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
...no, it's much more intuitive.  @alt is the textual replacement for the image.  If you want the text of an element that contains an image, you'll get the textual replacement of it.

[16:43:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
This is basic a11y stuff, and is the whole reason that @alt exists.

[16:43:01.0000] <Hixie>
it's also "silly" that <span itemprop=foo> <q>test</q> <br> <bdo dir=rtl>abc</bdo> </span> doesn't emit quotes, a newline, and bidi formatting characters

[16:43:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Agreed, to be honest.  Let's make all those changes.

[16:44:00.0000] <Hixie>
doing that leads to the implementation of microdata doubling or tripling in size

[16:44:01.0000] <Hixie>
it's not a good tradeoff

[16:45:00.0000] <Hixie>
and frankly it isn't necessary for most uses of microdata

[16:45:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Let's make browsers include a property for emitting it.

[16:45:02.0000] <Hixie>
browsers aren't the main consumers

[16:47:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Microdata currently defines that case as being the value of textContent.  This is a property exposed by whatever DOM implementation you're using.  We'd define a new property for DOM implementations to support that does "smart" text content.

[16:48:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
If you're not relying on an external parser to create and handle the DOM, then adding "smart" text content handling is *definitely* not a "doubling or tripling" of your code size.

[16:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
you'd be surprised

[16:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
textContent is implementable in about 3 lines

[16:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
what we're talking about here basically means implementing an HTML renderer for plain text

[16:49:03.0000] <Hixie>
that's 100+ lines

[16:49:04.0000] <Hixie>
maybe far more

[16:50:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
A "renderer" that handles, what, four cases total?  Plain text, <q> text, bidi text, and @alt.

[16:50:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
All I want is alt :)

[16:50:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
If you're starting from a SAX parser or something, it's definitely not 100+ lines unless you really, really suck somehow.

[16:51:00.0000] <Hixie>
there's far more to HTML than just the cases I mentioned

[16:53:00.0000] <ment>
how to best benchmark how much time browser spends rematching css on dom tree when i change the dom tree using js?

[16:54:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Let's see... I can see the possibility that you might want to do <sub> and <sup>, but I don't think there's an accept way to render them in plaintext.  You could *maybe* argue that <em> and <strong> deserve special formatting, but I can reasonably argue against it, I think.  I believe that's about it.

[16:55:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Everything else is sufficient as plain text for any purpose that Microdata might need.

[16:55:01.0000] <Hixie>
i am highly skeptical

[16:55:02.0000] <Hixie>
and again, i really don't think the use cases need this

[16:55:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
I think that @alt is the highest-priority one.

[16:56:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
If you're rolling your own DOM, then just where you loop through the nodes and check if they're text nodes, also check if they're element nodes with the name "img".

[16:56:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That is 2 lines (possibly more depending on your code formatting guidelines).

[16:57:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
You're already having to check if a node is an element node, to know if you have to recurse into it to search for more text nodes.

[16:58:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
All I want is alt :)

[16:58:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
So I challenge your statement that this would greatly increase the implementation cost.  The increase is so minor as to be trivial.

[16:58:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
JonathanNeal: I'm fine with just @alt too.  ^_^

[16:59:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
At least with <q> and <bdo> the contents are *available*, even if formatted badly.  <img alt> is simply *omitted* as it stands.


2010-04-16
[17:07:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
/me will just go file a bug about ti.

[17:08:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Do these bugs auto-cc the submitter, or do I need to manually put my email in the CC list?

[17:18:00.0000] <Hixie>
TabAtkins: the other elements that would need handling are all the flow ones, all the controls, dir="", lang="" (turning into unicode lang tags), things like <script> and <style> being hidden, <pre> not collapsing spaces but other things collapsing them, lists, <time>, it just gets more and more intractable

[17:19:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Okay, then we skip that.  All of those still return a useful value for their textContent, even if it's somewhat misformatted.  <img> returns nothing, though.

[17:19:01.0000] <Hixie>
so don't use it

[17:19:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's really not a big problem

[17:20:00.0000] <Hixie>
i really don't see why <img> is important but, say, <br> is not

[17:21:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
For the reason I just stated.  Losing a linebreak makes the text somewhat misformatted, but the text is still *there* and can be read.

[17:23:00.0000] <Hixie>
<bdo> then

[17:23:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Again, misformatted, but still present.

[17:24:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
A human can parse it, even if it's somewhat confusing.

[17:24:01.0000] <Hixie>
O_o neht ,dettamrof yldab tsuj si siht kniht uoy fi

[17:24:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
I can read it!

[17:25:00.0000] <Hixie>
the model works fine as is, uing textContent -- it's trivial to understand, doesn't need any special cases, and is easy to predict

[17:25:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
And it would only come out like that if a parent element's text contained a bidi override character.

[17:25:02.0000] <hober>
M-x reverse-region is your friend :)

[17:25:03.0000] <Hixie>
as soon as we start adding magic, things start going down the path to RDFa

[17:25:04.0000] <JonathanNeal>
): tla si tnaw I llA

[17:25:05.0000] <Hixie>
what's the use case for this anyway? what are you using microdata for for which you need alt?

[17:26:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Dude, there's no magic.  You want text, you get text, including the text equivalent of things that have text equivalents.

[17:26:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Sigh.  <h1 itemprop="fn org"><img src=foo alt="Example Corp"></h1>

[17:27:00.0000] <Hixie>
having to check each element's namespace and localname to see if it's an <img> from which to grab alt="" is magic.

[17:27:01.0000] <Hixie>
why would you use an image there?

[17:27:02.0000] <Hixie>
just use <h1>Example Corp</h1>

[17:27:03.0000] <TabAtkins>

[17:28:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[17:28:01.0000] <Hixie>

[17:28:02.0000] <TabAtkins>

[17:28:03.0000] <Hixie>

[17:29:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[17:29:01.0000] <Hixie>

[17:29:02.0000] <TabAtkins>

[17:29:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[17:29:04.0000] <Hixie>

[17:30:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

rigt?

[17:31:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[17:31:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
No "n" required.

[17:31:02.0000] <Hixie>
vcard requires "n" for all vcards

[17:31:03.0000] <TabAtkins>

[17:31:04.0000] <Hixie>
the microdata vcard vocab has none of that magic

[17:31:05.0000] <TabAtkins>

[17:33:00.0000] <Hixie>

[17:34:00.0000] <Hixie>

[17:34:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
If I can believe the wiki, you don't need any of the implied fn magic.  If you're doing an org name, the org name should be specified as the value of both "fn" and "org", and *no* value shoudl be specified for the "n" properties (they should all be blank).

[17:34:02.0000] <Hixie>

is "Kent" the given name or the surname?

[16:44:00.0000] <dglazkov>
can someone point me to a place that specifies submit-on-enter behavior for forms? I've been looking at http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/forms.html#forms and can't spot it

[16:45:00.0000] <dglazkov>
in other words, in which cases does hitting an enter in a textfield could submit a form?

[16:45:01.0000] <dglazkov>
IE and FF seem to agree that only if there's one text area and no submit button in the form.

[16:45:02.0000] <dglazkov>
WebKit just does it if there's no submit button.

[16:45:03.0000] <dglazkov>
either behavior seems arbitrary and weird.

[16:45:04.0000] <Hixie>
search for "default button" or some such

[16:46:00.0000] <Hixie>
or "default submit button"

[16:47:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[16:47:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[16:47:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[16:48:00.0000] <othermaciej>
dglazkov: seems like this is also more a UI issue than an interop issue - it might be irrelevant on platforms with a virtual keyboard that doesn't have "enter" when editing a text field for instance

[16:48:01.0000] <dglazkov>

[16:49:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[16:49:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[16:49:02.0000] <dglazkov>

[16:49:03.0000] <Hixie>

[16:49:04.0000] <Hixie>

[16:50:03.0000] <Hixie>

[16:51:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[16:51:01.0000] <Hixie>

[16:51:02.0000] <TabAtkins>

[16:51:03.0000] <TabAtkins>

[18:45:02.0000] <annevk>

[18:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
k

[18:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
so no tasks run while sync xhr is happening, right?

[18:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
i'm trying to work out how it interacts with workers

[18:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
seems fine currently

[18:49:03.0000] <annevk>
yeah, that's the idea

[18:49:04.0000] <annevk>
no timeouts, no events

[18:49:05.0000] <othermaciej>
you mean workings running a sync XHR, or running during a sync XHR?

[18:50:00.0000] <Hixie>
the former

[18:50:01.0000] <Hixie>
annevk: thanks

[18:51:00.0000] <Hixie>
annevk: should that change, you'll likely need to use the "spin the event loop" hook, in which case let me know because i'll have to define how that works with workers

[18:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
annevk: currnetly workers don't support 'spin the event loop' or 'await a stable state'/'synchronous sections', because nothing that runs in a worker can trigger those

[18:51:02.0000] <Hixie>
(i just noticed the storage mutex isn't handled right in workers and i'm fixing that)

[18:52:00.0000] <annevk>
okay

[02:06:00.0000] <jgraham>
zcorpan: It is not clear to me that there is a "natural" order for the arguments of assertEquals

[02:08:00.0000] <Philip`>
assertEquals(1+1, 2);

[02:08:01.0000] <Philip`>
assertEquals(2, 1+1);

[02:08:02.0000] <Philip`>

[02:08:03.0000] <zcorpan>

[02:09:00.0000] <jgraham>

[02:09:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:09:02.0000] <jgraham>
I'm not sure I agree

[02:10:00.0000] <jgraham>

[02:11:00.0000] <jgraham>
But assert equals 2, 1+1 also makes sense

[02:11:01.0000] <jgraham>
Not typical english word order but logical

[02:16:01.0000] <zcorpan>

[02:19:00.0000] <othermaciej>
jgraham: imagine if you also had assertFalse(), assertTrue(), assertThrowsException()

[02:19:01.0000] <othermaciej>
in each case you would want the test expression as the first parameter I think

[02:19:02.0000] <othermaciej>
so for consistency, assertEquals should also have it first, and the expectation second

[02:19:03.0000] <othermaciej>
my 2c anyway

[02:21:00.0000] <jgraham>
othermaciej: assertThrows should take some object to indicate the expected type and properties of the exception

[02:21:01.0000] <jgraham>
So that isn't an obvious counter-example

[02:30:00.0000] <othermaciej>
jgraham: it also needs to take a string to eval instead of an expression to do anything useful

[02:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
Isn't it better to pass a function(){} to call than a string to eval?

[02:32:01.0000] <othermaciej>
this is what WebKit's script tests look like: http://trac.webkit.org/export/57879/trunk/LayoutTests/fast/dom/HTMLAnchorElement/set-href-attribute-hash.html

[02:32:02.0000] <jgraham>
othermaciej: I would pass a function

[02:33:00.0000] <othermaciej>
and view the linked script-tests/set-href-attribute-hash.js to see what the actual test scripts look like

[02:33:01.0000] <jgraham>
/me has written an assertThrows with the signature assertThrows(expectedException, callable, message)

[02:33:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I think both the output and the source are more readable than Microsoft's format

[02:34:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(or whoever came up with that)

[02:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>
we use strings for both the test expression and the expectation

[02:34:02.0000] <othermaciej>
that way shouldBe (our version of assertEquals) can catch exceptions

[02:34:03.0000] <othermaciej>
so it can report unexpected throw instead of making the rest of the test bomb out

[02:35:00.0000] <othermaciej>
otherwise you have to either surround every test assertion with try/catch, or pass everything as closures

[02:35:01.0000] <jgraham>
I don't like using strings; making everything rely on eval can have surprising results

[02:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
in practice it hasn't caused a problem

[02:36:01.0000] <othermaciej>
other than people getting confused about the need to double-quote actual strings

[02:37:00.0000] <othermaciej>
anyway, strings are not the main point

[02:37:01.0000] <othermaciej>
my point was (a) readable output; (b) readable test script

[02:37:02.0000] <jgraham>
I think quoting hell plus the lack of syntax highlighting for the test code is enough to put me off

[02:37:03.0000] <othermaciej>
could easily convert the system to use all closures

[02:39:00.0000] <othermaciej>
here is one with examples of more of the types of assertions: http://trac.webkit.org/export/57879/trunk/LayoutTests/fast/js/regexp-compile.html

[02:39:01.0000] <jgraham>
We have a whole bunch of javascript tests that use assertEquals(expected, actual, [message]) type syntax, use try/catch on the backend to handle failures and uses closures for cases where the test is expected to throw

[02:39:02.0000] <jgraham>
It has worked pretty well

[02:39:03.0000] <othermaciej>
and the corresponding JS source: http://trac.webkit.org/export/57879/trunk/LayoutTests/fast/js/script-tests/regexp-compile.js

[02:40:00.0000] <jgraham>
(nothing that I can link to sadly)

[02:41:00.0000] <othermaciej>
anyway, say what you will about the details of the assert function parameters, I think our output is the most useful I have seen for script tests

[02:41:01.0000] <othermaciej>
the color makes it easy to spot failures at a glance, it copies to plain text well, it doesn't have pointless tables, etc

[02:41:02.0000] <jgraham>
However, I think the main difficulty with DOM tests (rather than pure ECMAScript tests) is dealing with async results\

[02:42:00.0000] <jgraham>
e.g. if you want to test that some event is fired when it ought to be

[02:42:01.0000] <othermaciej>
another reason to use strings is to include the test expression in the test output

[02:42:02.0000] <othermaciej>
so you don't have to say what ou tested a second time

[02:42:03.0000] <othermaciej>
that's definitely a problem with *some* DOM tests

[02:43:00.0000] <othermaciej>
not with the attributes of the <a> element though

[02:43:01.0000] <jgraham>
Well no

[02:43:02.0000] <jgraham>
But in general, if you want a framework that deals well with testing DOM, it has to test async stuff well

[02:43:03.0000] <jgraham>
That is the problem that I don't feel I have ever found a good solution to

[02:44:00.0000] <othermaciej>
we use ad hoc methods

[02:44:01.0000] <jgraham>
(A good general solution rather than just making it up for each specific case)

[02:44:02.0000] <othermaciej>
the most annoying is if you want to test that some async event fires eventually, and one possible bug is that it never fires

[02:44:03.0000] <othermaciej>
then you kinda have to add an arbitrary timeout, unless you know of a later event that will likely fire even in the bug case

[02:44:04.0000] <jgraham>
Yeah, but that's a pretty typical case

[02:45:00.0000] <gsnedders>
othermaciej: But the problem with outputting the JS source is that doing it as the WebKit tests do relying upon eval seems bad

[02:45:01.0000] <othermaciej>
we end up just relying on the fact that our test framework times out eventually

[02:45:02.0000] <jgraham>
So it sucks if you have to reinvent the wheel every single time

[02:46:00.0000] <othermaciej>
gsnedders: I hate eval as much as the next guy, but the string thing works really well in this case - too bad JS doesn't have macros

[02:47:00.0000] <jgraham>
othermaciej: If you write tests with one test per function, you can toString the function to get the text of the test

[02:47:01.0000] <zcorpan>
i now have a default timeout of 2s (many tests depend on network so need quite a long timeout) and require an explicit end() when the test is done in my framework

[02:47:02.0000] <jgraham>
it's not quite as simple

[02:47:03.0000] <zcorpan>
it works pretty well for async tests

[02:48:00.0000] <gsnedders>
othermaciej: Until you come across cases where you have bugs and eval has bugs the normal codepath doesn't (or vice-versa)

[02:48:01.0000] <Philip`>
/me does assertEqual(1+1, 2, "1+1", "2"); in order to be able to output the JS source without relying on eval

[02:48:02.0000] <othermaciej>
jgraham: true, and then you are just trading off the oddities of eval and the awkwardness of quoting for the oddities of code in a function and the awkwardness of saying function() { } all the time

[02:48:03.0000] <othermaciej>
Philip`: I think repeating yourself is a worse programming sin than eval

[02:48:04.0000] <Philip`>
...with an ugly custom preprocessor language that converts "@assert 1+1 == 2;" into that syntax automatically

[02:48:05.0000] <Philip`>
so that I don't have to repeat anything :-)

[02:49:00.0000] <othermaciej>
using a preprocessor is cheating :-)

[02:49:01.0000] <gsnedders>
othermaciej: But functions work better in the case of JITing compilers that compile whole functions at once, as then you can just loop the function

[02:49:02.0000] <jgraham>
It's true that tests-in-a-function can have problems if you want to test something that specifically depends on global scope

[02:49:03.0000] <zcorpan>
/me does assertEquals(1+1, 2, "1+1") or just assertEquals(1+1, 2)

[02:49:04.0000] <othermaciej>
/me still wonders what y'all think of the output format, as opposed to the use of eval

[02:50:00.0000] <jgraham>
These problems are perhaps more pronounced if you are trying to test the ECMAScript engine itself rather than the DOM

[02:50:01.0000] <gsnedders>
The output format is I don't think an issue, and is really just a bikeshed :)

[02:51:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:51:01.0000] <jgraham>
othermaciej: It's pretty nice. Not quite to die for though ;)

[02:51:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:51:03.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:51:04.0000] <jgraham>

[02:51:05.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:52:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't get why it's a table at all

[02:52:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I also can't tell what it's actually testing from reading

[02:52:02.0000] <zcorpan>
/me 's output is a <pre> which says "PASS" if it passed, or "FAIL" followed by the failing messages if it failed

[02:52:03.0000] <othermaciej>
since the descriptions are arbitrary strings and don't show the code it ran

[02:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>
readable test output makes it much easier for implementors to look at the test and fix their implementations accordingly

[02:53:01.0000] <othermaciej>
which is why I think it's important, more so than the details of how test assertions are coded

[03:02:00.0000] <jgraham>
othermaciej: I need to read the source code in either case to be confident I know what is going on

[03:03:00.0000] <othermaciej>
which is why it helps for the source to be readable too, which is why I dislike the giant try/catch blocks, and the fact that it's hard to map the table output to the test assertions in the source

[03:03:01.0000] <jgraham>
Giant try/catch blocks are unnecessary

[03:04:00.0000] <jgraham>
You should be able to do function testAddition() {assertEquals(2, 1+1)}

[03:05:00.0000] <jgraham>
Then you only need to dive in deeper if you broke the harness itself not the test

[03:05:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Does IE9 mode have a default border on linked images?

[03:05:02.0000] <jgraham>
(and you should make the harness simple to avoid that)

[03:06:00.0000] <jgraham>
and you can use e.g. the <details> element in the output to show the full test source

[03:06:01.0000] <zcorpan>

[03:07:00.0000] <jgraham>

[03:07:01.0000] <jgraham>

[03:07:02.0000] <jgraham>

[03:08:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[03:08:01.0000] <jgraham>

[03:09:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[03:09:01.0000] <jgraham>

[10:22:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hixie, is there some particular reason that uploads are disabled on the wiki, or should I go ahead and enable them?

[10:22:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[10:24:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I hypothesize that video games have more markup in subtitles because they're really targeted at everyone, not just the hard-of-hearing.  In many games, not all lines are even voice-acted, so subtitles have to be on.  In other cases the speaker might be far away or drowned out by loud noises, since dialog isn't always fully scripted.

[10:26:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Also, they're always from scripts, so you can copy italics from the scripts if applicable.  In unscripted videos, or videos that follow a loose script, there's no transcript to tell you definitively whether something should be italicized or bolded or such.

[10:27:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I don't think 3D video games are good examples to base HTML5 video stuff on, except if it's an actual video cutscene rather than an in-game dialog (and actual video cutscenes are rare these days in games).

[10:27:01.0000] <Philip`>
/me notes that Portal (and presumably HL2 too?) has both subtitles (for everyone) and closed captions (for hard-of-hearing)

[14:25:00.0000] <danbri>
browser geeks, may I ask for some help w/ rdfa idioms?

[14:25:01.0000] <danbri>
in rdfa/xhtml it is ok to put <object><span ...rdfablahblah></span></object> in the <head> of a doc...

[14:26:00.0000] <danbri>
...if such a block of markup found its way out of the xhtml universe and into html5 or pre-html5 html doc header, ... does anyone know of ugly side-effects of putting object/span there?

[14:27:00.0000] <Philip`>
danbri: The <object> would force an implicit </head><body> in most (all?) browsers

[14:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
(It seems pretty bogus that HTML4 (hence XHTML) allows <object> in <head>, since it doesn't work like that)

[14:34:00.0000] <danbri>
so if this is done, it should be the last section of <head> at least?

[14:35:00.0000] <jgraham>
It can't end up in head at all in HTML5/real text/html browsers

[14:35:01.0000] <danbri>
well this design is for the xhtml flavour, but it would be nice if it was non-destructive if it leaked elsewhere

[14:35:02.0000] <danbri>
what would the practical consequences be?

[14:36:00.0000] <danbri>
(hopefully the html/rdfa wg will come up with some microdata/rdfa hybrid in future and i won't have to be asking such things next year...)

[14:37:00.0000] <jgraham>
danbri: Play around with http://livedom.validator.nu/?%3C!DOCTYPE%20html%3E%0A%3Chead%3E%0A%3Cobject%3E%3C%2Fobject%3E

[14:38:00.0000] <jgraham>
Basically the practical consequences wouldbe that anything that expected the object to end up in head would break and there would be a high chance of collateral damage from things moving out of head that shouldn't

[14:39:00.0000] <danbri>
so only rdfa parsers would be looking for it in head...

[14:39:01.0000] <Philip`>
The practical consequences would be that HTML5 parser developers would curse you for exploiting misfeatures in the HTML4 DTD

[14:39:02.0000] <danbri>
...and if the <object> block was the last thing in </head> then nothing else would be bumped into body...

[14:40:00.0000] <Philip`>
and it would abort in pure streaming HTML5 parsers

[14:40:01.0000] <Philip`>
when it hits the explicit <body> later

[14:42:00.0000] <Dashiva>
A non-legacy timed text format that doesn't support ruby... heh

[14:44:00.0000] <Philip`>
danbri: <head><link etc><object></object><body foo> would (in non-streaming parsers) give the same DOM as <head><link etc></head><body foo><object></object> so that should indeed work

[14:48:00.0000] <danbri>
and spans inside the object would survive? page display and function generally ok in currently deployed browser?

[14:51:00.0000] <Philip`>
danbri: As far as I'm aware, yes

[14:51:01.0000] <Philip`>
although it looks like IE6 doesn't put the <object> element in the DOM at all

[14:52:00.0000] <Philip`>
and puts the <span> element as a child of the <head>

[14:52:01.0000] <Philip`>
Oh, and then it crashes

[14:52:02.0000] <Hixie>
note that putting <object> in <head> is non-conforming in XHTML5 and HTML5

[14:56:00.0000] <danbri>
thanks guys

[14:56:01.0000] <danbri>
so what's this about 'would abort'? I thought html5 parsers were softer, gentler more accepting creatures...

[14:57:00.0000] <Philip`>
In slightly rare cases, like if you want SAX output without potentially-unlimited internal buffering in the parser, there are some errors you can't correctly recover from

[14:58:00.0000] <Philip`>
e.g. <body foo><body bar> (which should be equivalent to <body foo bar> but it's too late if you emit the body element after reading the first tag)

[14:59:00.0000] <Philip`>
which (unless I'm mistaken) is what happens when you put non-head content inside a <head> (so it emits an implicit body element) and then have a body tag later

[15:01:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah, if you have a streaming parser (unusual for web browsers, but probably not unusual for rdfa processors) then that would likely cause an abort

[15:01:01.0000] <Hixie>
unless the streaming processor basically buffers everything

[15:01:02.0000] <Hixie>
but then it's not really streaming

[15:01:03.0000] <danbri>
ok well it seems the folk i'm helping are gonna stick with 'meta tags' for now

[15:02:00.0000] <danbri>
which gives some breathing time at least

links to the other pages?

[18:28:00.0000] <Hixie>
nessy: should a UA always grab all the tracks from the network, or should it only grab tracks when they're enabled?

[18:29:00.0000] <nessy>
external files: only when they are enabled

[18:29:01.0000] <Hixie>
interesting

[18:29:02.0000] <nessy>
save bandwidth where you can, I'd say

[18:29:03.0000] <nessy>
why?

[18:30:00.0000] <Hixie>
so we really need three modes when we have the API... on and displayed, on but only for hte API, and off

[18:30:01.0000] <nessy>
what do you mean by "on but only for the API"?

[18:30:02.0000] <Hixie>
suppose one of the timed tracks is a list of IDs of slides and times for when the slides turn on and off

[18:31:00.0000] <Hixie>
you wouldn't want the IDs actually shown on the video (or even listed in the UI)

[18:31:01.0000] <Hixie>
but you'd still want then "enabled" and triggering events for the script

[18:31:02.0000] <Hixie>
s/then/them/

[18:32:00.0000] <nessy>
are you saying that external tracks should trigger events even if they are not active?

[18:32:01.0000] <Hixie>
what do you mean by active?

[18:32:02.0000] <Hixie>
(if they're triggering events, presumably they are active)

[18:32:03.0000] <nessy>
hmm… I guess there is a difference between being loaded and being displayed

[18:34:00.0000] <nessy>
maybe this has to be done with two different attributes just like on the media elements

[18:34:01.0000] <nessy>
something akin to @controls for being displayed and something akin to @preload for being "available"

[18:35:00.0000] <nessy>
though those names of course don't match

[18:35:01.0000] <Hixie>
i can't see any good way to do it other than something in attributes, yes

[18:35:02.0000] <Hixie>
but for now i'm just trying to work out requirements

[18:36:00.0000] <Hixie>
so that i can go through your proposals

[18:36:01.0000] <nessy>
sure - my brain jumped ahead

[18:36:02.0000] <nessy>
there is some need for turning on and off UA display

[18:37:00.0000] <nessy>
and there is some need for enabling / disabling a track and its events

[18:38:00.0000] <nessy>
it may even make sense to have that fourth state: displaying, but no events triggered

[18:38:01.0000] <Hixie>
oh?

[18:39:00.0000] <nessy>
no?

[18:39:01.0000] <nessy>
if the Web developer knows they don't need the events why should the UA have to make the effort?

[18:40:00.0000] <othermaciej>
nessy: no events of what kind?

[18:40:01.0000] <othermaciej>
nessy: like DOM events for JavaScript?

[18:40:02.0000] <Hixie>
nessy: an event every few seconds isn't a big deal

[18:40:03.0000] <othermaciej>
nessy: browsers can optimize to avoid dispatching the event at all if there are no listeners

[18:40:04.0000] <nessy>
we're just talking about the cues from external text resources for media elements

[18:40:05.0000] <othermaciej>
if it is a performance issue to dispatch it

[18:41:00.0000] <nessy>
ok - I was just thinking through the logical possibilities and whether three states will do or whether there are two independent dimensions

[18:42:00.0000] <othermaciej>
what are the three states being considered?

[18:45:00.0000] <nessy>

[18:55:00.0000] <nessy>

[18:55:01.0000] <nessy>

[18:56:00.0000] <nessy>
CSS and Web Fonts cannot be the only part to trigger styling - it might come from the text resources

[18:59:00.0000] <nessy>
looks like you are solving the cue ranges problem as well with this ;)

[19:08:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah hopefully we can hit cue ranges as well, that would be nice

[19:09:00.0000] <Hixie>
dunno what to do with the styling thing... are we sure we don't just want it to be CSS?

[19:09:01.0000] <Hixie>
i mean most systems don't let the author style the captions at all, from what i've seen

[19:09:02.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. TVs these days put that under teh control of the user

[19:10:00.0000] <Hixie>
and HTML itself has moved towards putting all styling in CSS

[19:10:01.0000] <Hixie>
it would be weird to make subtitles an exception

[19:10:02.0000] <Hixie>
but i don't know, depends what the use cases are

[19:58:00.0000] <nessy>
some of the formats have styling

[20:01:00.0000] <nessy>
like the QTText example that I emailed:

[20:01:01.0000] <nessy>
{QTtext} {size:16} {font:Lucida Grande} {width:320} {height:42}

[20:01:02.0000] <nessy>
{language:0} {textColor:65535,65535,65535} {backColor:0,0,0}

[20:01:03.0000] <nessy>
{doNotAutoScale:off} {timeScale:100} {timeStamps:absolute}

[20:01:04.0000] <nessy>
{justify:center}

[20:01:05.0000] <nessy>
but often this is ignored

[20:02:00.0000] <nessy>
where styling is on the elements rather than on the full text cue, we cannot simply ignore it I think

[20:02:01.0000] <nessy>
formats is a whole problem by itself and I am tending towards developing this new one that we have been discussing on WHATWG and then mapping everything else to that

[20:17:00.0000] <nessy>
or look at SSA (substation alpha) format, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SubStation_Alpha

[20:17:01.0000] <nessy>
probably the most comprehensive subtitling format around

[20:31:00.0000] <nessy>
enojy your dinner

[20:31:01.0000] <nessy>
@media is supposed to be what it is for video: help filter a file for a particular device

[20:32:00.0000] <nessy>
for example if some caption file is written for a specific width, but wouldn't work on mobile, then there might be a max-width on it

[20:33:00.0000] <nessy>
as for sign language videos, they are the same problem as actual audio descriptions (the ones that are recorded voice)

[20:33:01.0000] <nessy>
they both are not time-aligned text, but time-aligned other media resources

[20:34:00.0000] <nessy>
the browser vendors have all told me that they don't want to implement such media synchronisation at this point in time, in particular if they come from different servers

[20:34:01.0000] <nessy>
(btw: did you see my test at http://blog.gingertech.net/2010/02/12/audio-track-accessibility-for-html5/ ?)

[20:35:00.0000] <nessy>
however, the idea is that the <track> element will allow for such media files in the future, too

[20:35:01.0000] <nessy>
so, the proposal already covers it

[00:45:00.0000] <Hixie>
nessy: do sign language files and recorded audio descriptions have built-in timings?

[15:05:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I was wondering if I could get some feedback from you guys on http://sandbox.thewikies.com/learn-html/ a project I'm writing to teach kids HTML.

[15:06:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Or maybe 9th graders (not little ones)

[15:08:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Interesting.

[15:09:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I think those kids are too young to get "all your base" :)

[15:11:00.0000] <Dashiva>
It's interesting, but I'm not sure if <em> and <strong> are good example elements. They're fairly abstract, and very similar (semantically, not visually)

[15:14:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Dashiva, sure, what other elements would be useful suggestions?  I picked <em> because it was short.

[15:14:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I would have picked <b> or <i> but I really didn't want to encourage that.

[15:18:00.0000] <Dashiva>
You could use one of em/strong, and another elements with a different type. E.g. <sup>

[15:18:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Or <a>, though that's probably too complex for a first lesson.

[15:19:00.0000] <Dashiva>
<hx> and <p> are also common starting elements, in my experience

[15:21:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
JonathanNeal: Honestly, teaching kids <b> and <i>, and having them be misused to mark up emphasis and importance, is better than teaching them <strong> and <em>, and having them be misused to mark up citations, foreign words, random bold text, etc.

[15:21:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Having not enough semantics is better than having wrong semantics.

[15:22:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Dashiva, headings and paragraphs would be the next lesson, I think.

[15:23:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I would tend to agree with what TabAtkins said there

[15:23:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I wanted to go for inline elements first, then either block elements or attributes (img, a, etc)

[15:24:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[15:24:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[15:25:03.0000] <Philip`>

[15:25:04.0000] <Dashiva>

[15:26:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[15:26:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[15:27:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[15:28:00.0000] <Philip`>

2010-04-22
[17:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
nessy: do you have an opinion on whether we need to support roll-up or incrementally displayed titles, as you see on live TV broadcasts?

[17:29:01.0000] <nessy>
they are typically used for live captioning

[17:30:00.0000] <nessy>
so, for live streaming, probably yes, though I don't quite know how that would work

[17:30:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah that was my next question - do we need to support live streaming, and what would that mean?

[17:30:02.0000] <Hixie>
presumably any live streamed captions would just be in the video file itself, rather than as an external file?

[17:30:03.0000] <Hixie>
or am i wrong?

[17:33:00.0000] <nessy>
I don't know, to be honest

[17:33:01.0000] <nessy>
I think what could be possible for live captions is to continuously write into an srt fil with timing and we would have to pick it up as it goes

[17:34:00.0000] <nessy>
but if it is included in the media file, then it's nothing different

[17:34:01.0000] <Hixie>
well if it's in the media file i conveniently don't have to worry about defining the format for it

[17:34:02.0000] <Hixie>
or the rendering semantics

[17:34:03.0000] <nessy>
indeed :)

[17:34:04.0000] <nessy>
ah, I think you still do

[17:34:05.0000] <Hixie>
so it's different in one rather important way :-)

[17:34:06.0000] <Hixie>
well i'm not defining e.g. the TTML rendering semantics

[17:34:07.0000] <nessy>
the rendering should be done the same no matter if it comes from an external file or from a media resource, IMO

[17:35:00.0000] <nessy>
incrementally displayed captions are still necessary since that is what karaoke does, no?

[17:35:01.0000] <Hixie>
i don't think that's possible, e.g. if an embedded timed track is a video of sign language, it can't possibly be rendered using the same CSS rules as an external SRT-like file.

[17:35:02.0000] <nessy>
no, I'm only talking about text tracks

[17:36:00.0000] <nessy>
external sign language video cannot be rendered into text either

[17:36:01.0000] <Hixie>
what's a "text" track? Is SVG+SMIL a "text" track?

[17:36:02.0000] <Hixie>
is TTML?

[17:36:03.0000] <Hixie>
would HTML+SMIL be?

[17:37:00.0000] <nessy>
I was talking about media-internal text tracks there, but yes, external files that are synchronised with the media would be regarded as virtual text tracks

[17:37:01.0000] <nessy>
if the browser can parse TTML, then it is a virtual text track

[17:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
we can define the rendering model of some formats, e.g. explaining where the text gets aligned, how it gets its styles from CSS, what happens if they are overlapping in time and how to do automatic stacking, etc, but we can't do that if the format has a built-in rendering model like XSL:FO or SVG

[17:38:01.0000] <nessy>
if the browser can parse HTML+SMIL and it is built to be a time-aligned text file, then yes, though with all of SMIL it generally would not be

[17:38:02.0000] <Hixie>
imho

[17:39:00.0000] <nessy>
I was hoping we could take the styles given in any format (including things like SSA, TTML, even SMILText) and transcode what is possible to CSS and then render it - then if the Web developer is overriding those stylings, that is fine

[17:39:01.0000] <nessy>
just like any media player does a best effort with caption formats that it supports

[17:39:02.0000] <Hixie>
that's an inane amount of work

[17:40:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's basically defining how you map XSL:FO to CSS, which is something the CSS and XSL working groups have avoided doing for about a decade

[17:40:01.0000] <nessy>
writing a image or video decoding library is, too - I regard these as text decoding libraries

[17:40:02.0000] <nessy>
and text decoding should be simpler ;)

[17:40:03.0000] <Hixie>
it's not

[17:41:00.0000] <Hixie>
if someone writes that spec, i'm willing to reconsider, but i think it would take me ~1 to 2 years to write such a spec, full-time

[17:41:01.0000] <nessy>
you don't have to map all of XSL:FO - only the stuff that TTML supports

[17:41:02.0000] <Hixie>
i'm talking about what TTML supports

[17:41:03.0000] <nessy>
really? there's not that much there, I thought...

[17:42:00.0000] <Hixie>
CSS and things like the inline box model are complicated to a degree that i cannot overstate

[17:42:01.0000] <nessy>
but indeed - until such time, it will not fit into the model and not be parsable

[17:42:02.0000] <Hixie>
well it can be parseable

[17:42:03.0000] <Hixie>
i don't see why we'd prevent it from being supported and rendered

[17:42:04.0000] <Hixie>
it just wouldn't automatically slide out of the way like multiple SRT captions could

[17:42:05.0000] <nessy>
how would you do that?

[17:42:06.0000] <Hixie>
it would effectively just be treated as a video stream

[17:43:00.0000] <Hixie>
wouldn't be affected by CSS pseudos or whatever mechanism we come up with to style srt-like subtitles (assuming we go with an srt model styled with pseudo-elements)

[17:43:01.0000] <nessy>
that's what Sean wants, I think … not sure I agree...

[17:44:00.0000] <nessy>
why wouldn't the content of a TTML <div> be treated like a srt-like subtitle and be able to apply the pseudo-elements to?

[17:44:01.0000] <nessy>
even if everything inside is "like a video stream"

[17:44:02.0000] <Hixie>
pseudo-elements apply at the inline box model level

[17:45:00.0000] <nessy>
we should not define an inline box model for srt - we should define an inline box model for cues, no matter where they come from

[17:45:01.0000] <Hixie>
CSS already has an inline box model. It's different than TTML's.

[17:45:02.0000] <Hixie>
i don't suggest we invent an inline box model.

[17:45:03.0000] <Hixie>
that way lies madness

[17:46:00.0000] <nessy>
ok, but you are creating boxes for srt

[17:46:01.0000] <Hixie>
i don't suggest creating boxes for srt

[17:46:02.0000] <nessy>
I suggest not to do that, but to create boxes for cues

[17:46:03.0000] <Hixie>
i suggest just defining how srt maps to css boxes

[17:46:04.0000] <Hixie>
maybe i'm not sure what you mean by "box"

[17:46:05.0000] <Hixie>
i am talking about CSS inline, line, and block boxes

[17:46:06.0000] <nessy>
and the cues could be handed "transparently" from TTML or any other format, just like decoded text - independent how that decoding is done

[17:46:07.0000] <Hixie>
TTML isn't text

[17:46:08.0000] <Hixie>
it's preformatted pixels

[17:47:00.0000] <Hixie>
just like HTML+CSS

[17:47:01.0000] <Hixie>
i don't know how to convey the complexity involved in defining a rendering model

[17:47:02.0000] <nessy>
can we deal with TTML as pre-formatted pixels by in a box per cue

[17:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
well we could but what does that give us?

[17:48:01.0000] <Hixie>
doesn't TTML define positioning?

[17:48:02.0000] <nessy>
only in relation to a "root area"

[17:48:03.0000] <nessy>
where we place the "root area" is up to us

[17:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
well we can't make the root area much less than the whole video, unless the text is going to end up very small or cropped

[17:49:01.0000] <nessy>
hmm … but I think I am starting to see what you mean ...

[17:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
surely

[17:50:00.0000] <nessy>
that's really f*ed up, actually

[17:50:01.0000] <nessy>
cause of course TTML thinks it knows how to avoid objects, but it only knows how to avoid objects in the video, not on anything else rendered on top by other streams

[17:51:00.0000] <Hixie>
that's a problem most formats are going to have

[17:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
even any we define

[17:51:02.0000] <nessy>
i's going to have to be solved by the Web author - cannot be done automatically

[17:52:00.0000] <nessy>
btw: Sean did say that when, e.g. the controls slide on from the bottom, the "root area" would need to be adjusted for TTML and would be reduced by that size

[17:53:00.0000] <nessy>
but that's a special case that the browser can deal with

[17:54:00.0000] <Hixie>
btw can you think of a use case for the author disabling a track that would normally be enabled by default? e.g. disabling chapter navigation tracks, or captions in the user's language when the user has opted into always seeing those captions?

[17:54:01.0000] <nessy>
otoh Eric said that this won't work with pilot-control-type centered controls

[17:55:00.0000] <nessy>

[17:57:00.0000] <Hixie>

[17:57:01.0000] <nessy>

[17:58:00.0000] <nessy>

[18:27:00.0000] <nessy>

[18:27:01.0000] <Hixie>

[18:27:02.0000] <nessy>

[18:28:00.0000] <Hixie>

[18:29:00.0000] <nessy>
so the real question is: "if i need enabled="true"/enabled="false" vs just enabled="" "  ?

[18:29:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[18:30:00.0000] <nessy>

[18:30:01.0000] <nessy>

[18:33:00.0000] <Hixie>
not necessarily

[18:33:01.0000] <Hixie>
there are three states

[18:33:02.0000] <Hixie>
enabled, disabled, and default

[18:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
for example most captions are disabled by default, except if the user has requested captions by default

[18:35:00.0000] <Hixie>
the question is whether we need the "disabled" state

[18:35:01.0000] <nessy>

[18:35:02.0000] <Hixie>

[18:35:03.0000] <nessy>
you might have chapters in different languages?

[18:35:04.0000] <Hixie>
this is more about what gets downloaded

[18:35:05.0000] <Hixie>
hm, interesting

[18:36:00.0000] <Hixie>
how would a user pick the language of chapters he wanted?

[18:36:01.0000] <nessy>

[18:36:02.0000] <Hixie>

[18:36:03.0000] <nessy>

[18:36:04.0000] <nessy>

[18:37:00.0000] <nessy>

[18:42:00.0000] <Hixie>
ok, so i guess the default for chapters is to be disabled except if the language matches the user's language somehow, with a max of one enabled?

[18:43:00.0000] <Hixie>
if we do that, does that mean we no longer need a disabled state?

[18:43:01.0000] <nessy>
what is the state if they are disabled?

[18:44:00.0000] <Hixie>
not downloaded, don't fire events

[18:44:01.0000] <Hixie>
for subtitles, available to be turned on from the UI

[18:44:02.0000] <nessy>
I'm still strugging to follow your three state / two state model, in particular when you say it's different to what we discussed yesterday

[18:45:00.0000] <nessy>
sorry for being difficult

[18:46:00.0000] <Hixie>
i'm not really expressing myself very well

[18:46:01.0000] <Hixie>
mostly because i'm still trying to clarify it in my mind

[18:46:02.0000] <nessy>
designing a spec is difficult :)

[18:47:00.0000] <nessy>
so, I understand there are three states:

[18:47:01.0000] <Hixie>
yesterday we were talking about do-not-download, download-and-show, and download-and-hide. I think we can do away with the download-and-show vs download-and-hide distinction because it applies at the level of what kind of timed track it is -- e.g. metadata is never download-and-show, and subtitles are never download-and-hide

[18:47:02.0000] <Hixie>
but that's the actual state of the track while the video is playing

[18:47:03.0000] <nessy>
indeed, those three :)

[18:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
there's a related concern, which is what the initial state should be

[18:48:01.0000] <nessy>
what if a user interacts and turns subtitles off while they are playing?

[18:48:02.0000] <nessy>
then it would go from download-and-show to downloaded-and-hidden sorta?

[18:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
that'd be do-not-download again, although it'd be already downloaded

[18:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
but it wouldn't fire events

[18:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
anyway there are basically two possible initial states, the same two states we end up with up there: do-not-download-or-fire-events, and download-and-show/hide-as-appropriate,-and-fire-events

[18:50:00.0000] <nessy>
let me dissect this a bit

[18:50:01.0000] <Hixie>
however, there are three ways to express that for an author: do-whatever-is-appropriate (the default), never-download-this-even-if-the-user-wants-it, and always-download-and-show/hide-as-appropriate,-and-fire-events-even-if-the-user-doesn't-want-it

[18:51:00.0000] <Hixie>
my question is whether there's a use case for "never-download-this-even-if-the-user-wants-it"

[18:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
there's obviously a use case for "do-whatever-is-appropriate (the default)"

[18:51:02.0000] <Hixie>
and there's a use case for "always-download-and-show/hide-as-appropriate,-and-fire-events-even-if-the-user-doesn't-want-it", namely custom controls where the user has set defaults the UA doesn't know about

[18:51:03.0000] <nessy>
probably not - if a user wants it, it should be downloaded and shown

[18:53:00.0000] <nessy>
I'm currently seeing 4 different, but dependent dimensions: download (yes/no), display (yes/no), fire events (yes/no), user wants (yes/no)

[18:53:01.0000] <nessy>
and we call them all "enable/disable"

[18:54:00.0000] <Hixie>
heh

[18:54:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[18:54:02.0000] <Hixie>
the matrix of those options is pretty sparse though in terms of what we need to support

[18:54:03.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. download=no display=yes makes no sense :-)

[18:54:04.0000] <nessy>
I'm trying to follow your linearisation of that matrix ;)

[18:55:00.0000] <nessy>
when you way "user wants" - that's either "author wants events" or "user wants display", right? so we can get rid of that dimension?

[18:55:01.0000] <nessy>
s/way/say/

[18:57:00.0000] <Hixie>
"user wants" is always "user wants display", i think, for some definition of "display" that includes chapter navigation appearing in a drop-down menu

[18:58:00.0000] <nessy>
or elsewhere on screen

[18:59:00.0000] <nessy>
then "never-download-this-even-if-the-user-wants-it-displayed" surely is not viable

[19:02:00.0000] <Hixie>
k

[19:07:00.0000] <nessy>
so, I can see three definite states and two not so sure

[19:07:01.0000] <nessy>
1) no download, no display, no events

[19:07:02.0000] <nessy>
2) download, display, events

[19:07:03.0000] <nessy>
3) download, no display, events

[19:07:04.0000] <nessy>
maybe also

[19:08:00.0000] <nessy>
4) download, display, no events (though as maciej said yesterday, this is an optimisation in the browser and doesn't really need its own state)

[19:08:01.0000] <nessy>
and something of a "pre-load" nature could be:

[19:08:02.0000] <nessy>
5) download, no display, no events

[19:09:00.0000] <nessy>
5) would also be the state it gets into when a track is turned off manually

[19:10:00.0000] <nessy>
Hixie: does that match your model?

[19:14:00.0000] <Hixie>
1 and 5 are basically the same state

[19:14:01.0000] <nessy>
so, maybe these for attribute values: "disabled" (1), "preload" (5), "enabled" (3), "display" (2)

[19:14:02.0000] <Hixie>
4 i agree is unnecessary

[19:15:00.0000] <Hixie>
2 and 3 i think depends more on the kind of track than anything else

[19:15:01.0000] <nessy>
1 and 5 make a bandwidth use difference

[19:15:02.0000] <Hixie>
you wouldn't ever put a subtitle track into state 3, or a metadata track into state 1, right?

[19:15:03.0000] <Hixie>
er

[19:15:04.0000] <Hixie>
you wouldn't ever put a subtitle track into state 3, or a metadata track into state 2, right?

[19:15:05.0000] <nessy>
I'd hesitate to define behaviour based on the kind of track something is - I would prefer to do a generic model that works with all tracks

[19:16:00.0000] <Hixie>
i'm alergic to generic models :-P

[19:16:01.0000] <Hixie>
5 is a state you'll only reach by going through one of the others -- i don't see a use case for reaching it otherwise

[19:16:02.0000] <nessy>
get over it :P

[19:16:03.0000] <Hixie>
i'm really very skeptical of (over-)generalising things

[19:16:04.0000] <Hixie>
if there is a use case for the more general model i'm all for it

[19:17:00.0000] <nessy>
I'm not overly fussed about state 5 as an initial state - it could be used to encourage the browser to download the file in preparation for later use

[19:17:01.0000] <nessy>
but then, text resources are rather small generally, so shouldn't be too much of an issue

[19:17:02.0000] <Hixie>
there's another state too: a) download, no display, render to audio, events

[19:17:03.0000] <nessy>
such as?

[19:17:04.0000] <Hixie>
and another: c) download, no display, show on timeline, events

[19:17:05.0000] <Hixie>
a = text audio description tracks

[19:17:06.0000] <Hixie>
c = chapter titles

[19:18:00.0000] <nessy>
when I say "display" I mean "rendering"

[19:19:00.0000] <Hixie>
right, but i'm arguing that the kinds of rendering -- including no rendering -- are the same axis as the kind of track

[19:19:01.0000] <nessy>
but here I follow your model of - "what rendering means is obvious from the kind of track it is" :P

[19:19:02.0000] <Hixie>
imho there's no need to distinguish at the authoring level a chapter navigation track from a subtitles track

[19:19:03.0000] <Hixie>
they can both be SRT or whatever

[19:19:04.0000] <nessy>
well, my argument is that the UA will know what rendering means for the type of resource - it's not up to the author to decide

[19:20:00.0000] <Hixie>
when you label it as a chapter track, then you ignore positioning and just display it on the timeline

[19:20:01.0000] <Hixie>
how?

[19:20:02.0000] <Hixie>
if the author doesn't say what's what kind of track, how does the UA know?

[19:20:03.0000] <nessy>
that's what the @role attribute is for

[19:21:00.0000] <nessy>
I hope you're not intending to also mix the @role values into the @enabled attribute values?

[19:21:01.0000] <Hixie>
i'm arguing that you're mixing them up in your description

[19:21:02.0000] <Hixie>
but that they are distinct

[19:22:00.0000] <Hixie>
whether something is firing events and being appropriately displayed or not is orthogonal to how it should be displayed

[19:22:01.0000] <nessy>
yes, they are distinct

[19:23:00.0000] <nessy>
indeed - I was arguing because it's an orthogonal matter how they should be displayed, I don't have to worry about that dimension when I talk about firing events/displaying it

[19:23:01.0000] <nessy>
the means of display is on a different and totally independent dimension

[19:24:00.0000] <nessy>
but we should get back to the question "you wouldn't ever put a subtitle track into state 3, or a metadata track into state 2, right?"

[19:25:00.0000] <nessy>
I can see a subtitle track in state (3) if I don't want to UA to display the subtitles, but rather want as an author to display them myself

[19:25:01.0000] <nessy>
in an appropriate manner to my custom interface

[19:26:00.0000] <Hixie>
wouldn't that just be a metadata track?

[19:26:01.0000] <nessy>
as for state (2) on metadata - indeed there would not be a UA default display for metadata - the state is still valid, though, it's just an empty display

[19:26:02.0000] <nessy>
no, it's still subtitles

[19:26:03.0000] <Hixie>
hmm

[19:26:04.0000] <Hixie>
i'll have to think on this some more

[19:26:05.0000] <Hixie>
gotta go for dinner now though

[19:27:00.0000] <Hixie>

[19:27:01.0000] <nessy>

[00:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:54:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[00:54:01.0000] <annevk>

[00:54:02.0000] <TabAtkins__>

[00:54:03.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:54:04.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:54:05.0000] <zcorpan>
same reason microdata attributes share the same prefix

[00:55:00.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: people are interested in making complete WebKit DOM bindings for other languages such as Objective-C or Python

[00:55:01.0000] <othermaciej>
not to run inside Web pages, but rather so that an app using WebKit can exercise the full power of the Web platform without having to go through JavaScript

[00:55:02.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: also, new Image() is just a shortcut, it doesn't provide a genuine new capability

[00:56:00.0000] <othermaciej>
you could always createElement("img") and then set its src attribute by hand

[00:57:00.0000] <annevk>

[00:57:01.0000] <annevk>

[00:58:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:58:01.0000] <othermaciej>
that would work for any language that can support constructors at all (which is pretty much any language of interest I think)

[00:59:00.0000] <annevk>

[00:59:01.0000] <annevk>

[00:59:02.0000] <zcorpan>

[00:59:03.0000] <zcorpan>

[01:00:00.0000] <annevk>

[01:00:01.0000] <annevk>

[01:01:00.0000] <annevk>

[01:03:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:04:00.0000] <annevk>

[01:05:00.0000] <annevk>
the XHR in a sandboxed iframe scenario can be implemented by a simple library and requires no cooperation

[01:07:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:08:00.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: a change in behavior could be represented as a mode flag instead of a subclass, but since there is a separate constructor anyway, it may as well be a subclass

[01:09:00.0000] <annevk>

[04:42:00.0000] <Lachy>

[04:42:01.0000] <Lachy>

[10:18:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[10:18:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's well-established; partial contact does the trick.

[10:19:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Partial contact is not a reasonable assumption

[10:19:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Once a zombie has contact with a brain, it has no reason to stop consuming

[10:19:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
With a brain, sure.  Once you hit that point, it's likely that you're fully disabled and at the nonexistent mercy of the undead.

[10:20:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'm talking about a conflict where the living sustains a bite or scratch, but is then able to escape.

[10:20:01.0000] <Dashiva>
This is, however, a minority situation

[10:20:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
I disagree.  Zombies are slow enough that, until you get swarm situations, most physical contact is escapable.

[10:21:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
You're also discounting the original infection point, which may create a large pool of zombies to start with.

[10:21:01.0000] <Dashiva>
There's your swarm

[10:21:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Furthermore, escape is only an option if there is somewhere to escape to

[10:22:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Not necessarily.  The initial group will, by default, spread out.  Swarms occur when a large number are all focused on a relatively small number of targets.

[10:23:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
If the zombification event hits everyone in an area, there are no immediate targets.  If it doesn't, there are likely a number of targets, which will flee in multiple directions and spread the initial swarm as well.

[10:24:00.0000] <Philip`>
Dashiva: You can escape to the Big Brother house

[10:24:01.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: So, what are you doing with the test suite stuff?

[10:24:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Philip`: That's a fate worse than (un)death

[10:24:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
gsnedders: Writing a new end-to-end harness for testing, which will swallow all the existing test suites and be runnable automatically in all browsers.

[10:25:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
At least, that's the eventual goal, and what I'm being paid for.

[10:25:01.0000] <Dashiva>
TabAtkins: That may hold for the very beginning, but secondary infections will have easy access to victims who trust them and expect nothing.

[10:26:00.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: For all tests, or just JS ones?

[10:26:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Dashiva: The hunger doesn't come until zombification does, at which point victims will know something is off.  Some will still succumb, unbelieving that their loved one has joined the army of darkness, but many will escape after an initial contact, possibly gaining an infected injury and eventually zombifying themselves.

[10:27:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
gsnedders: All tests.

[10:27:01.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: So how are you dealing with visual tests?

[10:27:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
gsnedders: At the moment, we're shooting for the reftest format.  Future improvements may allow further expansion in this area.

[10:27:03.0000] <Dashiva>
Zombification is not easily distinguishable from illness, which on the contrary would draw people closer to provide care

[10:28:00.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: And how do you do the screenshots?

[10:28:01.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: In a cross-platform, cross-browser way?

[10:28:02.0000] <Dashiva>
(Perhaps we've gone far enough for now)

[10:28:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
gsnedders: That's the trick, right?

[10:28:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
The answer is "We'll figure it out when we get there."

[10:29:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
But ideas are circling around a screenshot api for yanking pixels from a section of the screen.

[10:29:01.0000] <Philip`>
Is it possible to make a test harness that is powerful enough to swallow all the existing test suites, but still simple enough that people will be willing to use it and write new tests for it?

[10:29:02.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: heh

[10:30:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[14:36:00.0000] <jgraham>

[14:37:01.0000] <jgraham>
