[14:42:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
In 3 months I'll have an alpha that works from start to finish, though the actual pass/fail part will be manual.  After that I'll begin working on the automatic testing part.

[14:42:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Now I'm actually gone.

[14:43:00.0000] <jgraham>
Now I'm actually confused about what your plan is

[14:44:00.0000] <jgraham>
I guess for CSS tests it makes some sort of sense to have manual pass/fail

[14:44:01.0000] <jgraham>
For dom tests it makes no sense whatsoever

[14:45:00.0000] <jgraham>
to the extent that I don't see why you would design the system with "manual pass/fail" as an incremental step

[14:49:00.0000] <jgraham>
TabAtkins: You are working in the open, right? Is there any chance of an email to some list outlining your exact plans at some point?

[14:50:00.0000] <Philip`>
What does a test harness that doesn't detect pass/fail actually do?

[14:51:00.0000] <Philip`>
That seems like the most important part of it

[14:51:01.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: Presumably it loads tests and has a UI for a human to say whether they passes/failed

[14:52:00.0000] <jgraham>
For tests of rendering it makes some sense but it doesn't scale

[14:53:00.0000] <jgraham>
So you either have to do screenshots and mark pass/fail each time you get a new result or reftests

[14:53:01.0000] <jgraham>
and reftests are much less fragile

[14:55:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: Wouldn't that just be something like an HTML file with a list of links to each test case, and maybe some iframes, and a dozen lines of CGI script to save and display the human-entered results?

[14:56:00.0000] <Philip`>
I'd assume it must be doing something amazingly fancier if it'll take three months of work :-)

[14:57:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: The W3 testrunner thing as it currently stands has a webserver to provide the tests and a database for recording results

[14:58:00.0000] <jgraham>
Depending on the scope of the tests you might want the ability to significantly customise the server on a per-test basis (for HTTP testing)

[14:58:01.0000] <jgraham>
You might also want, say, a websockets server

[14:58:02.0000] <jgraham>
So, depending on the scope of the project, one can imagine a lot in infrastructure

[14:59:00.0000] <jgraham>
s/in/of/

[16:12:00.0000] <Hixie>
hm

[16:12:01.0000] <Hixie>
cross-origin timed tracks are going to be an issue

[16:28:00.0000] <nessy>
Hixie: yeah - hsivonen suggested iframe-like solution for that

[16:41:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
jgraham: Yeah, I'm in the open, and I can put a mail to the list.

[16:42:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
jgraham: Manual pass/fail is the first step because, frankly, that's the easiest thing to do.  Building it as a testing module, and then building additional modules that work automatically, enable me to get a verifiably working design quicker.

[16:42:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Basically it's the simplest thing that works.

[16:43:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Philip`: It doesn't take 3 months of work, it takes 3 months of my time, alongside all the other things I'm doing.  ^_^

[16:44:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Suffice to say, though, that I'm not coming up with this stuff myself - arronei and fantasai, in charge of the CSS test suite, are basically codevelopers with me, and I've talked with plh as well about it.

[18:26:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Summary of RDFa 1.1: A ridiculously verbose way of expressing identical metadata relationships as Microdata.  With datatypes.

[18:28:00.0000] <Hixie>
TabAtkins: that's not really fair, rdfa does way more than microdata. For example it does per-field typing, and supports XML literals.

[18:28:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I said per-field typing.  ^_^  XML literals is indeed something it has over Microdata.

[18:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
and it has full CURIE support

[18:29:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's not a benefit.

[18:29:02.0000] <Hixie>
oh

[18:29:03.0000] <Hixie>
well i'm sure it can be sold as a benefit

[18:29:04.0000] <Hixie>
does microdata do CURIES? I think not!

[18:29:05.0000] <Hixie>
clearly microdata is inferior

[18:29:06.0000] <TabAtkins>
Microdata does CURIES via an implicit @vocab mechanism.

[18:30:00.0000] <Hixie>
i have no idea what that means but it sounds good, i like it

[18:31:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
@vocab is just RDFa1.1's way of making you not need to use prefixes.  Any property nested in the @vocab element that doesn't have a prefix uses the @vocab value as its prefix.

[18:31:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Alternately: the mechanism isn't implicit, but it's covered by @itemtype.

[18:31:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Which I think is actually more accurate.

[18:33:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The RDFa 1.1 spec doesn't do a great job of explaining what all the attributes do.  It took some hunting to discover that @typeof and @datatype are the same thing, with the former for the triple-subject and the latter for the triple-object.

[18:33:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Also: chaining is a bad, confusing idea and I hate it.

[18:37:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Additionally: very confused about why/how @src is always a subject, never an object, but @href is always an object, never a subject.

[18:38:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's not true.  @src can be an object too, at the same time as it's functioning as a subject and a scoping indicator.

[18:41:03.0000] <Hixie>
/me is wondering what to do about positioning captions

[18:41:04.0000] <Hixie>
considering just the horizontal dimension for now

[18:42:00.0000] <Hixie>
there are three variables for a cue:

[18:42:01.0000] <Hixie>
horizontal position, size of the box, and the alignment of the text within the box

[18:42:02.0000] <Hixie>
http://docs.google.com/drawings/edit?id=1LXroDh1tSee1YM79toEMo6OEdlI2Du5EfoWt7mSmc8U&hl=en

[18:43:00.0000] <Hixie>
there's two ways i can think of doing this: either aligning the alignment edge to the given horizontal position, or

[18:43:01.0000] <Hixie>
aligning the point along the box in the horizontal dimension that is the given distance along the box as a fraction of the box width to the equivalent position on the video as a fraction of the video width

[18:43:02.0000] <Hixie>
the latter works really well if the width is known ahead of time and is not 100%

[18:44:00.0000] <Hixie>
the former works really well if the horizontal position is less than 75% or so

[18:44:01.0000] <Hixie>
the latter makes the position irrelevant if the width is 100% though

[18:44:02.0000] <nessy>
/me is just going through email and reached the public-html thread ;)

[18:45:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'm confused about how the last box in the second example works.

[18:45:01.0000] <Hixie>
and the former fails dramatically for the case of the position being 100%

[18:45:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Omitted size implies 100%, and thus ignores H?

[18:45:03.0000] <Hixie>
TabAtkins: the point 50% along the way of the box is aligned to the point 50% along the video

[18:45:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Oh, duh, got it.

[18:45:05.0000] <Hixie>
TabAtkins: it's just that since the dimension is 100% (presumably, by default), that is indistinguishable to any other position

[18:46:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I like that usage.  It's very natural in CSS backgrounds.

[18:46:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah but it totally makes the position useless if the width is not known

[18:46:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's as bad as the last case in the first box

[18:46:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Unless you introduce some concept of "shrinkwrap" for width.

[18:46:04.0000] <nessy>
for the positioning and styling stuff, can't we use CSS directly?

[18:46:05.0000] <Hixie>
TabAtkins: if we do that, then each cue would align differently

[18:47:00.0000] <Hixie>
nessy: CSS doesn't have the magic avoidance we need to add for titles to avoid the overlapping titles issue

[18:47:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes?  So either you do a definite size, or just deal with it.

[18:47:02.0000] <Hixie>
TabAtkins: i'd rather the default was pretty :-)

[18:47:03.0000] <nessy>
hmmm…

[18:47:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
I don't really have an opinion on whether it's better to shrinkwrap or just expand to full width.

[18:47:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
The latter seems like it would be fine, personally.

[18:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
maybe the default should be to do absolute positions, except if you set a width, then it does the second case...

[18:48:01.0000] <Hixie>
though then you still have the other problem...

[18:48:02.0000] <Hixie>
i guess the question is

[18:48:03.0000] <Hixie>
what should happen if you say a left-aligned box is at position 100% horizontally?

[18:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
does that even make sense?

[18:49:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's why always doing the latter is best.

[18:49:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
So that situation actually produces something good - a right-aligned box.

[18:49:03.0000] <Hixie>
always doing the latter works fine except when width is automatic, then it's counterintuitive or ugly depending on how we do it

[18:50:00.0000] <Hixie>
no, it produces a left-aligned box that is the full width of the screen :-)

[18:50:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
If the width is auto positioning it doesn't make sense, given our requirement that it shouldn't go out of the screen.

[18:50:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
At least, horiz positioning it doesn't.

[18:50:03.0000] <Hixie>
if the size of the box is 100%, and we use the case-2 alignment mechanism, then the position has no effect

[18:50:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes.

[18:50:05.0000] <Hixie>
yeah maybe that's the answer... if it has no width, then ignore the horizontal positioning

[19:10:00.0000] <Hixie>

[19:13:00.0000] <Hixie>

[19:13:01.0000] <nessy>

[19:13:02.0000] <nessy>

[19:13:03.0000] <nessy>
to authore

[19:14:00.0000] <Hixie>

[19:14:01.0000] <Hixie>

[19:14:03.0000] <Hixie>

[19:14:04.0000] <Hixie>

[19:16:00.0000] <nessy>

[19:17:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's more complicated than that because of having to deal with which direction the box grows in when it's multiple lines long

[19:18:00.0000] <nessy>

[19:20:00.0000] <nessy>

[19:20:01.0000] <nessy>
I would think

[19:21:00.0000] <Hixie>
i don't mean the block-progression-direction, i mean where the box is anchored. Consider http://philip.html5.org/misc/eva-captions.jpg -- if the top caption were one line long, it would be at the top, but if the bottom caption were one line long, it would be at the bottom.

[19:21:01.0000] <Hixie>
they grow in different directions

[19:21:02.0000] <Hixie>

[19:21:03.0000] <Hixie>
too

[19:22:00.0000] <Hixie>

[19:23:00.0000] <Hixie>
you wouldn't want the author to have to worry about this for each cue, so you really want good defaults so that just throwing the caption to the top or the bottom gets the right effect

[19:23:01.0000] <Hixie>

[20:29:00.0000] <Bolkonskij>
hi

[22:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
a lot of the discussion in public-html-a11y about timed tracks has assumed that subtitles are mutually exclusive... why is that?

[22:29:01.0000] <Hixie>
wouldn't that just be a UI decision?

[22:30:00.0000] <Hixie>
foolip: you were in that discussion a lot... any idea?

[22:31:00.0000] <micheil>
Hixie: I've been thinking about some websockets stuff, and have a bit of an idea.. wanted to run it past you if you had a moment?

[22:31:01.0000] <Hixie>
sure

[22:32:00.0000] <micheil>
okay, currently with websockets, they are a two way channel, however, what happens in the case where a websocket server is only interested in streaming data down to a client?

[22:32:01.0000] <micheil>
would it make sense to add an extra (optional) headers which allowed you to specific (from the server) whether the connection was to be a ReadOnly connection?

[22:33:00.0000] <micheil>
(alternatively, you may also wish to implement a writeOnly, but I can't see a use case for that)

[22:33:01.0000] <Hixie>
you define the protocol that runs over websocket, so you could just define your protocol such that there is nothing the client is allowed to say, and the server can just ignore everything the client sends

[22:33:02.0000] <micheil>
by default, websockets would assume that they are both Read and Write, unless this is set

[22:34:00.0000] <micheil>
true, although, would it not be a good idea to give the client some indication of this?

[22:34:01.0000] <micheil>
I'm thinking in a more generic sense, rather then at the subprotocol level

[22:35:00.0000] <micheil>
this flag would have no effect on the readyState of the connection.

[22:35:01.0000] <Hixie>
well it's not like the client is a random client, the client is you

[22:36:00.0000] <Hixie>
i mean, you're not going to be talking to random pages, you're only talking to people who know what your protocol is

[22:36:01.0000] <Hixie>
so they know your protocol is "read only", because that's why they're connecting to you

[22:37:00.0000] <micheil>

[22:37:01.0000] <micheil>

[22:40:01.0000] <Hixie>

[23:26:00.0000] <aboodman>
abarth: hey, i was wondering something about cors

[23:26:01.0000] <aboodman>

[23:27:00.0000] <othermaciej>
aboodman: no (unless intranet resources are in the habit of adding Access-Control-Allow-Origin headers randomly)

[23:27:01.0000] <abarth>
aboodman: that's one of the threats CORS tries to address

[23:27:02.0000] <abarth>
aboodman: do you have something speific you're worried about?

[23:27:03.0000] <othermaciej>
aboodman: in theory it *can* violate integrity (as opposed to confidentiality) of intranet resources, but only in the same ways forms already can

[23:27:04.0000] <aboodman>
right cors, requires that existing servers respond with a special header.

[23:27:05.0000] <aboodman>
even for GET.

[23:27:06.0000] <abarth>
yes

[23:27:07.0000] <aboodman>

[23:29:00.0000] <aboodman>

[23:29:01.0000] <abarth>

[23:29:02.0000] <aboodman>
that is, would not sending credentials be sufficient.

[23:29:03.0000] <abarth>

[23:29:04.0000] <othermaciej>

[23:29:05.0000] <abarth>
you can't avoid sending credentials

[23:29:06.0000] <abarth>
for example, proxy-auth credentials

[23:29:07.0000] <abarth>

[23:29:08.0000] <othermaciej>
"intranet" is a shorthand for a broad category

[23:30:00.0000] <abarth>

[23:30:01.0000] <abarth>
does that count as an intranet?

[23:30:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[23:30:03.0000] <aboodman>
othermaciej: ok, that shorthand is fine.

[23:30:04.0000] <othermaciej>

[23:30:05.0000] <aboodman>
intranet => any resource you have access to by virtue of network position

[23:30:06.0000] <abarth>

[23:31:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[23:31:01.0000] <abarth>

[23:31:02.0000] <abarth>

[23:31:03.0000] <othermaciej>
aboodman: many home routers are reconfigurable via http from the local network segment

[23:31:04.0000] <othermaciej>
aboodman: in many cases this is encoded in firmware that can't readily be upgraded

[23:31:05.0000] <aboodman>
i guess i'm asking: are there other forms of ambient authority that the browser does not control, other than client IP address.

[23:31:06.0000] <othermaciej>
so "if the intranet issue didn't exist" is a rather huge counter-factual

[23:32:00.0000] <aboodman>

[23:32:01.0000] <aboodman>

[23:32:02.0000] <othermaciej>
the IP address and the routes

[23:32:03.0000] <othermaciej>
for example, I have access to systems on net 17 right now

[23:32:04.0000] <othermaciej>
but my IP address is not on net 17

[23:32:05.0000] <othermaciej>
because I have a VPN tunnel

[23:33:00.0000] <othermaciej>
random attackers cannot send packets to machines behind Apple's firewall even if they can send packets to me

[23:33:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it's a matter of network topology, not just IP address

[23:33:02.0000] <aboodman>

[23:34:03.0000] <abarth>

[23:35:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[23:35:02.0000] <othermaciej>
aboodman: the CORS vs UMP debate is really about whether it is ever ok to send user and originating site credentials in a cross-site request

[23:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
the ObjCap people say no, because ambient authority is bad, end of story

[23:36:01.0000] <othermaciej>
others (e.g. me) would say, but the Web security model is already based on origins, so we may as well go with the flow in the soundest way we can instead of trying to fight it

[23:36:02.0000] <othermaciej>
and CORS makes it easier to code many common access patterns securely, notwithstanding theory

[23:37:00.0000] <Hixie>
imho UMP might make sense but only if you revamp the way the web works first

[23:37:01.0000] <aboodman>

[23:49:01.0000] <abarth>
IP address canonicalization seems to break down as Safari+Firefox versus Chrome+IE

[23:49:02.0000] <abarth>
IE likes to canonicalize whereas FF doesn't

[23:50:00.0000] <abarth>
canonicalize('http://000030052000001/') is 'http://192.168.0.1/' IE

[23:50:01.0000] <abarth>
canonicalize('http://000030052000001/') is 'http://192.168.0.1/' KR

[23:50:02.0000] <abarth>
canonicalize('http://000030052000001/') should be http://192.168.0.1/. Was http://000030052000001/. FF

[23:50:03.0000] <abarth>
canonicalize('http://000030052000001/') should be http://192.168.0.1/. Was http://000030052000001/. SA

[23:50:04.0000] <abarth>
as a random example

[23:50:05.0000] <othermaciej>
are there any reasons besides matching one browser or the other to caniicalize or not?

[23:50:06.0000] <Hixie>
abarth: iirc it is considered a security-wise dubious thing to support non-dotted-quad ipv4 addresses

[23:50:07.0000] <Hixie>
abarth: and it is certainly not kosher per the rfc iirc

[23:51:00.0000] <abarth>
what does "support" mean?

[23:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
convert to anything or resolve as an IP address

[23:51:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[23:51:03.0000] <abarth>

[23:51:04.0000] <othermaciej>
er

[23:51:05.0000] <othermaciej>
URLs

[23:52:00.0000] <Hixie>

[23:52:01.0000] <Hixie>
to start with, pure-numeric labels are valid dns labels

[23:52:02.0000] <Hixie>
so you could have a local machine in dns with the name "000030052000001" if i'm not mistaken

[23:53:00.0000] <Hixie>
(e.g. www.000.com. resolves)

[23:53:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[23:53:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[23:53:03.0000] <Hixie>
000.com and 123.com are both registered

[23:53:04.0000] <Hixie>
so...

[00:31:02.0000] <abarth>
KR canonicalize('http://example.com/foo%41%7a') is 'http://example.com/fooAz'

[00:31:03.0000] <abarth>
FF canonicalize('http://example.com/foo%41%7a') should be http://example.com/fooAz. Was http://example.com/foo%41%7a.

[00:31:04.0000] <abarth>
SA canonicalize('http://example.com/foo%41%7a') should be http://example.com/fooAz. Was http://example.com/foo%41%7a.

[00:31:05.0000] <abarth>
the question here is whether you URL decode things that don't need to be encoded

[00:31:06.0000] <othermaciej>
yeah

[00:31:07.0000] <othermaciej>
Brett really likes IE's URL parsing I guess :-)

[00:32:00.0000] <abarth>
IE likes to keep non-ASCII characters in URLs

[00:33:00.0000] <abarth>
brett seems to follow firefox + safari in making things more ascii more of the time

[00:33:01.0000] <abarth>
FF canonicalize('http://example.com/你好你好') is 'http://example.com/%E4%BD%A0%E5%A5%BD%E4%BD%A0%E5%A5%BD'

[00:33:02.0000] <abarth>
KR canonicalize('http://example.com/你好你好') is 'http://example.com/%E4%BD%A0%E5%A5%BD%E4%BD%A0%E5%A5%BD'

[00:33:03.0000] <abarth>
SA canonicalize('http://example.com/你好你好') is 'http://example.com/%E4%BD%A0%E5%A5%BD%E4%BD%A0%E5%A5%BD'

[00:33:04.0000] <abarth>
IE canonicalize('http://example.com/你好你好') should be http://example.com/%E4%BD%A0%E5%A5%BD%E4%BD%A0%E5%A5%BD. Was http://example.com/你好你好.

[00:33:05.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:43:00.0000] <foolip>
Hixie: mutually exclusive subtitles: this is the way virtually all software and hardware media players work. it seems useful to be able to mark up that certain tracks are mutually exclusive (<tracktrack>) so that the UI can create a sane menu.

[01:44:00.0000] <hsivonen>
having multiple subtitle tracks present at one time seems to be on the wrong side of 80/20

[01:44:01.0000] <foolip>
the other options are to make all tracks mutually exlcusive or all tracks "parallel", both of which are broken

[01:44:02.0000] <hsivonen>
if you want to make English subtitles plus Japanese subtitles for language learners for anime, you can package them into one track

[01:45:00.0000] <foolip>
hsivonen: I agree, but others (nessy) insisted, and I think the current solution is fairly non-intrusive

[01:45:01.0000] <hsivonen>
FWIW, in movie theaters in Finland, there are subtitles in Finnish and in Swedish, but they aren't independent tracks

[01:45:02.0000] <hsivonen>
specifically, the Swedish subtitles aren't bought from Sweden

[01:45:03.0000] <asmodai>

[01:45:04.0000] <nessy>

[01:45:05.0000] <foolip>

[01:46:01.0000] <nessy>
 then you cannot turn one off

[01:46:05.0000] <nessy>

[02:50:00.0000] <foolip>
SRT files often have overlapping times by mistake, because most (all?) player fix it during parsing

[02:50:01.0000] <nessy>
also about having multiple media resources in sync: I think you need both - (1) the dependent ones like audio descriptions whose timeline is totally dependent on the main timeline - they would go into <track>  - (2) the compositions of multiple media resources that may build a multimedia experience of sorts - they would be linked on the full <audio>/<video> level

[02:51:00.0000] <nessy>
foolip: players don't "fix" it - they just remove the old element when the new one appears

[02:51:01.0000] <foolip>
nessy: internally syncing them is the same think regardless of the syntax, so I think it's mostly a question of picking a syntax which makes sense

[02:51:02.0000] <nessy>
with srt that's the only thing you can do because they would be rendered in the same place

[02:52:00.0000] <asmodai>
hsivonen: Was going to try that now.

[02:52:01.0000] <foolip>
nessy: in any event the overlapping is concealed, so SRT files have overlap which wasn't intended as such by the author

[02:53:00.0000] <nessy>
the internal mechanism is only the same for some of it - e.g. if a dependent media resource is longer its overlength will never be played - if a synchronised media resource is longer, it will continue playing

[05:01:00.0000] <remysharp>
Re: canvas 2d api - toDataURL and the second optional argument, compression level - between 0.0 and 1.  Is 1 highest compression or 1 being biggest sized file?

[05:03:00.0000] <gsnedders>
It's only supported for image/jpeg

[05:03:01.0000] <gsnedders>
And 1 is the highest quality, and hence biggest file

[05:03:02.0000] <Philip`>
"The second argument, if it is a number in the range 0.0 to 1.0 inclusive, must be treated as the desired quality level."

[05:10:01.0000] <remysharp>
out of interest, does the quality actually affect the size of the base64 data. I'm assuming it does, but I don't know much about the encoding techniques

[05:12:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: No

[05:12:01.0000] <Philip`>
See e.g. http://philip.html5.org/tests/canvas/suite/tests/toDataURL.jpeg.quality.outsiderange.html and modify the last test

[05:13:00.0000] <Philip`>
(assuming the behaviour hasn't changed since the Opera I'm using)

[05:13:01.0000] <Philip`>
(which looks like 10.10)

[05:14:00.0000] <Philip`>
remysharp: Yes - base64 just does 4 bytes of output for each 3 bytes of input

[05:14:01.0000] <Philip`>
so if the input changes by 3 or more bytes then the output will definitely change length

[05:14:02.0000] <remysharp>
okay, cheers.

[08:06:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: "then you should include the BOM indicating UTF-16LE"

[08:07:00.0000] <hsivonen>
UTF-16LE is BOMless

[08:07:01.0000] <hsivonen>
the BOM indicates little-endian UTF-16

[08:07:02.0000] <gsnedders>
A leading U+FEFF is a ZWNBSP

[08:07:03.0000] <gsnedders>
(in UTF-16LE, UTF-16BE, UTF-32LE, UTF-32BE, etc.)

[08:07:04.0000] <hsivonen>
right

[08:08:00.0000] <gsnedders>
(it only isn't in UTF-8 because the spec specifically allows it, but assigns no meaning to it)

[08:08:01.0000] <Lachy>
I was using that as shorthand for indicating little-endian or big-endian, as indiciated by the BOM

[08:08:02.0000] <jgraham>

[08:08:03.0000] <hsivonen>

[08:10:02.0000] <Lachy>

[08:11:00.0000] <jgraham>

[08:54:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[08:55:00.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: a couple of years ago, I measured wikipedia pages re-encoded in various ways

[08:55:01.0000] <hsivonen>
summary: gzipped UTF-8 is so good that everything else is pointless

[08:57:00.0000] <jgraham>

[08:58:00.0000] <jgraham>

[08:58:01.0000] <jgraham>

[09:06:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[09:10:00.0000] <jgraham>
hsivonen: I think it would be great to blog any numbers that you have left over from that study

[09:15:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Perhaps if we talk about it enough, Philip` will make a service that takes a URL and outputs how big the page would be with different encodings and transfer options

[09:16:00.0000] <Philip`>
Surely you can do that with a single line of shell code

[09:16:01.0000] <Philip`>
using curl and iconv and gzip and wc and some loops

[09:22:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Philip`: Pretend this line is reverse psychology tricking you into making it to prove it's really possible in one line

[09:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
wget http://www.gutenberg.org/files/31757/31757-h/31757-h.htm; perl -e'for$c(qw(utf-8 utf-16be utf-16le utf-32 euc-jp shift-jis)){for$g(" ","|gzip -c"){print "$c$g ".`iconv -c 31757-h.htm -f utf-8 -t $c$g|wc -c`}}'

[09:33:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Accepted

[09:35:00.0000] <Philip`>
Interestingly the results are far tighter (and better) if you use bzip2

[09:35:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Is the default gzip compression level a reasonable assumption?

[09:38:00.0000] <Philip`>
Yes

[09:38:01.0000] <Philip`>
Don't know if it's a correct assumption, though

[09:38:02.0000] <Philip`>
Strangely, xz (LZMA) is slightly worse than bzip2 here

[09:42:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Not much difference with maximum compression on gzip anyhow

[09:44:00.0000] <Philip`>
You can save ~7% over gzip -9 by using 7z's gzip implementation

[09:46:00.0000] <Philip`>
(...though you wouldn't do that dynamically on a web server because it's way too slow)

[09:47:00.0000] <Philip`>
(but it's good whenever you're precomputing compressed files)

[09:55:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Heyo!

[09:57:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Philip`: But it doesn't seem to change the relative ranking of the methods

[09:57:01.0000] <Dashiva>
That's the most important thing, I think

[10:06:00.0000] <Philip`>
Dashiva: The most important thing is the size of the output, since the author's goal is to minimise that

[10:06:01.0000] <Philip`>
and if using a better compression implementation gives you a larger percentage gain than changing the charset, it's probably better for people to focus on the former before worrying too much about the latter

[10:08:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Compression is a different trade-off, though, since it also requires resources to (de)compress

[10:08:01.0000] <Philip`>
I guess so

[10:08:02.0000] <Philip`>
It's more complex to changing the compression code and to make it cached so it goes fast etc

[10:09:00.0000] <Philip`>
so maybe it's better to do dumb stuff like recompress static files on every single request, and make easy changes like reencoding the static file

[10:10:00.0000] <Dashiva>
But of course, in the end it's the size in actual bytes that matters

[10:11:00.0000] <Philip`>
Most compression algorithms seem to be designed to maximise resource usage on compression and minimise on decompression

[10:12:00.0000] <Philip`>
(e.g. LZMA can happily use 1GB RAM to compress, and a tenth of that for decompression)

[10:13:00.0000] <Philip`>
which seems precisely the wrong way around when you're doing compression on a single centralised server, and decompression on a thousand fast unutilised desktop PCs simultaneously

[10:25:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, the server can cache the compressed files.

[10:25:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Assuming they're more or less static.

[15:57:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
"From the current state of the discussion, it seems like removing Atom conversion would draw the weakest objections."

[15:57:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It seems like removing things always draws the weakest objections.  Let's just put everything controversial in the WHATWG spec only so that W3C change proposals can't affect it.  Is that what people want?

[15:57:02.0000] <Dashiva>

[15:58:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[15:58:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[15:58:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Actually, no, that's what anyone wants.  Some people want things removed from the WHATWG spec too.  They just can't get that.

[15:58:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Maybe they figure that even if they can't get it removed from the WHATWG spec, at least they can remove it from the W3C spec, and that will make people less likely to see it?

[15:59:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Of course, the more this happens, the less useful the W3C spec becomes, and the more people will use the WHATWG spec.

[15:59:01.0000] <Dashiva>
You can also see it as a PR battle, creating division between W3C and WHATWG

[16:01:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
The W3C has a more positive reputation than the WHATWG, certainly.  Much better known, too.

[16:02:00.0000] <Dashiva>
It's also likely that since the WHATWG copy exists, people have less incentive to fight to preserve the W3C copy

[16:02:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's true too.

[16:02:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Fragmentation is often the easiest option, although rarely the best.

[16:03:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
See also microdata vs. RDFa.  If we knew in advance that only one could exist, whichever one we had would probably be better than either of the two contenders now.

[16:03:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
But instead, everyone who likes one of them just ignores the other rather than trying to fix its deficiencies.

[16:05:00.0000] <Dashiva>
To be fair, RDFa seems to be absorbing some of the good ideas of microdata. It just doesn't seem as willing to part with the bad ideas.

[16:05:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: Fwiw, I've done a relatively thorough and open review of RDFa 1.1.  I think it's unfixable at this point, though.  They just made some initial architectural mistakes and have dug themselves down far enough in an attempt to reduce their impact that you can't "fix" it without substantially rewriting it.

[16:06:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The basic failure is not paying enough attention to the tree-based structure of XML, and relying on a notion of implicit subjects, rather than declaring subjects more explicitly.

[16:07:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Then they made it worse by trying to be clever with the chaining concept.

[16:07:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Bah, someone complained about this wording!  http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=7277

[16:08:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I appreciated that wording when I started reading the spec.

[16:08:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
The whole prefix/curie thing is pretty much a non-issue at this point.  1.1's @vocab and @profile attributes successfully hide the complexity in common cases.

[16:10:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Basically, chapter 8 of RDFa1.1 speaks for itself about why the basic RDFa architecture is a mistake.

[16:11:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
It has like 60 examples, possibly more, walking through several things step-by-step because otherwise it's impossible to decipher.

[16:12:00.0000] <Hixie>
TabAtkins: complexity can't be hidden unless it's gone from the syntax altogether, because people have to maintain other people's code, and the other person might use the feature that's complicated

[16:13:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
True.  It's at least lessened.  Using @vocab *looks* like Microdata with @itemtype on simple cases.

[16:13:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
. . . of course, you could say the same about HTML.  But I guess you'd say that there are few enough RDFa agents that we care about that we can break compatibility anyway.

[16:14:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: Exactly.

[16:14:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or, more importantly, few enough RDFa pages.

[16:14:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Since a few implementations can be changed pretty easily.

[16:15:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Once I finish setting up my workflow, I might spend a few hours hacking our Rich Snippets support to ensure that it works with Microdata properly.

[16:15:01.0000] <Dashiva>
It seems to be some of the same people saying we can ignore deployed HTML5 content because it's not a standard yet who proclaim existing RDFa-in-HTML content must be supported

[16:15:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Those people don't have a point, they're just inconsistent due to their agenda.

[16:16:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me tried to rewrite that to reverse the roles, but it didn't work

[16:16:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: Yay!  That's how you know it's true.

[16:16:02.0000] <Dashiva>
I'm sure you can reverse it

[16:16:03.0000] <Dashiva>
You just need to apply a secondary measure

[16:16:04.0000] <Dashiva>
E.g. we can't ignore [massively] deployed HTML5 content, but we can ignore [small amounts of] RDFa-in-HTML

[16:17:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, we ignore deployed RDFa+HTML content because there's not a lot of it, but there's a lot of HTML content, so it seems consistent.  I'd need to be more creative.

[16:17:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Indeed, but if you apply that measure with the original statement, it becomes obviously ridiculous.

[16:17:02.0000] <Dashiva>
It seems obvious, but I'm not sure it's necessarily so

[16:17:03.0000] <Dashiva>
e.g. if you take the claims that blog software ships with it enabled by default, and doing something useful by default

[16:18:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Most blog software also outputs HTML.

[16:18:01.0000] <Dashiva>
I personally don't think anyone would notice even if it was deployed by default, but I don't have the data to back it up

[16:19:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I think WHATWG people tend to only really care about browsers (and maybe search engines and feed readers and such), while the specific technology is usually more or less of secondary interest.  The RDFa people seem to be more invested in a particular technology than in a particular high-level goal.

[16:19:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
The same is true for lots of people who disagree with WHATWG people, actually.

[16:19:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
That technology is "namespaces", for RDFa.

[16:20:00.0000] <Dashiva>
And RDF ;)

[16:21:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
RDF's not necessarily a problem.  You could parse RDFa data into JSON with roughly the same ease as you parse Microdata into RDF.

[16:21:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Is there anything wrong with RDF, or just RDFa?

[16:21:02.0000] <othermaciej>
RDF as a data model

[16:21:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
RDF is just a rolled-out version of tree-based data.

[16:21:04.0000] <othermaciej>
?

[16:21:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
With a focus on URIs.

[16:21:06.0000] <othermaciej>
RDF is not tree-based data, it is graph-based

[16:22:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Not necessarily wrong, but coming from a graph structure and designing for a tree is tricky

[16:22:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Graphs should be the exception, trees the norm

[16:23:00.0000] <Dashiva>
But if you come from a world where everything is graphs, it can be hard to adapt

[16:23:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
All trees are graphs, and they're more common in real data, so I still think my gloss is mostly accurate.

[16:23:02.0000] <erlehmann>
I like graphs.

[16:23:03.0000] <Dashiva>
TabAtkins: It's a graph in total, but each page usually only contains a tree-like subgraph

[16:23:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Dashiva: Right, that's what I tried to say, but failed to do so clearly.

[16:24:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Thanks for the clarification.  ^_^

[16:25:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
So anyway, that's why RDFa's essential architecture is wrong.  It didn't take full advantage of the parallel between most data's tree-nature and HT/XML's tree-like nature.

[16:26:00.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: all trees are directed graphs, but not vice versa

[16:26:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
othermaciej: That's what I said, isn't it?

[16:26:02.0000] <othermaciej>
earlier you said "RDF is just a rolled-out version of tree-based data."

[16:26:03.0000] <othermaciej>
maybe I misinterpreted that statement

[16:27:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Right, I left out some details that Dashiva corrected me on.

[16:27:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
In a hand-wavey way, I mean that the RDF structure of data embedded in pages is typically a tree, or at least very tree-like.

[16:27:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I agree that a lot of interesting data can be expressed well enough with a tree, rather than a general directed graph

[16:28:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I suspect a lot of RDFa at least points to common objects and so is likely at least a DAG

[16:28:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Yeah, I should have said DAG instead of tree. Even microdata is like that.

[16:29:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah.

[16:29:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Microdata is a DAG?

[16:29:02.0000] <Dashiva>
With itemref

[16:29:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
And, in a larger sense, with itemid.

[16:29:04.0000] <othermaciej>
itemref just clones some properties though

[16:30:00.0000] <othermaciej>
does the actual Microdata model retain a DAG structure?

[16:30:01.0000] <othermaciej>
are you pointing to the same conceptual object, or do you just happen to have properties with the same values?

[16:30:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
No, it serializes as a tree.

[16:30:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
But, if you lean on urls as values, it retains exactly as much DAGness as RDF would.

[16:33:00.0000] <Hixie>
RDF isn't natively a graph at all, it's a list of triples

[16:33:01.0000] <Hixie>
actually even that's not accurate

[16:33:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's a list of quads

[16:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
with some annotations

[16:34:01.0000] <Hixie>
but you can form a graph from that list

[16:34:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
The graphness comes from defining a form of url-equality, yeah.

[16:34:03.0000] <Hixie>
microdata is natively a tree, that you can flatten to a list of triples, from which you can also create a graph

[16:34:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
What's the quad?  The object type?

[16:34:05.0000] <Hixie>
value type

[16:35:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Right, yeah.

[16:35:01.0000] <Hixie>
and annotations are language of the value if it's a literal, and source of the triple

[16:35:02.0000] <Hixie>
also the literal can itself be structured XML

[16:37:00.0000] <othermaciej>
RDF serializations are a list of triples/quads/whatever

[16:37:01.0000] <othermaciej>
but RDF the data model is a graph

[16:39:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Under your wording, othermaciej, Microdata's data model can indeed be a DAG, if you lean on url-equality to associate nodes as being the same (the same thing you have to do to make RDF a graph).

[16:40:00.0000] <Hixie>
right

[16:40:01.0000] <othermaciej>
but no cycles?

[16:40:02.0000] <Hixie>
microdata itself isn't but when you convert it to RDF you can get the same kind of graph with cycles

[16:40:03.0000] <Hixie>
the only thing you can't do cycles through in microdata iirc is bnodes

[16:40:04.0000] <Hixie>
but since you can just give them unique IDs, that becomes a non-issue

[16:42:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah, bnodes in Microdata are only as blank as you allow them to be.

[16:42:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't really understand what a bnode is

[16:42:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
A node in the data graph without an associated url.

[16:42:03.0000] <Hixie>
it's a node without an identifier

[16:43:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
In Microdata's RDF serialization, a bnode is the subject of all the triples generated by an @itemscope without an @itemid.

[16:44:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's hard to say exactly what the RDF model is since there's no official API; the only reason I'd say microdata's model is a tree and not the RDF graph is that there's an explicit microdata API that does't follow the URL refs and thus makes it a tree

[16:45:00.0000] <othermaciej>
the API being proposed by RDFa doesn't expose a graph or tree at all

[16:45:01.0000] <othermaciej>
just a list of triples

[16:45:02.0000] <Hixie>
right, like i said, RDF's model is just a list :-)

[16:45:03.0000] <othermaciej>
which seems like a pretty lousy interface

[16:45:04.0000] <Hixie>
which by convention can be interpreted as a graph

[16:47:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I believe you're just supposed to parse the triples out and then hand them to a triple-store which will make the node associations for you.

[16:47:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah the usual way of working with RDF is through queries, not through an API

[16:47:02.0000] <othermaciej>
but if you are running as JS in the browser, you don't have a triple store available

[16:47:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I expected the RDFa API itself to be a "triple store"

[16:47:04.0000] <othermaciej>
maybe that was a bad assumption

[16:47:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
You'd be disappointed, then.  ^_^

[16:47:06.0000] <othermaciej>
er

[16:48:00.0000] <othermaciej>
assumption

[16:48:01.0000] <Hixie>
it's not clear to me that the people designing the API are doing it for any reason other than to say they have an API

[16:48:02.0000] <othermaciej>
it seems like this model makes it very hard to have a live triple store on a dynamically modified document

[16:48:03.0000] <Hixie>
(unlike the microdata API, which is designed to make the information available)

[16:48:04.0000] <Hixie>
but then browser vendors are even less likely to implement a real triple store with querying than to implement the flat API

[16:48:05.0000] <Hixie>
so...

[16:49:00.0000] <othermaciej>
a triple store API would be more complicated to implement, but on the other hand it might have a real use case

[20:23:00.0000] <jlebar>
Hixie, Is there a reason that offline manifests don't treat form feed characters (and other unicode space characters) as whitespace?

[20:24:00.0000] <jlebar>
e.g. step 17 in http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/offline.html#writing-cache-manifests

[20:24:01.0000] <annevk>
consistency

[20:24:02.0000] <jlebar>
annevk, with what?

[20:24:03.0000] <annevk>
text/plain, HTML, CSS, etc.?

[20:25:00.0000] <jlebar>
the split on spaces algorithm does consider ff to be whitespace.

[20:26:00.0000] <jlebar>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#skip-whitespace

[20:26:01.0000] <annevk>
sure, but newlines are always just CR and LF or CRLF

[20:27:00.0000] <jlebar>
Right.  But the step in the algorithm I first mentioned is stripping whitespace off the end of a line.

[20:29:00.0000] <annevk>
aah I see now

[20:29:01.0000] <annevk>
sorry

[20:30:00.0000] <jlebar>
np

[20:30:01.0000] <annevk>

[20:32:00.0000] <annevk>

[02:52:00.0000] <Philip`>
Why do you need a standardised API for implementing pretty-printers?

[02:52:01.0000] <Philip`>

[02:55:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: I don't really. But it's not like there are lots of existing implementations that expose private APIs to do what I want either

[02:56:00.0000] <Philip`>
Getting an implementation to expose a private API sounds like far less effort than getting every implementation to expose a public API

[02:57:00.0000] <jgraham>
It's really unclear that that is true :)

[02:58:00.0000] <jgraham>

[02:58:01.0000] <jgraham>
*didn't

[02:59:00.0000] <Philip`>
How can it not be true? The public API is as much effort as doing the private API multiplied by the number of implementations, plus the cost of coordination

[03:00:00.0000] <jgraham>
Because the cost to me isn't the implementation cost it is the cost of convincing people

[03:00:01.0000] <Philip`>
I was assuming you weren't being so selfish as to only consider the cost to yourself ;-)

[03:01:00.0000] <Philip`>
(Given the apparent pain and suffering involved with SpiderMonkey's decompiler, I doubt implementors want to do much more of that kind of thing - computing and storing perfect lossless ASTs seems to conflict with optimisation goals, and deriving an AST from more optimised data structures is hard)

[20:43:00.0000] <nessy>
I have a question about Firefox and video - does Firefox store the byte ranges in an actual file on disk, so when all byte ranges have been downloaded the full original files is available? or do you just keep the byte ranges in memory and throw them out?

[20:44:00.0000] <doublec>
we keep the ranges on disk in a 'media cache' but throw them out when you leave the page

[20:45:00.0000] <doublec>
we also cache the video in the standard browser cache if it meets caching requirements - but due to the nature of video (seeking, large files, etc) it often doesn't meet those requirements

[20:46:00.0000] <doublec>
the media cache is shared across all videos being played too - and defaults to 50MB iirc. As more video gets played old entries in the cache get evicted

[20:47:00.0000] <nessy>
so in the 'media cache' you won't typically end up with the full original file

[20:47:01.0000] <nessy>
just its byte ranges as temp storage?

[20:47:02.0000] <doublec>
nessy: http://weblogs.mozillazine.org/roc/archives/2009/04/media_cache.html

[20:47:03.0000] <doublec>
nessy: correct

[20:47:04.0000] <nessy>
I'm asking, since it's then not strictly progressive download as described here http://weblogs.mozillazine.org/roc/archives/2009/04/media_cache.html

[20:48:00.0000] <roc>
why does it matter?

[20:48:01.0000] <nessy>
it's more like actual streaming and more secure  - except for the "Download src" right context menu functionality :)

[20:49:00.0000] <nessy>
thanks for the link!

[20:49:01.0000] <nessy>

[01:53:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[01:53:01.0000] <othermaciej>
mess with the viewbox attributes

[01:54:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(I think)

[01:54:01.0000] <hsivonen>
no, viewBox sets up the coordinate space

[01:54:02.0000] <zcorpan>
possibly preserveAspectRatio can change it, but i think at least in opera it'll always be clipped

[01:54:03.0000] <hsivonen>
but how do I make shapes outside the viewBox box get painted outside the box

[01:55:00.0000] <hsivonen>
zcorpan: oh so the IE9 demo that gets clipped in "other browsers" isn't about "defaults" but about other browsers always clipping?

[01:56:00.0000] <zcorpan>
dunno

[01:56:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't know what the IE9 demo is specifically

[01:56:02.0000] <othermaciej>
SVG in theory requires (effectively) that SVG root elements have overflow: hidden !important in the UA stylesheet

[01:57:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think at least some browsers let you override that to overflow: scroll

[01:57:01.0000] <hsivonen>
http://ie.microsoft.com/testdrive/Graphics/21FallingBalls/Default.xhtml

[01:57:02.0000] <othermaciej>
on the theory that the SVG spec didn't know what it was talking about

[01:57:03.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: something different happens in IE?

[01:57:04.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: that's sad. overflow: hidden !important sabotages one of the coolest things one could do with inline SVG

[01:58:00.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: we have that in our UA stylesheet but I am tempted to get rid of it

[01:58:01.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: in IE9, the balls that fall out of the box don't get clipped out

[01:58:02.0000] <zcorpan>
image-fit:cover (or content-fit or what it's called now) should be able to make svg paint outside its box

[01:59:00.0000] <othermaciej>
oh I guess we don't have that any more

[01:59:01.0000] <othermaciej>
just overflow: hidden

[01:59:02.0000] <othermaciej>
the demo could choose to set overflow: visible on the <svg>

[01:59:03.0000] <hsivonen>
is !important supposed to work in the style attribute?

[01:59:04.0000] <hsivonen>
overflow: visible !important; doesn't work for me in <svg style=

[01:59:05.0000] <hsivonen>
in Gecko

[02:00:00.0000] <zcorpan>
hsivonen: !important is supposed to work in style="" but it would only affect later declarations in the same style=""

[02:00:01.0000] <othermaciej>
we don't actually have a !important rule in WebKit trunk

[02:00:02.0000] <hsivonen>
looks like I won't be making the demo I wanted to make

[02:01:00.0000] <zcorpan>
hsivonen: since style="" is author level and highest specificity, it will override anything that doesn't have !important anyway, and if something earlier has !important then nothing will override it

[02:01:01.0000] <hsivonen>
zcorpan: is image-fit implemented in any browser?

[02:01:02.0000] <zcorpan>
hsivonen: it's implemented in opera but not shipped yet

[02:01:03.0000] <othermaciej>
see the comment here for a long-winded explanation of the clipping issue: http://trac.webkit.org/browser/trunk/WebCore/css/svg.css

[02:01:04.0000] <hsivonen>
plain overflow: visible; doesn't work in Gecko, either.

[02:02:00.0000] <zcorpan>
hsivonen: i hope gecko and webkit will implement it as well since it's really cool

[02:03:00.0000] <othermaciej>
WebKit still clips if I force overflow: visible

[02:03:01.0000] <othermaciej>
not sure why

[02:03:02.0000] <hsivonen>

[02:04:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[02:04:01.0000] <zcorpan>
hsivonen: just memorize them

[02:05:00.0000] <othermaciej>
svg root element seems to clip to its bounds regardless

[02:05:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I could probably figure out why with some code study but I don't have time at the moment

[02:06:00.0000] <zcorpan>
it's really easy, the leading part is invariant, the year is 1999 for xhtml and xlink, 2000 for svg, and the trailing part is xhtml, svg or xlink (no trailing slash for any of them)

[02:06:01.0000] <zcorpan>
the mathml and xml namespaces are harder

[02:06:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I think our rule in svg.css is probably based on an incorrect interpretation of "outermost"

[02:07:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it should really be a rule for svg svg rather than for svg:not(:root) I think

[02:07:01.0000] <othermaciej>
not that this would fix the IE demo but it would make the stylesheet match the comment

[03:32:00.0000] <roc>
annevk: my point of view is that CORS lifts same-origin restrictions. I don't see how when those restrictions are imposed "for privacy" CORS is suitable but when those restrictions are imposed for other reasons, lifting them with CORS is an abuse of CORS

[03:32:01.0000] <annevk>
because CORS cannot be used in a generic way for those other purposes

[03:33:00.0000] <othermaciej>
why can't it?

[03:33:01.0000] <annevk>
and CORS is intended to be a protocol that works q

[03:33:02.0000] <annevk>
equally for all resources

[03:33:03.0000] <annevk>
othermaciej, because most scenarios already allow cross-origin loads

[03:33:04.0000] <roc>
that's because we currently have no way to impose same-origin restrictions for <img> loads etc

[03:33:05.0000] <othermaciej>
couldn't CORS be used in principle to allow cross-origin images or videos to draw into a canvas without tainting?

[03:34:00.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: yeah, but CORS isn't what allows you to do the load, it's what allows you to read the data

[03:34:01.0000] <roc>
if we did have a way to impose such restrictions, we could use CORS to lift it

[03:34:02.0000] <annevk>
othermaciej, that's not another purpose, that's CORS' purpose

[03:34:03.0000] <annevk>
othermaciej, preventing bandwidth theft through CORS just for fonts is what is being proposed here

[03:34:04.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't say it was another purpose

[03:34:05.0000] <roc>
the problem <img> is that no restrictions exist for CORS to apply to

[03:34:06.0000] <annevk>
othermaciej, but that cannot be used for <video> or <img> in that way

[03:35:00.0000] <annevk>
othermaciej, so it is completely tied to font loading

[03:35:01.0000] <annevk>
and just makes CORS some kind of weird case there

[03:35:02.0000] <annevk>
which imo is wrong

[03:35:03.0000] <roc>
it's not a weird case

[03:35:04.0000] <roc>
CORS can be used to lift same-origin restrictions where they exist

[03:35:05.0000] <othermaciej>
if you wanted to limit <video> or <img> to same-origin-only for bandwidth protection purposes, you'd have to check Origin or Referer on the server side

[03:35:06.0000] <roc>
they just happen to not exist at all for <video> and <img>

[03:35:07.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't think the intent of applying same-origin policy to fonts is for bandwidth limits

[03:35:08.0000] <hsivonen>
annevk: is this about a matter of principle, a technical problem or fear of a lawyer thinking that CORS is Effective?

[03:35:09.0000] <othermaciej>
I think the intent is for half-assed pseudo-DRM

[03:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
at least I imagine that is why the font vendors want it

[03:36:01.0000] <annevk>
hsivonen, technical consistency?

[03:36:02.0000] <annevk>
hsivonen, haven't really tried to think about lawyers and DRM that much

[03:36:03.0000] <othermaciej>
if font had a same-origin restriction then it would be reasonable for CORS to lift it

[03:37:00.0000] <hsivonen>
annevk: seems technically consistent to use CORS to lift the Same Origin restriction whenever it is lifted for any reason

[03:37:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think the controversial part is whether fonts should have a same-origin restriction by default

[03:37:02.0000] <annevk>
othermaciej, there's no reason for fonts to have same-origin restrictions

[03:37:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't think anyone in WebKit-land has any interest in adding that restriction

[03:37:04.0000] <roc>
right, that is the issue

[03:38:00.0000] <roc>
CORS is a red herring

[03:38:01.0000] <othermaciej>
but if the Trident and Gecko developers want to add such a restriction, then it seems reasonable to use CORS to selectively lift that restriction

[03:38:02.0000] <roc>
thank you!

[03:38:03.0000] <annevk>
hsivonen, we shouldn't have same-origin restrictions however for whatever reason

[03:39:00.0000] <annevk>
hsivonen, if the problem is bandwidth theft then that problem also exists for <video>

[03:39:01.0000] <annevk>
hsivonen, so the solution cannot be CORS imo

[03:39:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I would be unhappy if whatever spec people are talking about required same-origin restrictions by default for fonts though

[03:39:03.0000] <roc>
CORS is not the solution to bandwidth theft

[03:39:04.0000] <annevk>
indeed it's not

[03:39:05.0000] <roc>
the solution for bandwidth theft and certain other problems is a same-origin restriction

[03:40:00.0000] <othermaciej>
WebKit-based browsers would probably never be conforming if that was the case

[03:40:01.0000] <roc>
CORS lets authors opt out of that

[03:40:02.0000] <annevk>
roc, that solution fails for a lot of scenarios so it's not a good solution

[03:41:00.0000] <roc>
we can argue about that, but the fact remains that if we're going to have a same-origin restriction, it seems reasonable to use CORS to lift that restriction

[03:41:01.0000] <jgraham>
Why isn't video same-origin only?

[03:42:00.0000] <roc>
there was a big discussion about that

[03:42:01.0000] <annevk>
because it doesn't make sense

[03:42:02.0000] <othermaciej>
it would suck to not be able to embed video cross-site

[03:42:03.0000] <roc>
that

[03:42:04.0000] <annevk>
at least not with how <script>, <img>, etc. work

[03:42:05.0000] <jgraham>
Yeah I remember a discussion

[03:42:06.0000] <roc>
plus legacy reasons

[03:42:07.0000] <othermaciej>
given that a key feature of the most popular video sites is embedding cross-site

[03:42:08.0000] <othermaciej>
also, plugins can do it and <video> shouldn't be less capable than plugins

[03:42:09.0000] <annevk>
anyway i need to get some food/sleep and make some more slides

[03:42:10.0000] <othermaciej>
(e.g. QuickTime)

[03:42:11.0000] <jgraham>
Yes, but if CORS is a solution for fonts it is a solution for video

[03:43:00.0000] <jgraham>
but moreso given the realtive bandwidth requirments

[03:43:01.0000] <jgraham>
*relative

[03:43:02.0000] <othermaciej>
the proposed solution for fonts isn't so much CORS as it is imposing a same-origin restriction by default

[03:43:03.0000] <othermaciej>
CORS just mitigates some of the downsides of that basic decision

[03:43:04.0000] <roc>
right

[03:44:00.0000] <othermaciej>
imposing a same-origin restriction by default wasn't really a viable option for video

[03:44:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it seems less obviously broken for fonts, though I am not super enthusiastic about it myself

[03:45:00.0000] <jgraham>
So the argument goes that fonts are fundamentally different from video because video is often cross origin whereas fonts are typically same origin?

[03:45:01.0000] <roc>
I think it's reasonable to provide a convenient mechanism allowing authors to control who accesses their resources

[03:45:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I think it's reasonable too

[03:46:00.0000] <othermaciej>
the questions are: (a) should the default be no cross-origin access instead of full access as for most other resource types?

[03:46:01.0000] <annevk>
they can just check the Origin header

[03:46:02.0000] <othermaciej>
and: (b) should this mechanism be enforced client-side instead of server-side?

[03:46:03.0000] <annevk>
or we could have a header that enforces same-origin loads

[03:46:04.0000] <roc>
checking the Origin header is not convenient

[03:46:05.0000] <othermaciej>
if you answer "no" to both, then nothing in particular needs to be added

[03:46:06.0000] <annevk>
that would also work for all other types of resources

[03:47:00.0000] <jgraham>
Would people have argued differently for video if CORS was already widely deployed?

[03:47:01.0000] <roc>
checking on the client has better privacy properties

[03:47:02.0000] <othermaciej>
using CORS to undo the restriction is about as convenient/inconvenient as checking Origin to add a restriction

[03:47:03.0000] <roc>
jgraham: it would have helped a bit, but probably we'd have the same outcome

[03:47:04.0000] <roc>
othermaciej: most authors don't need to undo the restriction

[03:48:00.0000] <othermaciej>
which goes back to question (a)

[03:48:01.0000] <annevk>
we could just have a header that enforces same origin loads

[03:48:02.0000] <jgraham>
roc: In that case the argument for fonts seems very weak

[03:48:03.0000] <annevk>
that could even be part of the CSRF work from Mozilla

[03:48:04.0000] <annevk>
a header which people likely need to use anyway

[03:48:05.0000] <jgraham>
s/fonts/making fonts same-origin by default/

[03:49:00.0000] <roc>
annevk: a header on the document referencing the font?

[03:49:01.0000] <annevk>
no on the font of course

[03:49:02.0000] <roc>
ok

[03:49:03.0000] <roc>
that's a question of what the default should be

[03:49:04.0000] <annevk>
it's also a question of whether we want to solve the bandwidth problem two times or just once...

[03:49:05.0000] <roc>
based on what the font vendors say, it sounds like they're going to require authors to control access

[03:50:00.0000] <annevk>
and whether a different request policy for fonts really makes sense -- i think it doesn't

[03:50:01.0000] <roc>
most of them

[03:50:02.0000] <roc>
so authors will frequently want to same-origin restriction

[03:50:03.0000] <annevk>
i personally think this whole WOFF thing is somewhat of a mistake

[03:51:00.0000] <annevk>
before it's done Ubuntu and other systems will support it natively, I'm sure

[03:51:01.0000] <annevk>

[03:51:02.0000] <roc>
sure

[03:51:03.0000] <roc>
that's all fine

[03:51:04.0000] <othermaciej>

[03:51:05.0000] <roc>
othermaciej: it is

[03:51:06.0000] <othermaciej>
no need to bring the browser into it

[03:51:07.0000] <annevk>
anyway, gotta go, will read the logs later

[03:52:00.0000] <roc>
the question is how easy is it going to be for the customer to follow their side of the license?

[03:52:01.0000] <roc>
we can give them tools to make it super easy

[03:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>
or we can create a business opportunity for Adobe Straming Font Server :-)

[03:53:01.0000] <roc>
or we can force them to do server-side checking, with a number of downsides for convenience, privacy and robustness (firewalls stripping headers)

[03:54:00.0000] <zcorpan>
so should we add a header Restrict-Load-To: http://example.org

[03:54:01.0000] <zcorpan>
which would work for everything (fonts, images, videos, html)

[03:54:02.0000] <othermaciej>
server-side checking would be better if the motive was actually preventing bandwidth waste

[03:55:00.0000] <jgraham>

[03:55:01.0000] <othermaciej>
since by the time the client checks, your bandwidth has already been wasted

[03:55:02.0000] <roc>
"embedding laws and licensing agreements in code" is totally not happening here ... that's the DRM bogeyman

[03:56:00.0000] <roc>
othermaciej: the point is that site authors aren't going to link to a font cross-site if that load isn't actually going to work

[03:56:01.0000] <roc>
unless they just want to maliciously eat your bandwidth to no useful purpose

[03:56:02.0000] <othermaciej>
roc: really, authors aren't going to do strange things with no visible effect and then leave that in their production site?

[03:56:03.0000] <jgraham>

[03:56:04.0000] <jgraham>
+typical

[03:57:00.0000] <othermaciej>
that would make my job a lot easier if it was true!

[03:58:00.0000] <roc>
othermaciej: ok, there'll be a little of that

[03:58:01.0000] <othermaciej>
you are correct that it would reduce the motive for bandwidth waste somewhat, though not the opportunity

[03:58:02.0000] <roc>
jgraham: we have same-origin restrictions for XHRs. I don't see having them for fonts as a wild innovation

[03:59:00.0000] <jgraham>
roc: For XHR is is needed for security

[03:59:01.0000] <roc>
sure, so?

[03:59:02.0000] <jgraham>
So that is a clear reason for the difference

[03:59:03.0000] <roc>
it's still true that we have different classes of loads

[04:00:00.0000] <jgraham>
The font thing seems to be predicated on the idea that fonts are somehow fundamentally different from an IP point of view compared to images or video

[04:00:01.0000] <jgraham>
or text

[04:00:02.0000] <roc>
there are a different set of tradeoffs

[04:00:03.0000] <hsivonen>
Restrict-Load-To would have bad effects if Opera supported it before IE

[04:00:04.0000] <roc>
images are totally constrained by legacy issues

[04:01:00.0000] <roc>
video is constrained by legacy issues and the "viral video" feature

[04:01:01.0000] <jgraham>
Right, if we were designing the platform from scratch we would do it differently

[04:02:00.0000] <hsivonen>
but server refusing to serve if the request didn't have the right Origin header would have better game theoretica characteristics to motivate UA implementation

[04:02:01.0000] <roc>
if those issues didn't exist, would it be a good idea to have a default-same origin restriction for images and video? I think so, although that world's so counter-factual I'd have to think harder than I have

[04:02:02.0000] <othermaciej>
it does seem to me like many font deployments won't really want to share cross-origin, on the other hand, I could imagine big sites wanting to serve their fonts off of Akamai

[04:03:00.0000] <othermaciej>
or I could imagine the existence of central type hosting sites like TypeKit

[04:03:01.0000] <othermaciej>
or of sites that have a separate domain for large static resources in general, or which have multiple subdomains

[04:03:02.0000] <roc>
I can tell you that in practice when we raised the idea of same-origin restrictions for <video> there were howls of protest from authors and, well, just about everyone

[04:03:03.0000] <hsivonen>
typekit's core feature is addressing complications

[04:03:04.0000] <roc>
whereas for fonts, we have had no protest whatsoever

[04:04:00.0000] <jgraham>
roc: Because people aren't expecting Youtube for fonts

[04:04:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[04:04:02.0000] <roc>
jgraham: well, there you go

[04:04:03.0000] <othermaciej>

[04:04:04.0000] <jgraham>

[04:05:00.0000] <roc>

[04:05:01.0000] <jgraham>

[04:05:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[04:05:03.0000] <roc>

[04:05:04.0000] <Philip`>

[04:05:05.0000] <othermaciej>

[04:05:06.0000] <othermaciej>

[04:05:07.0000] <Philip`>

[12:25:00.0000] <Matjas_>
Which ARIA roles should be used when faking a HTML5 <details> element?

[12:35:00.0000] <webben>
Matjas_: Hmm. Does it require ARIA?

[12:36:00.0000] <Matjas_>
webben: Once <details> is natively supported, I don't think so, but for now (while we're still stuck using fallbacks) I'd say some ARIA wouldn't hurt

[12:37:00.0000] <webben>
Matjas_: When you say faking it - do you mean using the HTML5 markup and adding behavior with JS?

[12:37:01.0000] <Matjas_>
webben: Yes. Like this: http://mathiasbynens.be/notes/html5-details-jquery (also see Shelley Powers’s comment, suggesting to add ARIA: http://mathiasbynens.be/notes/html5-details-jquery#comment-6)

[12:38:00.0000] <divya>
Matjas_: Slide 65 on this: http://www.slideshare.net/AaronGustafson/why-aria-devchatt-2010 seems to discuss ARIA for tabbed interfaces, I am guessing you could investigate some of the roles covered there. 

[12:39:00.0000] <Matjas_>
divya: Thanks!

[12:39:01.0000] <webben>
But it's not tabbed?

[12:39:02.0000] <webben>
Matjas_: Or is it tabbed?

[12:40:00.0000] <Matjas_>
webben: Depends what you mean by ‘tabbed’

[12:40:01.0000] <Matjas_>
webben: There’s a demo here: http://mathiasbynens.be/demo/html5-details-jquery What do you think?

[12:40:02.0000] <webben>
Matjas_: Mmm I wouldn't really say that's a list of tabs.

[12:41:00.0000] <webben>
I don't think there are ARIA roles that map perfectly onto details and summary.

[12:41:01.0000] <Matjas_>

[12:41:02.0000] <Matjas_>
Perhaps aria-hidden="false" could be used

[12:41:03.0000] <Matjas_>
Question mark?

[12:42:00.0000] <webben>
Matjas_: In your JS implementation, should you not move focus to the start of the content when you open the details?

[12:42:01.0000] <webben>
Matjas_: I agree aria-hidden="true" should be applied to the contents in the closed state.

[12:42:02.0000] <divya>
Matjas_: http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-implementation-20091215/#mapping_role see the table for the huge list of roles you can choose from :/

[12:43:00.0000] <Matjas_>
webben: Why? I’m focusing the <summary> element so that when tab is pressed, it jumps to the next 'tabbable' element

[12:43:01.0000] <webben>
slightly newer at http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/roles#role_definitions

[12:43:02.0000] <webben>
Matjas_: Let's say I'm using a screen reader. I activate the summary element ... somehow (we can come back to that), how do I know what's changed?

[12:44:00.0000] <Matjas_>
webben: Hmm, I see your point

[12:44:01.0000] <Matjas_>
divya: Thanks again!

[12:46:00.0000] <webben>
Matjas_: With regards to activation, I guess give the summary element a role of "button" and a property of "aria-pressed".

[12:46:01.0000] <webben>
Matjas_: Though given you're faking the lot with JS, you could just as well insert an actual button element.

[12:46:02.0000] <webben>
and it will work with more UAs

[12:47:00.0000] <webben>
Matjas_: you could use aria-owns/aria-controls to indicate the relationship between the button and the content.

[12:48:00.0000] <Matjas_>
webben: I'm trying to keep DOM manipulations to a minimum. JS makes the summary element clickable, regardless of wether the browser understands it correctly. Would it really be beneficial to replace it with an actual button?

[12:48:01.0000] <divya>
webben: Would the role of "note" be not sorta similar to what <details> semantically stands for? http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/roles#note

[12:49:00.0000] <webben>
divya: Not necessarily.

[12:49:01.0000] <webben>
I think that's a bit closer to <aside> really.

[12:49:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, what are the default ARIA semantics of <details> in HTML5?

[12:49:03.0000] <webben>
Matjas_: It would be beneficial in the sense that there's plenty of deployed software which can't make head or tail of ARIA or HTML5.

[12:50:00.0000] <divya>
"The details element represents a disclosure widget from which the user can obtain additional information or controls." says http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/interactive-elements.html#the-details-element

[12:51:00.0000] <Matjas_>

[12:51:01.0000] <webben>

[12:52:00.0000] <Matjas_>

[12:52:01.0000] <webben>

[12:53:00.0000] <webben>

[12:53:01.0000] <webben>

[12:53:02.0000] <webben>

[02:57:00.0000] <annevk>

[02:58:00.0000] <annevk>

[02:58:01.0000] <annevk>

[02:58:02.0000] <annevk>

[02:59:00.0000] <asmodai>
annevk: it's a continuation of http://tweakers.net/nieuws/66906/cookies-mogen-volgend-jaar-alleen-na-toestemming-internetter.html

[03:01:00.0000] <asmodai>
Directive 2009/136/EC generally requires end-user consent to the storing of information-such as the piece of software known as a "cookie"-on the user's computer. Accessing stored cookie data-the raison d'être of a cookie-would also require consent. Further, a user's consent would be valid only if he or she is "provided . . . clear and comprehensive information" concerning the cookie's use.

[03:02:00.0000] <asmodai>
So it would mean changes to browser defaults methinks.

[03:02:01.0000] <jgraham>

[03:02:02.0000] <annevk>

[07:58:00.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, yt?

[08:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
Lachy: Sort of

[08:01:00.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, just wanted to check with you about whether or not this test is correct, since you know more about canvas than I do. http://tc.labs.opera.com/html/canvas/getContext/2d/drawImage/003.htm

[08:01:01.0000] <Lachy>
I don't get why it's expecting an exception to be thrown for that one

[08:03:00.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: speaking of walls: did the idea of asking Randall Munroe to draw the HTML5 tokenizer state transition graph go anywhere?

[08:03:01.0000] <Philip`>
Lachy: Looks like the image's 'complete' attribute would be false, which used to make drawImage throw an error but should now cause it to be silently ignored

[08:03:02.0000] <Philip`>
(so the test is currently incorrect)

[08:04:00.0000] <Lachy>
(new Image()).complete returns true in every browser though

[08:04:01.0000] <Lachy>
so I guess all browsers are wrong about that

[08:04:02.0000] <Philip`>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/embedded-content-1.html#dom-img-complete indicates it should be false, I believe

[08:05:00.0000] <Philip`>
(I don't know if the spec is correct)

[08:05:01.0000] <Lachy>
ok. So that's a bug in opera for image.complete and an invalid test.

[08:05:02.0000] <Lachy>
the spec doesn't agree with implementations, but it makes more sense than saying an image is complete, even though it has no src

[08:06:00.0000] <Philip`>
You could interpret it instead as saying the image downloading/decoding is complete

[08:07:00.0000] <Philip`>
and an image with no src isn't still in the middle of the downloading/decoding process, so that process is not incomplete

[08:07:01.0000] <Lachy>
but it hasn't actually completed anything

[08:07:02.0000] <Lachy>
and that means setting a src attribute should make set it to false

[08:08:00.0000] <Lachy>
until it loaded the image again

[08:08:01.0000] <Philip`>
It's completed the "complete = false; if (there is a src) { ... do a long slow download and decode ... }; complete = true" process

[08:09:00.0000] <Philip`>
but then you have to deal with images that are complete but still don't have any image data

[08:09:01.0000] <Philip`>
I don't think it's particularly illogical either way, but the spec's current definition seems more helpful

[08:12:00.0000] <Lachy>
I guess that makes the spec ambiguous if it can be interpreted either way.

[08:12:01.0000] <Lachy>
I'll send mail about that later.

[08:19:00.0000] <Philip`>
Oh, I don't think the spec is ambiguous

[08:20:00.0000] <Philip`>
I just think the attribute name "complete" is ambiguous so it could defined in different ways that wouldn't seem particularly wrong

[08:20:01.0000] <Philip`>
s/could/could be/

[08:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
and the current spec has chosen one definition which seems reasonably clear (though maybe people could argue it should make a different choice to better match current implementations)

[09:35:00.0000] <Lachy>

[09:36:00.0000] <Lachy>

[09:38:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[09:39:00.0000] <Lachy>

[09:40:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[09:40:01.0000] <Lachy>

[09:41:00.0000] <Lachy>

[09:41:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[09:42:00.0000] <Lachy>
but Mozilla could now implement that using their experimental :-moz-any() selector

[09:43:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Got it.  Which browser were you going to roll this into?  Cause some folks would want to customize that if they could.

[09:43:01.0000] <Lachy>
well, it's in the spec and will hopefully be introduced into all browsers eventually. I don't know of any browser that has any immediate plans.

[09:44:00.0000] <Lachy>
but as annevk just said above, Mozilla has just implemented some support for the new elements, without doing anything about these heading styles

[09:45:00.0000] <Lachy>
see http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/complete.html#margins-and-padding for more info

[09:46:00.0000] <Lachy>
so, according to that, Mozilla should implement those styles using :-moz-any(article, aside, section, nav) in place of the selector "x" given in the spec

[09:47:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Neat, maybe I should add that into http://www.iecss.com/whatwg.css

[09:49:00.0000] <Lachy>
is that stylesheet based on the styles given in the spec?

[10:08:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
TabAtkins, so I would put the fn org logo on the anchor or h1? 

[10:15:00.0000] <TabAtkins_>
JonathanNeal: The <h1>, because putting it on an <a> has a special meaning too.

[10:18:00.0000] <TabAtkins_>
If @itemprop appears on an <img>, <video>, <audio>, <link>, <object>, <a>, or <time>, the value is drawn from an attribute.  <meta> too, but that should be obvious.  Any other tags, it grabs the text contents instead.

[10:18:01.0000] <TabAtkins_>
Basically anything with a significant url attribute, plus <time> and <meta>.

[10:20:00.0000] <JonathanNeal_>
I'll move it to the H1 right now on all of them.

[10:23:00.0000] <JonathanNeal_>

[10:27:00.0000] <TabAtkins_>

[10:44:00.0000] <JonathanNeal_>

[10:46:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
All right, only one problem left.  ^_^  The itemscope has to be an ancestor to all its properties, so you'll have to move @itemscope, @itemref, and @itemtype all up to the hgroup.

[10:46:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Or, move the @itemprop into a wrapper element somewhere inside of the <h1>.

[10:48:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[10:51:00.0000] <JonathanNeal_>
Which <div>s don't you like?

[10:51:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
How big is a typical starting size for TCP windows?  I haven't been able to find any real-world estimates in some brief Googling.

[10:51:02.0000] <JonathanNeal_>
itemscope has to be an ancestor or a child?  Which am I moving?

[10:52:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
#main-document, and at least one of #content or #main-content.

[10:53:00.0000] <JonathanNeal_>
main-content is useful for the skip to main content link.

[10:53:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
@itemscope declares that something is a Microdata container.  It must be an ancestor.  So either move @itemscope up (along with @itemtype and @itemref, which must be alonside @itemscope) or move @itemprop down onto a wrapper element (since there is no appropriate child element to carry those @itemprops right now).

[10:53:02.0000] <JonathanNeal_>
main-document is the document wrapper, and describes its contents.

[10:53:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
<body> is the document wrapper.

[10:54:00.0000] <JonathanNeal_>
This where I usually bring up a chat bar or a dockbar that might exist aside the main portion of the document, and may be application content.

[10:55:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Ah, okay.  That's not in the template, so it looked extraneous.

[12:55:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[12:55:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[12:55:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[15:02:00.0000] <aboodman>
quick question on the proposed Origin header.

[15:02:01.0000] <aboodman>
would it be sent with all requests, or only those from XHR?

[15:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>
aboodman: all requests, though some particular kinds of requests would always send "Origin: null"

[15:06:01.0000] <othermaciej>
abarth probably knows the details of what is proposed and what WebKit does currently

[15:16:00.0000] <aboodman>
othermaciej: so, eg, if a form was constructed and submitted cross-origin, the Origin header would be present.

[15:16:01.0000] <aboodman>
and a site that checked it would not be vulnerable to xsrf.

[15:28:00.0000] <paul_irish>
aboodman: offhand, do you know what was the first version of FF to support CORS? v3?

[15:28:01.0000] <aboodman>
paul_irish: nope

[15:28:02.0000] <aboodman>
i don't even know if any current versions support it

[15:42:00.0000] <othermaciej>
aboodman: yes

[15:42:01.0000] <othermaciej>
aboodman: more importantly, the same-origin form would have its own domain's Origin

[15:42:02.0000] <othermaciej>
aboodman: so tricky ways of stripping the origin would probably produce Origin: null rather than a valid value

[15:43:00.0000] <GarethAdams|Home>
What would happen if the initial value of a <textarea> or <input> was longer than that permitted by the maxlength?

[15:43:01.0000] <othermaciej>
aboodman: you may find this informative about some of the concepts: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-webapps/2009OctDec/0468.html

[15:44:00.0000] <aboodman>
othermaciej: i read that already, thanks.

[15:44:01.0000] <aboodman>
(it was)

[15:44:02.0000] <aboodman>
i don't think it covered the detail of whether the Origin header was sent for normal forms, but maybe I missed it.

[15:57:00.0000] <othermaciej>
aboodman: it tried to explain how Origin can be a CSRF defense

[15:57:01.0000] <othermaciej>
(if I recall correctly)

[15:57:02.0000] <othermaciej>
it has to be sent for normal forms for that to work

[15:58:00.0000] <othermaciej>
yeah, it's illustrated in the diagram (CSRF: Origin Defense)

anyone here at WWW2010?

[23:13:00.0000] <Hixie>

[23:13:01.0000] <Hixie>
it'll submit fine and it doesn't get truncated

[23:14:00.0000] <Hixie>

[23:18:01.0000] <zcorpan>

[23:18:02.0000] <Hixie>

[23:19:00.0000] <Hixie>
zcorpan: btw re the websocket stuff

[23:19:01.0000] <Hixie>
still going through my mail from having been off sick for a day

[23:19:02.0000] <Hixie>
but

[23:19:03.0000] <Hixie>
i don't think it matters where you drop the connection if you drop the connection

[23:19:04.0000] <Hixie>
since it's black-box indistinguishable

[23:20:00.0000] <Hixie>
however, you shouldn't use your HTTP parser, since it does different things (like continuation lines)

[23:20:01.0000] <Hixie>
and it might do error handling differently

[23:20:02.0000] <Hixie>
since HTTP doesn't say how to do error handling

[23:20:03.0000] <zcorpan>
Hixie: it's not black-box indistinguishable if the server sleeps half-way

[23:20:04.0000] <zcorpan>
Hixie: yeah

[23:21:00.0000] <Hixie>
the client is always allowed to insert aribitrary sleeps anywhere

[23:21:01.0000] <Hixie>
nothing in the spec defines the performance characteristics of a websocket client

[23:22:00.0000] <zcorpan>
Hixie: if the server responds "HTTP/1.1 200" and then sleeps, we want to abort but the spec doesn't allow it

[23:22:01.0000] <zcorpan>
since we haven't seen an 0x0A byte yet

[23:24:00.0000] <zcorpan>
continuation lines is something i should test

[23:28:00.0000] <Hixie>
hm yeah i should allow the UA to break early if it can prove that it wouldn't ever accept the connection

[23:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
assume that i'll make that allowed

[23:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
i hadn't thought of breaking early

[23:30:00.0000] <zcorpan>
Hixie: thanks

[23:30:01.0000] <Hixie>
in case i forget by the time i reply to your e-mail, just remind me of the above :-)

[23:31:00.0000] <zcorpan>
ok

[23:31:01.0000] <Hixie>
